Lovett Cameron, R.N., on "Africa."

The lecturer said that the further British influence extended in Africa the more would slavery of every kind be done away with. Besides illegal slavery, there was extensively practised in Africa a system of native despotism which it was very desirable should be abolished. In 1876 nobody seemed to take any notice of Africa, and the exportation of India-rubber from Zanzibar amounted to something under £20,000. Now the amount was about £250,000! With respect to ill-health in that continent, he had found that some of the native treatments were by no means to be despised, and many of our English doctors could take a leaf out of their book. The record of men who had travelled through Africa and endured every conceivable kind of hardship proved that Africa had been cursed by the idea of its unhealthiness, a reproach which it did not deserve. The great thing required, however, was adequate communication. African travelling, under present circumstances, meant, at the outside, fifty miles in a week. At the present time every mile of railroad laid down in Africa drove a dozen nails into the coffin of the slave-trade, to say nothing of the immense impetus to trade and commerce which would thus be afforded. From Cairo right away to the Albert Nyanza was navigable water. There would be no difficulty in overcoming the obstacles of cataracts, &c., which modern engineering would easily surmount. The central high plateau of Africa was, to a great extent, in British hands, and offered the most important means of repressing the slave-trade in future. Every slave working at the present time was in direct defiance of the Act of 1873. Mr. Rhodes' great railway, which would reach Zambesia within eight years, should be kept under British control, as native treaties were more or less uncertain. In 1876 they could have obtained all that is now German territory by holding up their hands. The Germans, however, are practically locked in. A dispute had been going on with Portugal as to whether the Zambesi was an open highway. Fortunately, owing to the twenty-one miles strip of land granted by England to Germany these two powers would be as one on the question, and in future arbitration claim the Zambesi as an open highway. A wise system of emigration should be conducted. He would like to see Indian planters transferred there, and Chinese too. Africa offered an excellent opening for the English working man, and it was desirable that the Government should protect its emigrants. The dangers of Africa were largely dwelt on nowadays, and its advantages were put in the rear. This was the reason why the development of that great continent was so far behind hand.

The following resolution was proposed by Admiral Field, M.P., seconded by Mr. Johnson (of the Stanley Falls, Congo):—', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Although the Lagos Colony extends on paper as far as the right bank of the Benin, no authority is exercised by the Lagos officials further east than Leki. At Benin River begins the British protectorate of the Niger territories, which extends along the coast of the German boundary of the Cameroons at the Rio del Rey, and inland for an immense distance along the main streams of the Niger and Benin—in fact, one might say right into the heart of the Western Soudan, to places such as Ribago on the extreme Upper Benin that are in touch with Darfur, Egypt, and Tripoli. The Niger territories are under the administration of the Royal Niger Company, to whom a charter was granted about two years ago. But a considerable portion of the delta and the basin of the Cross River beyond has been, and still is, under the administration of Consular officers, who, by virtue of certain Orders in Council, govern the country through the native chiefs. It was in occupying this function that I have recently been employed in West Africa. It is understood, that the Government are engaged in the consideration of a scheme for placing the Niger territories not at present administered by the Royal Niger Company under some more definite and direct administration, and to better attain this purpose a commissioner is to be dispatched early in the present year for the purpose of reporting on the views and wishes of the natives. When the Niger Delta is endowed with a permanent Government, it will prove one of the most valuable and easily governed of all our West African possessions.

From statistics I have compiled, I find that the entire trade of Great Britain with the British possessions on the West Coast of Africa for the year 1888—or, let us say, from December 1, 1887, to December 1, 1888—amounted to an approximate value of £5,012,210, that is to say, £2,423,840 worth of imports and £2,588,370 in exports. I think the figures I have quoted, which represent only the trade of British West Africa with Great Britain (a further amount being with Havre and Hamburg, and that, moreover, carried in British ships), will convince you that our trade with West Africa is no trifle to be despised and neglected by politicians.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CAPTAIN CAMERON, R.N., ON AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"This meeting views with satisfaction the attention paid by her Majesty's Government to British interests in Africa, and trusts that the results of their policy may be beneficial alike to the natives and to the legitimate enterprise of British subjects in that continent."

After an animated discussion, in which various gentlemen interested took part, the resolution was carried unanimously.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.7, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British possessions of the Gold Coast extend over a coast line of about 350 miles, and are separated from the colony of Lagos by a short interval, which is filled up by a wedge of German, two wedges of French territory, and the narrow strip of independent Dahomie coast, which was until recently under the protection of the Portuguese. The inland limits of the Gold Coast colony are vague, and variable in extent. Behind our actual possessions, our political influence largely extends, and might be exercised much to the benefit of the interior were we less timorous about asserting it. In spite of several alterations in our Ashanti policy, we may consider the Ashanti kingdom as within the sphere of political influence. It would not be difficult to extend British influence from the Gold Coast right up to the great bend of the Niger, and thus secure them to British commercial influence. When we think of how much has been effected in the consolidation and extension of our Gold Coast territories since 1871, we may confidently hope for a further extension and a great future for this rich and important possession. The littoral of the Gold Coast is of the same moist equatorial character in its climate and scenery. The typical West African forest country ends, however, on the northern frontiers of Ashanti, and the characteristic park-like grass land scenery of Central Africa begins in the plains through which the Upper Volta flows. Beyond the Volta and the countries of Gyaman, Ashanti, and Brono, the inhabitants are mainly Mahommedans, and belong to a stock related to the Mandingos, although there is a large infusion of immigrant Hausa traders and fighting men. In some of these lands a proportion of the Hausa constabulary of the Gold Coast is recruited. Although the inhabitants of the Gold Coast belong almost entirely to what may be called the Ashanti family, yet increasingly the Hausa language is becoming the commercial tongue of the natives, although English has a great hold and is extending. The influence of the Hausa, no doubt, is aided by the presence of the constabulary, who are either recruited on the Niger or at the back of the Gold Coast. A most valuable arm they are likely to prove. They are very brave, very sober, and very loyal to their white officers.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Commercial Value of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Altogether our West African possessions do a trade with Great Britain (mainly with Liverpool, London, and Bristol) of about £5,000,000 yearly, give honourable employment to some 770 of our British fellow-countrymen, and bring at least 5,000,000 of intelligent (Sierra Leone), sturdy (Krumen), industrious (Gold Coast), artistic (Yoruba), brave (Niger), good-tempered (Oil Rivers) negroes under our sway. I have dwelt more in detail on the extent of our interests in West Africa than on those which we possess in other parts of the Continent, because it is with West Africa that the inhabitants and commerce of the United Kingdom are most concerned. I mean that the trade of our West African possessions, and the employment given to British subjects, are directed almost solely to Great Britain. If we gave away the Gold Coasts or Lagos, or the Niger, for instance, in exchange for concessions from France or Germany in the Pacific or the North Atlantic, the ratio of loss to the inhabitants of Great Britain would be far greater than the gain to the Australians or the Newfoundlanders. To those who argue that our missionaries and merchants might go on working in West Africa just the same, even if the rule in our possession were transferred to another Power, I would ask, 'How many British merchants are there in French Senegambia? What is the total of British trade with the French, German, Belgian, Portuguese possessions in West Africa as compared to that carried on with the districts under the British flag? Are the British missionaries able to conduct their evangelisation in French Africa? In the most enlightened and liberal-minded of these foreign administrations, the German possession of Cameroons, did not the English Baptist Mission, who had laboured there for forty years prior to the German advent, have to leave the country after the German rule was established?' We should not blame the Governments of foreign powers for these results. The fault lies in our peculiar idiosyncrasies as a people. We are of a cranky, self-willed, unaccommodating disposition, tolerably patient under the government of our own fellow-countrymen, but utterly impatient of foreign control. While, however, our possessions of Western Africa are become a necessity to the trade of Liverpool, Manchester, Burnley, Birmingham, Leeds, Sheffield, Bristol, and London, our newly-gained spheres of influence in South Central Africa—besides the important Scotch interests which they concern—are a necessity for the commercial expansion and feeding-ground of our growing British South African Confederation, which has a total population of over 2,000,000, and does a yearly trade with the United Kingdom of £18,000,000 in value. Then as to Zanzibar and British East Africa, they, in their turn, besides securing the southern approach to the dominions of our Egyptian ward, are a necessity to the trade and overflow emigration of our great Indian Empire, with its nearly 300,000,000 of people and its yearly trade with the British Empire of some £90,000,000. The trade of the British Empire with British Africa amounts to about £25,200,000 yearly. Among the more valuable products which British Africa sends us, or supplies to herself, may be cited the following: gold, silver, copper, coal, diamonds, ivory, rubber, palm oil, palm kernels, gums, cotton, dyewoods, indigo, coffee, sugar, rice, Indian corn, horses, cattle, donkeys, hides, amomum seeds, red peppers, and many other valuable dyes, spices, oils, timber, drugs, skins, and farinaceous foods.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'British Influence on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following letter has been addressed recently to Earl Granville by the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, on behalf of the African Trade Section of that Chamber:—

"My Lord,—I am requested by the Council of this Chamber to ask that your serious consideration may be given to the following facts, many of which are doubtless well known to you, but which have a special significance owing to the position of matters in West Africa at the present time. The British protectorate, as you are aware, is extended over a large portion of the Coast of Africa, which stretches from the settlement of Sierra Leone to the district of the Niger. Upon this coast, excluding the State of Liberia and the neighbourhood of Whydah, the port of Dahomey, there are three French settlements—viz., Grand Bassam, Assinie, and Porto Novo; also portions of coast unprotected by any European Power. West of Grand Bassam there is unoccupied coast of considerable extent; east of Lagos, beyond Leckie, and reaching to Old Calabar, there is the important territory at the mouths of the Niger. Quite recently the Germans have taken certain ports on this coast—viz., Ahgweh, Bageida, and Little Popo. At these there was a thriving and increasing British trade, and with the chiefs of Ahgweh and Little Popo treaties had been made on behalf of Her Majesty, securing the right of British subjects to trade on equal terms with those of any other nation. The occupation by France and the late annexations by Germany break the continuity of the British protectorate; there is an increasing conflict of the various national interests, and the influence of the British authorities with the natives is being lessened; the introduction of different principles of trading will also seriously affect the prosperity of British commerce. It is important to mention in this connexion that the duties upon spirits, arms, and ammunition levied in the British settlements furnish the greater portion of the Government revenue. In German and French settlements these articles are known, in most cases, to be free of duty, and being sold to a great extent in the same markets as the British imports, competition becomes difficult, and the loss to the British revenue and trade must ultimately be great. The Chamber would suggest, therefore, that while negotiations regarding African territories are pending, something might be done in the way of exchange or by mutual concession to induce Germany, at least, to withdraw from those newly acquired ports where British trade had become established, and where German rivalry upon different principles is likely to be so injurious. This Government might also be requested to take into consideration the question of the extension of the British protectorate to the unprotected portion of the coast named.—I am, &c.,

"C. B. Paris, President,  
"Thomas H. Barker, Secretary."', 'last_edit_date': '1885-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1885#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH ADMINISTRATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The present is a very critical time in the history of the British West African Colonies. It is a fact well within the knowledge of all interested in the welfare of the oldest British colony in Africa that for some years past the French, by means of treaties made with the chiefs of the Upper Niger and Western Soudan, have been gradually encroaching upon the hitherto not very well-defined boundaries of the Colony of Sierra Leone, with the result of gradually reducing the British sphere of influence, and at the same time narrowing the field from which the merchants and traders of that Colony draw their native produce, and in which, in return, they have been in the habit of finding a market for their imported goods. Rather more than two years ago, an agreement was concluded at Paris between our Government and that of France with regard to the boundaries of their respective spheres of influence in West Africa. The territories referred to in the agreement were Senegambia, Sierra Leone, the Gold Coast, and the Slave Coast. It was provided that the two Governments should have the right of appointing special Commissions of Delimitation "to trace upon the spot, wherever they may consider it necessary, the line of demarcation between the English and French possessions" in conformity with the agreement. The work of determining the boundary line between Senegambia and Sierra Leone is now about to be begun, the British Commissioners having left Liverpool on Saturday last. For some time past British merchants interested in commerce with Sierra Leone have been apprehensive that their trade with the interior might be seriously interfered with, if not absolutely ruined, by a wrongful definition of the boundary. Our trade with Sierra Leone is mainly dependent upon the caravan traffic between the British port of Freetown and the upper portion of the Niger.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'IN THE MONTH that has just ended, our Gallic neighbours have entered into two treaties affecting different parts of Africa, which are not unlikely to have an important bearing upon the future of the so-called Dark Continent. The treaty concluded with Liberia is doubtless intended to increase French prestige and authority upon the West Coast; but the future of that country of repatriated Negroes is so entirely problematical, that we may safely leave the effect of this convention to the development of years, only observing that for the present, at any rate, British interests are not likely to be affected by it to any serious degree. But with regard to the Treaty entered into with the Congo Free State, the case is somewhat different. France has for years made no secret of its desire to form a vast Colonial Empire in Central Africa, and has repeatedly urged its rights of succession to the territory of the Congo State if once, from any cause, the present status comes to an end. By this new agreement the boundaries of the "spheres of influence" of these two States have been definitely arranged, and a troublesome controversy thereby removed. Great Britain and the Congo State came to a somewhat similar arrangement a few months ago, and then the French showed themselves jealous, as usual, of what they were pleased to call our "greed." By that agreement the Congo State recognised that the whole of the Upper Nile valley was within the British sphere, and Great Britain leased to King Leopold, as the sovereign of the Free State, a large slice of territory on the left bank of the Nile. This lease was to remain valid during the King's life: afterwards the territory to revert to Great Britain with the exception that, so long as the Congo Free State existed as an independent State or a Belgian colony.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1894#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AT THE MEETING OF THE BRITISH ASSOCIATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the meeting of the British Association, held this year at Newcastle-on-Tyne, the things of Africa came in for a good deal of discussion and consideration.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I must preface this article by two definitions. For want of a better concise name I shall use the vague term "Central Africa" to describe the more or less malarious portion of that continent lying between (say) the eighteenth parallels of north and south latitude, exclusive of the maritime regions within twenty or thirty miles of the seaboard, which can look to European fleets for protection of life and property. Central Africa, thus defined, is about thirty times the area of France, and fifty times that of the United Kingdom, and probably contains about one-twelfth of the population of the globe. In the second place, and for the same reason, I use the word "England" for "Great Britain and Ireland," and "Englishmen" for the inhabitants of this country. "Britain" and "Britons" are, unfortunately, considered pedantic in prose.

The Anglo-German and Anglo-Portuguese agreements of 1890 have induced a colonial movement in France which, in this age of electricity, may be described as a strong secondary current. Competent authorities tell us that this agitation is no longer confined to colonial enthusiasts, but has penetrated into the mass of the nation; and a number of expeditions have lately been despatched from widely separated points of the African coast to extend French rights into the heart of the continent. The inadequate recognition in England of this movement may perhaps be attributed to a well-founded belief on the part of "Our own Correspondents" that the British public has lately had a surfeit of the Dark Continent.

It may seem illogical that the demarcation by other countries of spheres of influence in East and South Africa should affect the estimates which France had previously formed of the value of the regions bordering on her possessions in the north and west of the Continent; but it is not in France alone that the fever of annexation proves contagious. To this cause, principally, may be attributed the popularity of propositions for the immediate occupation of vast areas of Central Africa. Two minor causes have contributed to this movement. The first has been the downfall of the Boulangists, who had opposed colonial adventures; partly, no doubt, from a belief in the necessity of concentrating the forces of France at home, and, perhaps, partly from a desire to oppose any policy which had been adopted by their bête noire. Now M. Ferry, having recognised the hegemony of Germany in Europe, had, during his tenure of power, sought to direct the energies of France to compensations abroad. The reaction against Boulangism has

hh: The recruitment and effective performance of African soldiers in colonial military forces, such as the Yoruba battalion, demonstrate their perceived competence and adaptability, influenced by their unique cultural experiences and openness to international engagement.
result: The recruitment and effective performance of African soldiers in colonial military forces, such as the Yoruba battalion, are supported by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook provides a broad context, highlighting that African recruits were enlisted through various means, including voluntary service, conscription, and forced 'volunteering.' It notes the willingness of some African groups, like the Senegalese citoyens, to accept military obligations in exchange for citizenship rights, reflecting adaptability and engagement with international norms. The text also discusses the integration of Western innovations and military techniques by African societies, indicating openness to external influences, though it does not specifically mention the Yoruba battalion. In contrast, The African Times articles offer more specific details, emphasizing the competence and adaptability of African soldiers, such as the Yoruba battalion's recruitment efforts in Ibadan with local authorities' assistance, and the Hausa's fearlessness and resilience in battle. The articles also highlight the historical context of African soldiers in the West India regiments, attributing their loyalty and effectiveness to cultural experiences and training. However, they also mention challenges, such as the weakening of regiments due to racial mixing and logistical difficulties in recruiting carriers in Lagos. Together, these sources illustrate a complex picture of African soldiers' roles in colonial military forces, underscoring their perceived competence and adaptability while acknowledging the challenges they faced.

[{'document_title': 'The First World War and its consequences', 'section_title': 'The African involvement in the War', 'content': "Recruits for both fighting and carrier service were raised by three methods. The first was on a purely volunteer basis where Africans offered their services freely without any outside pressure. Thus, in the early stages of the war on the Palestine and Syrian fronts, large numbers of im› poverished fallâhïn (peasants) in Egypt offered their services in return for what were comparatively attractive wages. There is no doubt that in most African countries there were volunteers for the army who knew exactly what enlistment entailed. The Senegalese citoyens of the Four Communes of Senegal were quite prepared to accept the full obligations of compulsory military service exacted from Metropolitan Frenchmen if it would guarantee their own status as citizens. And to this end their Deputy, Blaise Diagne, secured the passage of a Law of 29 September 1916 which stated that 'the natives of the communes de plein exercice of Senegal are and remain French citizens as provided for by the law of 15 October 1915'. In Madagascar all 45 000 recruits into the French army were said to have been volunteers,$^{24}$ but the great majority of African recruits went into the various armies against their will, either as forced 'volunteers' or as conscripts.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'Change and continuity', 'content': 'Nor is the 'traditional-modern' polar model, with all its attendant implications of conflict and incompatibility, applicable to the entire spectrum of African experience of change under colonialism. There were manifold variations in the reaction of African cultures to western innova› tions. Not only were certain customs and beliefs discarded or modified, but some were retained at one level of society at the same time as new alternatives were being accepted at another level. Thus while human sacrifice, the slave trade and the killing of twins were discarded in societies where such practices had existed, and old and new ideas were amalgamated in the sphere of religion, the European ideal of monogamous marriage, accepted as part of an expected public image by sections of the westernized elite, exists side by side under the law with the institution of polygamy among the urban and rural masses. [{'id': 105, 'article_title': 'ANAMABOE.', 'full_section_title': 'ANAMABOE.', 'last_edit_date': '01-14-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': "There were assembled at this time in the square at least ten thousand armed men, hedged in by a dense mass of spectators. In the midst of the armed men were seen here and there the large umbrellas of the different Cabboceers and chiefs. These umbrellas might be called tents almost, for some of them are large enough to afford shelter to ten or fifteen men. They are made of silk and satin of the most gorgeous colours and the most expensive description, and on the top of each there is an ornament in either gold, silver, or wood, which is, literally, the crest of the owner. The numerous flags of the different companies added greatly to the effect. These flags, all of which had the Union Jack in the corner, were made some of silk and some of ordinary bunting, and had devices, something similar to those which ornamented the tops of the Cabboceers' umbrellas, worked in them. It is these devices in flags and figures on the umbrellas which have so often caused jealousies, leading to the shedding of blood; but such events rarely occur now, for the people are getting more enlightened. The whole of the force being now assembled, they fired a grand salute, which lasted nearly one hour, after which the King and chiefs alighted from their baskets and ascended to the verandah, where they were introduced to, and had a long interview with, his Excellency. The King and all his chiefs were arrayed most gorgeously in silk togas, and were preceded by all the insignia of their respective offices—two-edged swords with gold and silver handles, gold and silver sticks and messengers' canes, elephants' tails mounted in the same precious metals, and musical instruments of African manufacture, rude, but by no means so unpleasant as might be supposed. The King and some of the principal chiefs, one of them the uncle of a member of the Legislative Council of these settlements, were literally groaning under the weight of the gold ornaments, manufactured and rough, with which they were covered. Their attendants were also attired in most superb habiliments. Their guards, though not exactly habited as troops are in civilised countries, were yet, in dress, very far removed from that state in which some ungenerous persons from more civilised lands delight to depict them. These men presented a most creditable appearance, which went far to prove that the natives of the Gold Coast are not the least advanced amongst the sons of Africa in civilization. I have never been in America, nor have I ever seen American volunteers; but I have read a great deal regarding them in the English and American papers of late; and if half that I have read respecting them is true, then I think that we Africans, who do not profess to be so civilised, need not to be ashamed of our black troops that passed in review before the Governor of the Gold Coast on this occasion *(To be continued.)*"}, {'id': 639, 'article_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '06-23-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_06_1865', 'content': 'In the report on Lagos will be found a more particular account of the history and characteristics of this tribe, who, in addition to their other good qualities, have, unlike most other natives on the coast, no objection to go to other countries, many of them having readily enlisted for service in a black regiment in the West Indies.

Protected as the West Coast Settlements have been hitherto by a body of regular troops, it would not be expedient to make suddenly the experiment of confiding their security entirely to a local force, but as a sufficient number of houssas can be organised, a reduction may be effected in the strength of the garrisons, especially of the minor settlements, and the chief part of the troops concentrated at Sierra Leone, where it would be, with the increased facilities of communication to be supplied, at once available for movement on any point where it might appear to the head of the Government that its services could be usefully and judiciously employed.

The concentration of the Government, the employment of additional steamers, and the organisation of a new police force will involve a considerable addition of expense, which most of the colonies are certainly not now in a condition to meet. With improved administration will, no doubt, come an improved revenue, and the time may not be far distant when under such circumstances they will be able to bear the whole cost of their Government; for the present, however, aid must be continued to be given them, and when it is noticed (Return, No. 31, Appendix) that of the £89,500 which is the total cost of their establishments, they raise £77,000, leaving but £12,500 to be supplied from Imperial funds, it must be admitted that according to their means they contribute fairly to the expense of their administration.

If, however, the proposed reductions of the military establishments be carried into effect, there will result a very large saving to the Imperial Government on this head, and it may be presumed that should inquiry establish the propriety of retaining the settlements, such assistance will be afforded as may be necessary to place them in a position to discharge efficiently, though economically, the important objects for which they will be maintained.—I have, &c.,

(Signed) H. St. George Ord.'}, {'id': 5796, 'article_title': 'THE NEGRO FROM A MILITARY POINT OF VIEW', 'full_section_title': 'THE NEGRO FROM A MILITARY POINT OF VIEW', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-7', 'issue_date': '04_02_1889', 'content': '### THE NEGRO FROM A MILITARY POINT OF VIEW.

**LORD WOLSELEY**, in an article which he has contributed to the *Fortnightly Review*, discusses the military qualities of the negro, and the causes to which they are due. "I know of nothing so debasing," says he, "as cowardice in a people." Yet of the three peoples whose courage he extols he attributes the possession of it in the first to fear (the Ashantees), in the second to pride (the Zulus), and in the third to bigotry (the Soudanese).

In the first place, the writer has something to say about the West Coast natives as soldiers. Of the old slave-recruited West India regiments, he entertains a high opinion. The African slave had two great merits as a soldier—derived from his instinct as a savage and his training as a slave. The instinct of some breeds of dogs renders it easy to teach them their special work, which other species, though equally intelligent, cannot be effectively taught. The wild tribes dependent upon hunting for their daily food possess a sort of intuitive knowledge of wild animals, of their ways and habits, which give them an immense advantage over the ordinary town-bred soldier. The trapper's life of hardship and privation fits him physically for the ups and downs and rough usage which war brings with it. The hunter is already half a soldier, and not only accepts the miseries of war in an uncomplaining spirit, but regards them as the ordinary incidents of everyday life. The African in our West India regiments has always displayed that childlike affection for, and implicit reliance upon, the officers who treated him well, which is so marked a feature in the character of the negro slave. A certain governor, finding that his servants were given to robbing him, had orders given to the sentry before his door that no one was to be allowed out carrying any parcel with him. Shortly afterwards the governor himself put some papers up to take with him to the judge's house. But the sentry would not allow him to pass with the offending despatch-box. He said his "copral" had told him not to allow anyone with a bundle to pass, and the "copral's" order was law. Since the old slave days, the *personnel* of the West India regiments has, Lord Wolseley thinks, declined. The infusion of white blood into the negro race has weakened its strength and impaired his courage. The only countervailing advantage is that civilisation has made him more teachable. The man who has been educated in Barbados to read his Bible and has learned to sing hymns, acquires a knowledge of drill more easily than the released slave who came from Equatorial Africa.'}, {'id': 6873, 'article_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS.', 'full_section_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1897#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_12_1897', 'content': 'The British & African Co's steamer "Accra" arrived at Liverpool on Nov. 10 from West Africa with mails and passengers. She left Old Calabar on Oct. 9 and met the Protectorate gunboat Ivy coming in with the King of Benin on board. The King had been round in the steamer to most of the rivers in the Protectorate. When the Accra left Lagos on Oct. 15, the West India troops were still in the town as carriers could not be got for them. Fifteen hundred carriers were required, and, up to the time of leaving, only 300 had been obtained. The French at Porto Novo were pressing the Natives into their service, and all able-bodied men in the villages round the town were being forced to go up into the interior with their troops. The French at Porto Novo were also contemplating putting a tax on produce which was sent from Porto Novo to Lagos for shipment. The produce in question comes down the Lagoon from Porto Novo and is shipped to England and the continent. This tax is to compel the shippers instead of sending the produce through the British Colony, to send it to Kotonu, the French port. Captain Creighton, A.D.C. to Governor M'Callum, was at Ibadan recruiting Natives for a new battalion of troops. The new troops were to be called the Yoruba battalion, and were to be 1,000 strong. The authorities at Ibadan were assisting the British to recruit able-bodied men. Mr. Fuller had been appointed British Resident at Ibadan, succeeding Capt. Bower. Governor M'Callum had had another attack of fever, but had recovered when the Accra passed. It was reported that the Governor himself intended going up into the hinterland with the troops. Information from the interior received at Lagos said that the French when they got into the Saki were told by the chiefs of that place that it belonged to the English. They however would not retire, but sent an expedition against Ilesha. The Natives of Ilesha gave the French such a reception that they had to retire defeated with several killed and wounded.

The French Commander was wounded by arrows. Subsequently the French left Saki and occupied Kissi. As the French went through the English territory on the march from Porto Novo it is reported that they seized British subjects and pressed them into their service as carriers.'}]

[{'document_title': 'Some Facts About the Hausas', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Hausa Native is perfectly black, but he does not possess such thick lips or such curly hair as we are accustomed to associate with the ordinary negro. He is naturally a trader rather than a soldier, but when trained, as he has frequently been down on the coast, by English officers, he is more than a match for any other Native. The Governor of the Gold Coast told me that in a battle the Hausas appeared utterly devoid of fear, and that the only difficulty was to restrain them. It would not infrequently happen that a small body of Hausas, having defeated the enemy to whom they were opposed, would pursue them to a considerable distance from the scene of battle, and perhaps stop to raid their village before returning to look after or assist their companions. It is hard for anyone who has not actually seen Hausa porters to believe the weights which they are accustomed to carry. While staying at Lokoja, the officer in command of the Royal Niger Company's Hausa troops pointed out to me a mountain gun lying on the ground, and asked me if I could lift it. With considerable difficulty I succeeded in raising it about an inch off the ground. He then told me that one of their Hausa soldiers was regularly accustomed to carry this gun on his head. On my appearing somewhat incredulous, he had the man sent for, and told him to put the gun upon his head, which he proceeded to do, and walked for some little distance with it. The officer told me that on one occasion he had been known to carry this gun twenty-two miles in the day. If you ask a Hausa why his people are so strong, he will tell you that it is because of the different food which he eats. The tribes in the Niger delta and near the sea coast live for the most part on yams and bananas, which are produced with the minimum amount of labour. The Hausas live almost entirely on guinea-corn, a species of millet, which has a very minute and hard red grain. This is ground up by the natives, and, mixed with water, makes a sort of porridge, which has, however, a most disagreeable sour taste.", 'last_edit_date': '1897-01-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1897#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.617, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SURGEONS FOR THE GOLD COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Army Medical Department has been advertising in the daily papers for assistant surgeons to serve on the West Coast of Africa—at Sierra Leone, the Gambia, and the Gold Coast.

We feel that this advertisement for assistant surgeons calls for especial notice from us. It appears inexplicable to us, if the Army Medical Department believe the climate to be so bad as is pretended, and as the seeming necessity of advertising for assistant surgeons would induce the uninitiated to believe, that they do not encourage coloured surgeons to apply for these ap-

[NOVEMBER 23, 1863.

appointments. It was our intention to have entered at large upon this subject on this occasion, but the time and space at our disposal this month will not allow of our doing full justice to it. We are reluctantly compelled to postpone it till our December number. But we cannot close even this brief allusion to it without saying that the capacity and capabilities of properly-educated Africans to serve with distinction as medical officers is now so clearly established, that, for many important reasons, we consider it incumbent on the Army Medical Department, as a strict matter of duty, to endeavour to avail themselves of the services of properly-qualified coloured gentlemen for these appointments of assistant surgeons on the West Coast, provided such can be found. And we will go one step further—viz., that it is the duty of the Department to give the preference to such gentlemen.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SURGEONS FOR THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In our last number we briefly remarked on the Army Medical Department having recently advertised for assistant-surgeons for service in our West African colonies. We then took occasion to suggest that a preference should be given to black, or coloured medical men, provided such could be found in every respect properly qualified to perform the duties of these appointments. We believe that there would be no difficulty whatever in finding educated men of colour who would gladly accept these appointments. We therefore again strenuously advocate their being employed, not only because such a step would save the country the large sum of money which at present is annually expended in providing European medical officers with passages to and from the Coast, but because of its paramount importance in the saving of human life. For the fact has been established in the most satisfactory and conclusive manner, that the negro is exempt from attacks of yellow fever; and this is a fact which should never be forgotten, but ought to be constantly borne in mind. We desire not to be misunderstood, or as advocating that the army and colonial medical officers on this Coast should consist only of negro surgeons; all we contend for is, that medical men of that race ought to be exclusively stationed in localities notoriously known to be at present most dangerous to European health and life: and partially in every other colony or dependency on the West African Coast. Among the former we should rank Macarthy's Island, in the River Gambia, where, in 1859, three medical men died from yellow fever. We confess, however, that we cannot", 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.6, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.606, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MANUFACTURERS IN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The tribes might readily be imagined. The cities were surrounded by walls and ditches, a large proportion of the young men followed the business of war, and all able-bodied men were liable to be called upon to protect their homesteads. In spite of these drawbacks, Yorubaland was well and widely cultivated, thickly inhabited, and full of local commercial activity. The price of food prevailing throughout Yoruba would show how industrious were the people and how rich its soil. Maize in the grain sold in the public market place at 6d. per cwt., large yams at 3d. a dozen, sweet potatoes at 1½d. per cwt., beans at 1s. 6d. a cwt., and eggs at from ¾d. to 2d. a dozen, while the most expensive luxuries of beef and mutton were sold for less than 1d. a pound, goats from 2s. 6d. each, sheep from 7s. to 8s., fowls for 3s. a score, and the small cattle of the country from 30s. to £2 10s. each. For 40 cowries—four-fifths of a halfpenny—his wife were in the habit of receiving a good meal. The city of Ibadan was the capital of Yoruba, the London of Negroland. It was surrounded by 163 farming villages, and was estimated to have a population of 250,000, while within the walls of the city 120,000 people were gathered. Other considerable towns were found at distances of a day's journey from one another. The trails throughout the country were kept in order by the farmers and villagers. Yoruba held out good prospects of commercial development, for the natives were not only industrious agriculturists for the purpose of supplying their daily wants in food, but they were also a people whose standard of comfort led them to spend much labour in raising and preparing luxuries which could be more cheaply supplied to them from Europe. Backed by the authority of the leading men in the country, he was able by personal inspection to satisfy himself as to the stock of cloth owned by the people, and the quantity annually consumed. He found that, taking an average of rich and poor, an annual consumption of cotton, silk, grass, and mixture cloths existed amounted to not less than 30 yards for each male adult, 45 yards for each female adult, and 6 yards for each child. The Yorubas were a fully-clad race, who for fashion's sake were ashamed to appear in public unless gracefully draped with two or three ample cloths. The price of such goods varied from threepence to half-a-crown per yard. They were made of home grown materials, dyed with native dyes, and woven in narrow looms or frames out of yarn spun by hand. From careful calculation it appeared that 31,000,000 yards of cloth were annually consumed in Yoruba, of which 30,000,000 were of home manufacture. From this they would be able to realise the extent to which the people were engaged in the work of making their own garments. In Yoruba there was an immediate market for European goods worth half a million a year, and in return for those goods the people there had the will and the necessary amount of produce to put at least an equal value of trade into our hands. By opening up the rivers of navigable depth there was no doubt that the trade could at least be doubled. These natural waterways were unfortunately as completely choked by vegetation as the overland trade routes were blocked by a rank growth of middlemen. To the industrious and struggling Yorubas, an opening for their energies in the direction of commerce would be invaluable. The Government of this country had for some time been actively engaged in negotiating the opening of the trade routes to the interior by land and water without infringing upon the liberty of the tribes, who were much better left to manage their own affairs, and without using unwise or arbitrary measures. Could other tribes be persuaded, "for a consideration," to relinquish their commercial blockade, which might or might not be quite within their legal rights, there was no doubt that they would be the first to profit by the access of prosperity which would follow. And the Yorubas would profit in no less a degree. Their warlike young men would find in trade an adventurous life well suited to their training, which at present unfitted them for more peaceful employment; a less limited supply of arms would restore the balance of power in the interior, and insure the safety of the coast, while the terrors of the slave trade would give way to a large extent to the more profitable occupations of commercial enterprise.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-07-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_07_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SURGEONS FOR THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In our next number we shall continue our remarks on this highly-important subject. Meanwhile, we repeat that it is the duty of the Army Medical Department to give the preference to properly-qualified gentlemen of colour for appointments as assistant-surgeons on the West Coast of Africa; and add, that if the encouragement thereby given fails in inducing an adequate number of young Africans to devote themselves to the medical profession (a result, we unhesitatingly state, about which no apprehension need at present be entertained), some liberal measure should then be devised in order to bring about this most desirable result.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.611, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Capabilities of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Dear Brother in the cause of God and humanity,—The elevation of Africa is near my heart, and anything that promises to aid in rescuing her from her long and deep degradation meets a warm response in my heart. I feel identified with the coloured race by my five years' imprisonment in Missouri, on account of my love of the slave, and by my six years' residence in West Africa, where I laboured hard and suffered much for them; and should probably have remained, but for the ill-health of my family—wife and child. We had buried our first-born there, a little boy of six years.

But poor Africa—what can be done for her? I rejoice in the success of Dr. Livingston, and of every other explorer and labourer in Africa; but much more need to be and can be done for her. 1. She needs missionaries and teachers, but these alone will not do the work needed. Accompanying them should be (2) farmers and mechanics, who can teach them civilization, for both must go together—civilization and Christianity: either without the other will fail; but both united will, with God's blessing, lift her up, and soon give her a place among the nations.

She has natural resources abundant. 1. The people are capable of being educated in the arts and sciences, in which they make rapid proficiency when an opportunity is provided. In managing business, mercantile or other, they manifest an ability equal to the whites. The richest men in Sierra Leone are negroes who were taken out of the slave ship. They make very efficient preachers, teachers, mechanics, farmers, &c., when instructed.

2. The country is rich—very productive in many things needful for commerce and home consumption. Rice, Indian corn, and some smaller grains, suited to exportation, can be produced to any extent. Ginger, pepper, arrowroot, can be supplied to meet the wants of the world. Coffee and cotton of fine quality grow wild abundantly, and can be cultivated to any extent to supply Manchester and every cotton factory in Christendom. There only needs to do this to start it all along the Western Coast, and make a market for them, and the natives will go to producing them. They will work at what they can make the most money by. Africa is by far the best and most natural coffee and cotton country in the world, and, I will add, sugar-cane also. These articles are spontaneous products of the soil. Coffee is a forest tree, from twenty to seventy-five feet high, as I saw myself, and is cultivated with great care. Cotton grows to quite a bush, from six to ten feet high, and the same bush bears a crop every year; and sugar-cane, when once planted, will shoot up and make new crops as often as cut down. These things I have seen.

3. And her minerals are rich and abundant. Gold and iron ore, the purest in the world, is very abundant in many parts. Copper, zinc, lead, &c., have been discovered, how abundant we know not. Coal has been found on the West and East Coast.", 'last_edit_date': '1861-10-14', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_02_1862#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.602, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Though Englishmen naturally think that English rule is best, other nations cannot be as thoroughly persuaded of the truth. Provided Frenchmen, Germans, and Portuguese exercise their rights according to the dictates of international equity and Christian civilisation, they are to be welcomed as fellow labourers rather than regarded as of interlopers. Their recent activity has had the result of animating the sense among Englishmen of the splendour of their African inheritance. Without the presence of Frenchmen and Germans in the vicinity the British plantations would have remained as slumberous as they have been in the past. Now that international rivalry has awakened them they will find an ample range for all reasonable ambition. Their business is to teach the negro race within the compass of their sway how to extract the benefit for itself from the destiny which has given it Englishmen for its rulers.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.602, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Condition of the Congo State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'No agent may undertake hostilities against the Natives, except for legitimate purposes of defence or unless duly authorised by the Commissioner of the district or the commander of the expedition to which he is attached. Moreover, regular and auxiliary troops which take part in the war operations must always be commanded by a European. No exception to this rule will be exercised, and agents infringing it will be liable to be recalled without prejudice to the judicial proceedings which there may be ground to take against them. In the event of hostilities, the property of Natives must not be destroyed, and upon no pretext must villages be burnt as a means of repression. European officers and their subordinates must especially take care that the operations are conducted in such a way as to avoid all cruelty. The wounded rebels must be carefully tended, and the bodies of the dead must be respected. The Europeans must absolutely forbid the barbarous mutilation of bodies, such as Natives often practice among themselves. The European leaders of any war party will be held personally responsible for all cruelties of this nature which they permit; and the guilty parties will be tried by court-martial and judged in accordance with the laws.

Prisoners of war and hostages must be treated with humanity, and it is formally forbidden to maltreat them. If there are women and children among them they must be placed under the direct protection of the commander of the operations.

The agents must remember that the disciplinary penalties, provided for by the regulations of military discipline, are only applicable to military recruits and solely there for breaches of discipline and under the conditions specially provided for by the aforesaid regulations. They are not applicable on any pretext to civil servants of the State or to Natives, whether the latter are or are not in rebellion against the State. Those who are charged with offences or crimes must be brought before the competent tribunals and judged according to the laws.

Agents infringing the regulations regarding the relations which they must observe with the Natives, or tolerating mutilations or cruelties on the part of their soldiers, will, in the case of their committing the offences specified, be brought up for trial. Moreover, agents found guilty, who have received the star for service, will be deprived of their right to wear it.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-09-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.6, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In New Calabar River, in the Niger delta—a native river—war having broken out, our Consul, who is a smart, clever man, intervened at once, and as one side declined to cease fighting, he ordered a gunboat to the place to protect the trade. But in this, a British river, our property may be looted or burnt, our servants, so long as they were not born in a British settlement, may be slaughtered, while aid or protection we have none. Perhaps, on the principle of killing a director on an English railway, if the Marabouts of Badibboo were to beat or shoot our Administrator, the Government would wake up, and show some of their boasted "spirited foreign policy."—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1879-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.601, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—In your March number you inserted an article, "A Ga Sabbato School" in our town, founded by some young gentlemen. It was a characteristic of our town that scarcely anybody knew about it, till the notice of it was read in your valuable paper. We found it just as was stated, and feel ourselves most thankful to these our fellow citizens who have taken this task upon their shoulders; and it is the more to be acknowledged, as these young gentlemen are clerks, having work to do through the whole week, and therefore desire a Sunday afternoon recreation. May their work prosper!

But it was not commendable to see how other people tried to make use of this work. Scarcely did the Rev. Shamfelt read that article than he came to seek the school. Luckily none of the ten or twelve persons whom he asked could give any information about it, and he was thus obliged to go back without having effected his object. And that was well. Our reverend seemed to have a great desire to mix himself up with that undertaking, and it would not have been long before we should have seen a long report of his zealous love to Africa, and the real undertakers...

would be thus forgotten. Indeed, we have enough of such reports of dubious credibility, only to do homage to self-love, and are therefore glad to be spared now and then therewith.

But if our missionaries really want to do something for the country, we should think there are opportunities enough. On our small Gold Coast, with about 200,000 inhabitants, are two missions, the Wesleyan Mission and the Basil Mission; we may say three, as there is also the Bremen Mission, occupying a bordering line on the Slave Coast. We are told that it is now more than fifty years since the missionaries have been on this coast, and that the missionaries are greatly complaining of seeing no success in their work. But we found it otherwise. There is very much done in these fifty years, especially in the second to the fourth decenary. The missionaries know themselves how many congregations they have, and how many members of whom they cannot say that all are chaff. Besides there are lots of healthy houses built, the whole Bible, and other useful books are translated into these languages, so that our present missionaries need no more "to pick up the languages word by word from the thick lips of the negro with great difficulty!" A whole staff of native assistants is formed, whose help our missionaries should better acknowledge. We are sure there would be more success if they continue their works in the same manner, instead of sitting and lamenting the incorrigibleness of the negroes, and criticising the works of the zealous predecessors of theirs in a most invidious way.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-04-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.604, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. The interior is in a constant state of siege, and legitimate trade is stagnated. hh: The promotion of education by African leaders and colonial powers in the late 19th century aimed to foster intellectual development and stability in African societies, as seen in the efforts to educate the sons of chiefs in regions like Yoruba and Liberia.
result: The promotion of education by African leaders and colonial powers in the late 19th century, as observed in both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles, aimed to foster intellectual development and stability in African societies, particularly through efforts to educate the sons of chiefs in regions like Yoruba and Liberia. The General History of Africa highlights the role of Christian missions, colonial governments, and local African initiatives in spreading education, with colonial powers like France and Britain establishing special schools for the traditional elite. This aligns with the claim, though the textbook also notes the emergence of an educated elite from various social strata, not just the sons of chiefs, adding nuance to the claim. In Liberia, the gradual expansion of schools and the assimilation of indigenous Liberians into Americo-Liberian culture further supports the idea of fostering stability through education. The African Times articles corroborate these efforts, citing initiatives like Mr. Edward S. Morris's college in Liberia for educating the sons of native kings and chiefs, and the Church Missionary Society's work in West Africa, including Fourah Bay College in Sierra Leone. However, the articles also highlight challenges, such as limited colonial government involvement and reliance on missionary societies, suggesting a more complex picture. They emphasize the need for technical and practical education to equip Africans with economic skills, complementing the intellectual aims. Together, these sources provide a nuanced view that both supports and complicates the claim about educational promotion in the late 19th century.

[{'id': 113, 'article_title': 'ABEOKUTA', 'full_section_title': 'ABEOKUTA', 'last_edit_date': '01-06-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': 'The Harmattan wind has been blowing here for the last month. The thermometer has fallen greatly under this chilling dry wind. We are informed that at Ibadan it has fallen to 64, here it has been at 63, and at Lagos 62. This wind will be very favourable for the picking of cotton, which is now beginning to come in in small quantities.

The Rev. Messrs. Lamb and Buhler, with Mr. Davis (of Lagos) and Mr. Wilhelm, have returned here. They were pretty well received, but we fear that not much has been accomplished as regards any prospect of termination of the war with Ibadan. They left Abeokuta on December 11. The following is the account given by the _Iwe Irohin_:—

"The party altogether was upwards of thirty in number. They went with the consent of the chiefs, and were accompanied by a man with a staff from the Bashorun, but they were requested by the chief to start before the people were astir in the morning, and to take a very circuitous route, consequently they left at four o'clock in the morning for Berekodo. The road has been so long unused that in some parts it has quite disappeared, in others it was very disagreeable from the tall grass overhanging the path. After some little explanation they were well received, the object of their journey was much approved, a lodging was assigned them, and the Ibadan Consul of the town sent them a present of agidi and palaver-sauce. The next day they reached Bioku, where the chief was also very favourable. At Oyo, where the King of Yoruba resides, there was a good deal of delay and formality. The Yorubas refused to let Mr. Buhler go in to the King's presence with spectacles on, accordingly he stayed outside and preached to the people. After the interview, re-

King sent them a bag of cowries and two sheep. He has been very kind to the native agents during the war, and promised that when the war was over each of the chiefs would send a son to be taught. In the afternoon Mr. Buhler baptized six persons, these were the first adult baptisms in the place. They stayed at Oyo three days. On passing through the town of Ijaye, which was destroyed nine months before, papaw trees with ripe fruit were to be seen inside many of the houses.'}, {'id': 3795, 'article_title': 'CHRISTIAN EDUCATION FOR AND IN AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'CHRISTIAN EDUCATION FOR AND IN AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '04-21-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1879#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_05_1879', 'content': 'In answer to an invitation from Samuel Gurney, Esq., to meet Mr. Edward S. Morris, of Philadelphia and Liberia, a meeting was held at Devonshire House, London, April 21st, 1879, when the following resolution was unanimously passed: "That the thanks of this meeting be given to Mr. Morris, for his interesting and encouraging statement on the condition and prospects of Liberia; that we fully agree with him as to the crying necessity for Christian schools in Africa, and earnestly desire that every necessary means may be given him to make his estate (800 acres) in Liberia a nursery of education, industrial as well as literary—especially for the sons of native chiefs, and the future kings of Africa." Mr. Morris was recommended to Samuel Gurney, Esq. by Mr. Welsh, the United States Minister in London, in terms which we feel compelled to quote: "Mr. Morris has thrown an enthusiastic energy into the work he has entered upon, which gives the strongest promise of success. His earnest desire is for the Christian education of the sons of the savage chiefs who border on Liberia. They are to be the future rulers of Africa. This is to be his life-work; and his instruments will be schools for the purpose established in Liberia. In such a cause he cannot fail to have the support of many good people." Mr. Morris has secured an estate of 800 acres in Liberia, where he is about to erect his college, in which he proposes to educate the sons of native kings and chiefs. His admirable plan is to make them at the same time educated men, Christians, and practical coffee planters and general agriculturists. This is surely a work fraught with well-grounded hopes of at present incalculable good to Africa; and as such, Mr. Morris, who seems to us to be peculiarly fitted for it, has our warmest desires and earnest prayers for a full measure of success. Mr. T. A. Denny, of London, has promised 100l. of the 1,000l. required by Mr. Morris, who, in his letter to Joseph Gurney Barclay, Esq., and George Williams, Esq.,—well-known in London business circles—who have accepted the office of Treasurers for the funds which Mr. Morris hopes to collect while in England, says: "When the school-house shall have been built, the teacher engaged and at his post of duty, and the boys in their seats, THEN will I commence to draw on the funds deposited, and placed in your hands as Treasurers."'}, {'id': 3948, 'article_title': 'EDUCATION ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'EDUCATION ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '01-20-1880', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1880#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_03_1880', 'content': 'Lagos, January 20, 1880.

Sir,—On Wednesday last, the 14th inst., there was an educational meeting held at the C.M.S. Infant School-room, Faji, when friends of education, and others, attended by invitation and public notice.

Owing to the absence of his Excellency Lieutenant-Governor Griffiths, C.M.G., in the Eastern districts, the Right Rev. Bishop Crowther, D.D., took the chair.

After prayer, Bishop Crowther's able and effective speech, in which the venerable prelate spoke of his early days and education, especially his anxiety and yearning to learn the Greek language at Fomah Bay College, when first opened in 1827, he being the first pupil, called forth loud applause from the meeting. He proved that the African only requires some one to show and teach him, and he will soon prove his ability; that he is capable of gaining distinction in learning. The Bishop then introduced Mr. Nathaniel S. Davies, B.A., Senior Tutor of the Fomah Bay College (Dunelm), Sierra Leone.

On his appearing in his college dress, Mr. Davies was received with much cheering, and then this native gentleman went on to explain the new system on which that College, now opened for general education, is worked. The delivery of his speech was such that he was greatly admired and cheered. He created a lively interest for general education, which is now understood. Some questions were put to and answered by Mr. Davies.

Bishop Crowther then commended the explanation of Mr. Davies to all friends of education in Lagos.

Mr. Registrar Payne then proposed a vote of thanks to the Right Rev. Bishop Crowther, to the Rev. Mr. Maser (for the arrangements made in the School-room), and especially to Mr. Davies, for his explanation, which, he had no doubt, had made a deep impression on the audience.

Mr. Payne was loudly cheered by the meeting, when he said: Well, Mr. Davies, on behalf of our people and myself, we thank the College authorities for sending you to explain the new system to us; but I must not conceal the fact from you that we all envy and feel jealous of you to-night, and would all like to be "Bachelors of Arts," but as the elder ones, who are in business or in responsible positions, cannot leave their calling to go and get the B.A., we trust the young folks of Lagos will go to the College and get it.

The votes of thanks were carried unanimously.

Mr. Davies returned thanks on behalf of the College authorities for the kind reception given to him.

The Bishop returned thanks, and pronounced the Benediction, and the meeting dispersed.'}]
