Morris—whose efforts some eighteen months ago in London to raise a fund for male and female education of sons and daughters belonging to the native chiefs of the interior of Liberia, had the warm sympathy and support of Mr. Samuel Gurney and other long-tried friends of Africa—has sent us some printed papers from the United States, where he is endeavouring to complete the fund. Mr. Morris writes to us: "You will be pleased to learn that my lady teacher (white) and her son (nineteen years old, and born at Corisco) will sail for Liberia in October next, to inaugurate my Industrial and Literary School. She is the widow of a devoted missionary of the Presbyterian Church of U.S. Corisco holds his precious dust." As Mr. Morris seems to require only an additional 500l. to inaugurate his school-house in Liberia, and as his appeal for this is endorsed by well-known friends of the Africans in the United States, we hope he will soon obtain it. Bishop Stevens (Pennsylvania) writes: "I have great confidence in Mr. Morris's scheme for the education of the sons of native chiefs in Africa. Mr. Morris has devoted his life to the service of God in Africa, and, by God's help, will succeed." Our heart is with him in his great and good work.—**ED. A.T.**', 'last_edit_date': '1880-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1880#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.696, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sir Alfred Moloney on West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "This Society aims, I take it, and so rightly, at maintaining all original rights, and at giving every support, in an educational sense, to the interests of the natives, so that they may take more and more active part in their own affairs, and may go on occupying more prominent places in our possessions in Western Africa. Such is, I may say, the policy of our various Governments there. Great advance has been of late years made in this direction, for which the Colonies are much indebted to the generous and far-seeing policy of Lord Knutsford, who has seen fit to add several important selections from the qualified native gentlemen for professional, lucrative and honourable posts, and they have done credit to his choice. His lordship has, I may venture to say, approved of a system of scholarships and apprenticeships in many branches of the Government of the colony of Lagos, so as to help to educate their youth up to a standard sufficient to enable some to come later to the front. He has also allowed some to be sent to the Botanic Department of Jamaica, to be trained up so as afterwards to take charge of a similar institution in Lagos; and further, a promising young Lagosian is being educated, also at the expense of the colony, in England, so as to qualify as a surveyor or civil engineer. Of these few instances the Aborigines' Protection Society will, I am sure, be glad to learn, and in connexion with them I must repeat that West Africa may thank the present Secretary of State for the Colonies.", 'last_edit_date': '1891-05-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LIBERIA COLLEGE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are glad to see that higher education is making progress in Liberia. The following from the *Observer*, extracted from a "Circular," is of interest, and appeals strongly to the friends of Africa:—

"It is now proposed to take a new departure. It is expected that students will avail themselves of the advantages of the college not only from all parts of the Republic, but from other settlements along the coast, and from the tribes in the interior. In respect to funds, the trustees feel that in view of the increased work which lies before them, they will urgently need far larger pecuniary assistance than the institution has yet had. Increased endowments are necessary to enable the institution to hold its position and fulfil its functions as a college. It is the object of the trustees to encourage and assist needy boys, who give promise of usefulness, especially from among the aborigines, to obtain a liberal education. To this end they earnestly solicit the establishment of permanent scholarships. Professorships of Ancient Languages and Mathematics are provided for. There is urgent need now for endowments of Professorships in the departments of the Moral and Physical Sciences, of Jurisprudence, and of Arabic and the Native vernaculars. . . . No provision is at present made for boarding the students in the college building; but board may be had in respectable families in the neighbourhood of the College, at prices varying from ten to twelve dollars, or from 2l. to 2l. 10s. per month. The charges for one year, for students from abroad, including all expenses, will vary from 150 to 200 dols., or from 30l. to 40l. sterling, according to the disposition of the students."', 'last_edit_date': '1881-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1881#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—I thank you much for your able and well-timed article in your issue of August last on the subject of the Education of the Gold Coast Protectorate, and the responsibility of the British Government in connection with it. Short of Christianity, no subject is more intimately connected with the welfare of a subject or a protected people than that of their education, and yet there is not one that the Government has so much neglected in its West African settlements. The work of educating the people has been relegated entirely to Christian Missionary Societies. It cannot be that the Government is of opinion that African races are not capable of mental improvement and development, or that they do not need it, and that its government over those entrusted to it should simply be that of a police force for the preservation of order. If this is not its opinion, it is difficult to understand its policy. Whatever may be the ultimate intention for which it holds its settlements on the Coast—whether it be to make them eventually independent and self-governing, or to make them always appendages to the British territory—there is an obligation on its part to furnish them with the means of a liberal education, especially when they are not themselves in a position so to do, so that they may properly discharge their own obligations and answer the end of their existence. They have responsibilities which they cannot discharge without education. These settlements were acquired, and the position held by the Government secured, with the constantly avowed object of thereby aiding to suppress the slave-trade and correct the many untold evils it has inflicted upon Africa, and of making them renovating centres for Western Africa. The object is noble and laudable; but, I ask, what has the Government done to compass this end? What amount of education has it given to the people? For ignorance is as much a hindrance and weakens as education of the right sort is power, and progress. The development of the capabilities of the mind is a power of no little magnitude for developing the resources of a country that is poor and low in the midst of an abundance of the elements of wealth and greatness. The people should be educated to a strong sense of their privileges, duties, and responsibilities. Why is it, then, that the Government has all along neglected this duty, when it stands in loco parenta to these settlements? or has it no faith in the power of education? But for the Missionary Societies, and particularly the Church Missionary Society, which have established themselves in them, these settlements would not have been worth their present value. The efforts made by Government to educate have been very feeble; it has not convinced the people of its earnestness on the subject. I am one of those who think that the funds of Missionary Societies are sacred, and should be employed solely for the work of preaching the Gospel to the heathen. It is for this object they appeal to their friends for support constantly; it is not theirs to establish abroad schools of learning. If educational work is done by them, it should not generally exceed the barely elementary one which would enable converts to read the Scriptures for themselves, and that of raising up native missionaries and pastors to enforce on the people the truths they read. It is all the more necessary that this should be the case, because the area of ground to be covered in heathendom is large, and the funds of great missionary societies have not for many years now shown a large and steady increase. The claims upon them are many and urgent, and in some places there are doors of usefulness open to them already which they are urgently invited to occupy. It has now been sufficiently established that the Africans are receptive, that they are easily taught not only the rudiments of education, but when good masters are found for them, and they are placed under a good system, the higher branches also. We are not, therefore, asking the British Government to take a leap in the dark—to organize educational institutions without absolute knowledge as to whether the people are capable of receiving education. We could point to members of that once despised African race who occupy really an eminent position in law and medicine; and if we have not yet skilled engineers among them, it is only because there have not yet been inducements among them to the cultivation of those sciences whose mighty power is at this time revolutionizing the world. There is every possible encouragement, therefore, to the British Government in entering upon the noble work which we maintain that it is now their duty to undertake and set about in right good earnest. We would have two superior institutions established, one at Lagos and the other at Accra. These settlements and seats of Government are at so little distance from each other, and the facilities for passing from the one to the other are so frequent and so good, that one supreme organizing and superintending educational head would suffice for both. It is not a little feeble, glimmering light that we thirst to see introduced at those important points of West Africa, but one in educational power that shall resemble the electric among illuminating flames. Great Britain will thus, indeed, justify her presence and extend her beneficent influence on the West Coast of Africa. The work of African civilization is an immense work; the means employed, to be worth anything, must be commensurate with the end to be obtained. We need for those West African countries a host of African evangelists and apostles of civilization; we ask that ignorance shall be beaten down by an array of educational power capable of overcoming its inertia, conquering its will, and subduing to itself its sympathies and its love. Oh, 'tis a glorious work to be undertaken, a glorious aim to be accomplished—a work and an aim worthy of a Government that has taken seriously in hand the deliverance of South-eastern Europe from the paralyzing influences of a rule under which every noble aspiration has been strangled, and the commonest principles of humanity have been outraged and trampled under foot. And we cannot conceive on what ground such a work can be any longer neglected and delayed. That the whole civilized world, and more especially Great Britain and the other European countries, have the deepest possible interest in the civilization of Africa, and that development of her wondrous resources which can only take place through the diffusion of civilization, is beyond all doubt; and since West Africa herself, under the organizing and administrative help of Great Britain, can be made to furnish the means, we earnestly exhort the Secretary of State for the Colonies to plant there without delay that tree of knowledge which alone can effect it. It is only thus that the prophecies of a Buxton and a Palmerston can be fulfilled; and Africa become the glory, instead of the reproach and disgrace, of the Christian civilized world.", 'last_edit_date': '1880-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1880#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I consider that, as far as may be expected of Missionary Societies, they have been liberal in their efforts to educate the people in some parts of the Coast, and particularly in Sierra Leone, where, besides the Missionary Colleges of the Church Missionary Society and the Wesleyan Missionary Society, the former has had a public Grammar School since 1845, and a Female Institution which is nearly as old, if not older, and training masters from England. The Government is indebted to them for the measure of educated native intelligence which it brings into requisition in its service. These Societies have shown that Africans are capable of any degree of improvement, and created a thirst for learning which the people are now anxious to have satisfied.

I am not aware that their general educational work was subsidized by Government all the while they were at it; and it was hardly to be expected that the people themselves, mostly poor liberated slaves, could have contributed much for its support. The Government holds a position on the Gold Coast; this position is enhanced, and its responsibility increased, by the Act which has recently liberated hundreds of thousands of slaves from bondage, or at least placed them on the way to claim their freedom. Untold blessings to the Coast and the interior of Africa will, I expect, result from it if the efforts to discharge duties and responsibilities are of the right kind, and are properly directed. It is the duty, and will be to the honour of the Government to seek to liberate from slavery the minds of those whose bodies only have been made free. They are yet the slaves of ignorance, superstition, and folly, and can and will do no credit either to themselves or to the Power that has given them the status of freed men if they are left to continue uneducated; nor will they be ever qualified for a proper and wholesome use of the position they enjoy, and the power placed in their hands; and by how much the mind is superior to the body, by so much is the slavery of the mind worse than that of the body. Besides these freed slaves, there is a very large originally free but poor population, who cannot provide schools for their children. The establishment of elementary schools over the whole Protectorate, and the power to read and write in their own language and in others acquired by the people, would be the beginning of their greatness.', 'last_edit_date': '1875-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.721, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When writing last month on the all-important subject of the future spread of Christian civilization in West Africa, we pointed out that educated natives, more or less under the influence of Christian faith, more or less imbued with Christian principles, more or less governed by Christian precepts, are and will be indispensable as a vanguard of the great army of civilization that must be projected upon the ignorant barbarism of heathen Africa whenever the means for such projection shall be arranged. We go further than this, and equally maintain that not only the vanguard of the army of civilization must necessarily consist of educated Africans, but that the army itself must be chiefly composed of them. With this conviction rooted in our mind, the question of education in West Africa has for many years past greatly occupied our attention. The end in view being so great, and of so vast importance primarily to Africa, and secondarily to the whole civilized world, it is natural we should have asked ourself whether the means of education at present employed are adequate for the purpose; and if not, how and by whom those means are to be made so. We have already adverted to the unselfish efforts of the religious societies of Great Britain (and in the case of Liberia, of those of the United States of America) in diffusing among the natives the great blessing of education. The efforts of the Missionary Societies, and more especially of the Church Missionary Society, have been unremitting and gradually increasing in scope and efficiency, until they would seem at last to have culminated in the affiliation of their Fomah Bay College at Sierra Leone to the University of Durham, whereby degrees may be obtained by Africans who have never left their native land. By these efforts of Missionary Societies, the Church of England and the Wesleyan Methodist, all who can boast of any degree of education in West Africa have been rescued from heathen ignorance, and prepared more or less, for civilized usefulness. It was, perhaps, well and unavoidable, though we are far from saying or thinking that it was so, that so all-important a work, if Africa is ever to be rescued from heathen degradation, should have been hitherto left in the hands of the Missionary Societies. But that it ought any longer to be so left, we most emphatically deny. Under those noble efforts of the Missionary Societies, combined with constantly increasing facilities for commerce which steam navigation has supplied, the condition of the British settlements has undergone so great a change, that a continued dependence on missionary effort for the education of the people will, if persisted in, be a gross injustice and disgrace on the part of the British Government. This is so patent that we feel convinced it is only necessary the subject should be urged upon their attention to induce such action on their part as shall wipe away the reproach that now justly attaches to them, and relieve the Missionary Societies from a charge to which their funds, so urgently required for the propagation of Christian truth in other localities in the great heathen world, ought not to be any longer subject. Education ought to be now organized and diffused in and from the British settlements by and at the charge of the local revenues. The inadequacy of means, which as regards the Gold Coast, for instance, might have been pleaded some ten or twelve years ago, when the public revenue there did not exceed annually the sum of seven or eight thousand pounds, can no longer be urged now that the revenue has attained the comparatively magnificent amount of one hundred thousand pounds a year. A similar comparative increase has been experienced at Lagos; and if the revenues of Sierra Leone and the Gambia have not advanced in the same ratio, they are still sufficient, if properly administered, to meet the great and urgent want of public education, under the organization and auspices of the State. A State education is what we now claim for West Africa, and in especial for the Gold Coast and Lagos. A systematic and adequate commencement of it ought not to be any longer delayed. A Liberal Government in Great Britain cannot surely any longer deny to the people of West Africa that of which they have been such earnest promoters, both individually and collectively, at home. It can scarcely be necessary to remind the Earl of Kimberley that, as Crown Colonies, those settlements are altogether dependent upon an initiative from Downing-street; that themselves, the people, even if they felt the need, can do nothing; that the expenditure of the public revenue is entirely at the command of the Secretary of State for the Colonies; and that it now rests with him either to aid in or retard the Christian civilization of West Africa, which cannot progress without a more general diffusion of education than can or ought to be expected from the Missionary Societies of Great Britain. While, however, we are prepared to maintain that it is now the duty of Government to undertake the work of the education of the people, both elementary and higher, in all the West African settlements, we shall confine ourselves more especially at this time to the claims and needs of the Gold Coast and Lagos. The influence that may be diffused from these British settlements in the great work of the civilization of Africa would be immense, and justly entitles them to our especial consideration as regards public education in West Africa. It is from Lagos that the work of civilization must proceed to the moral conquest of the whole of those extensive territories that are bounded by the River Niger, and of that blood-stained kingdom of Dahomey, whose sanguinary customs continue, though of late but little spoken of, to outrage humanity, and exhibit the worst features of ignorant heathen barbarism. In considering the question of State education in Lagos, it is incumbent on the British Government to take into consideration that the public revenue of that portion of the Gold Coast Colony is derived entirely from traffic in the produce of those interior countries; that the spread of civilization increases production; and that therefore, while on the one hand it is imperatively their duty, it is not less their interest, as rulers of this Crown settlement, to devote a portion of that revenue to constitute Lagos a focus of light from Britain, to be diffused throughout the Egba and Yoruba countries, and the territories of their unquiet neighbour, Dahomey. The presence of Great Britain on the coasts of these countries of West Africa, after her own renunciation and denunciation of the infamous and horrible foreign slave-trade, was justified by her presence there being absolutely necessary for securing the final annihilation of that traffic, and remedying in some degree, by the security she gave and the repression she exercised, the fearful results that had been produced there by it, and the outrages on humanity perpetrated at the behests of sanguinary superstitions, which had been made through successive ages its active agents and accomplices. Under her ægis a new condition of things has gradually arisen; and although—such is the tenacity of evil—her presence could not even yet be dispensed with as regards the repression of slave-trading propensities, this repression ought now to be regarded as a secondary, and the spread of civilization the primary, justification of her continued rule. Those who have known this journal during the past twenty years cannot need to be reminded that we have ever laid it down as an axiom that a basis of British power on the Coast is indispensable to the success of missionary enterprise and the progress of civilization in Africa. The natives have become so debased by superstition during ages upon ages of heathen darkness, that they are incapable of believing in anything that does not come to them accompanied by evidences of power. They have such evidence at Lagos; they have it within the mainland territories of the Gold Coast Colony. That evidence will suffice to insure the gradual acceptance of civilization when once the interior populations, as well as those in the Coast towns,', 'last_edit_date': '1880-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1880#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.739, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Too much praise cannot be given you for your unwearied and long-continued efforts on behalf of poor Africa and her unfortunate sons. The lively interest and heartfelt sympathy you have always manifested in the work of Africa's regeneration and advancement seems ever to be increasing with the onward march of time, and it is to be hoped that such zealous and benevolent efforts will be crowned with abundant success.

Your remarks on the subject of Education in your last two issues, and the convincing arguments you advanced to recommend the subject to the notice of the "higher powers," have been read by not a few here with feelings of deep gratitude and satisfaction. It is greatly to be hoped that such an earnest appeal will not be suffered to pass by unheard. It is gratifying to state that the Accra Church of England High-class School has been fairly established and set in proper working order, and since its establishment the number of its pupils has been steadily on the increase. If, as stated in my previous correspondence, such a school as the High-class School be amply and efficiently supported, it will prove a great boon to the place. That the educational work that is thus being inaugurated here needs such support as you have pleaded for will be evident from the fact that it has not been undertaken by the Church Missionary Society, as your remarks would seem to indicate, but by the sole efforts of some of the native residents of this place, who, sensible of the great educational wants of the community, have requested the Bishop of Sierra Leone to aid them in the establishment here of the Church of England with a properly-organized school; and the kind-hearted prelate, ever ready to lend a helping hand to every very good work, promised to aid their efforts in the undertaking. From this it will be seen that such needful help as you have advocated is a *sine qua non* in the proper development of education in this place; and should it be afforded, an efficient staff of competent teachers will be secured, and high-class schools, grammar schools, collegiate schools, and other seminaries of learning will be established along this Coast, which will undoubtedly be productive of unspeakable benefit to the country at large. This, Mr. Editor, in my humble opinion, will be the only panacea for the effectual eradication of the moral, social, and intellectual evil under which "the land is groaning."

The hope of this country's elevation seems to me to be in the rising and future generations, in the proper development of their intellectual faculties, and the instilment into their minds of the "sweets" of education. Without this, there will be but small encouragement to hope for the fulfilment of the oft-repeated prophecy of "Africa shall rise."', 'last_edit_date': '1880-11-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.732, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': '"Technical Education" in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is customary to speak of "the march of civilisation." As regards West Africa the phrase has a significance altogether too slow. Even "leaps and bounds" does not adequately represent the rate of progress, which can only be measured by the pace of the steam engine. That too, will presently be distanced by the onward move of events which has already brought West Africa to the threshold of such an advanced outpost of civilisation as technical education. This is a sign of progress the more remarkable when it is remembered that at a not very remote period the principal instruments of civilisation in Africa were reputed to be rum and gunpowder. But the schoolmaster, chiefly through the medium of the missionary societies, has long been abroad in Africa. Light on the subject is derived from The Lagos Weekly Record, which recently, in commenting on the possibilities of the Yoruba country, as indicated in the Governor's report, remarked that "The time was at hand when the civilised Natives, now appearing to flourish in the settlement, will demand outlets for their energies, and new sources of livelihood; when in order to succeed, or even to live, they will be obliged to join the great army of aboriginal producers, or ally themselves to the foreign consumers, or be crushed between the two."

The necessities thus summarised are recognised both by the Government and by the missionary societies, and the former is devising the establishment of an institution for training youths in various handicrafts. At present, it is stated, the whole of the coast is dependent for mechanics upon the protégés of the Basel Mission and repatriates from the Brazils. The extension of the work of technical education is encouraged by the success that has attended the efforts of the Basel missionaries, thanks to whom "the Gold Coast is now the principal source whence good coopers, carpenters, blacksmiths, and wheelwrights can be obtained, and the skilled mechanics of Accra are in great demand all over the West Coast from Sierra Leone to the Congo." The fact that there is scope in the Colony, as well as at other points along the West Coast, for almost any number of skilled mechanics, certainly favours the enterprise now under the consideration of the Government, and this scope for technical skill cannot fail to be greatly broadened as the interior is increasingly opened up. The practical steps which are being taken in the direction of equipping African youths in the most modern of civilised fashions for the struggle for existence on their own soil may be briefly summed up. The Bishop of Sierra Leone, assisted by Canon Taylor Smith, will, during their present visit to England, make an effort to raise £2,000 for the erection at Freetown of a technical school for the education of young Africans: whilst Captain Denton, during his residence in England on leave, will give attention to the details of the proposed Government scheme.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1894#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Superior General Education at Sierra Leone by the Church Missionary Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—At last there will be a college for general education in Western Africa, under the auspices of the invaluable Church Missionary Society. A Mr. Alcock has been sent out as principal of Fourah Bay College, to open it not only for students of divinity preparing for holy orders, but for students to receive a general education.

Mr. Alcock, so far as I could observe, is truly a good man, a graduate of Trinity College, Dublin, and does not entertain a prejudice to colour. How these good qualities of his will withstand the heat of the climate, and the biased statements of the ill-disposed, the future will tell.

It is now time for the local government to take the initiative, and establish Regius professors. It is high time to abolish that system of school-boy's teaching, and let a professor be appointed to one or two subjects, and let him give by lectures the results of extensive readings and researches. The subject will be better mastered by the teachers themselves, and the students will reap largely the benefit. Lectures should be given in theory and practice of education, classics, mathematics, natural philosophy, mensuration, and bookkeeping; English language and literature, French, German, Hebrew, history in general, natural history, geology, mineralogy, physiology, zoology and botany, chemistry, moral and political philosophy, civil and commercial law, drawing and music, besides the various subjects in divinity.

That Fourah Bay College should be opened to all the country, was the general cry for the last fifteen years. Now that it is about to be realized, I hope it will be well supported by the well to do in the colony. It is further of the very highest importance that a medical school should be attached to this college, for not until such a school is established will the Africans be able to oppose with energy and force the wild doctrines of modern anthropologists.—I am, Sir, yours, &c.,", 'last_edit_date': '1866-11-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_12_1866#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'But besides the establishment of elementary schools, it is desirable for the Government to aid in the establishment of superior colleges for young men and young women in its most advanced West African settlement, Sierra Leone. There is a demand for this; and since the Government has rendered very little help to educational work, it is right for us to expect that it would take up such a work earnestly. The people unaided are unable to provide themselves with such establishments. The practice has been adopted of sending young men and young women to England for education, but it is a very expensive one and is attended with a great risk, and comparatively very few persons can use it. The success that has attended it is one of a doubtful character. Some have returned home with enfeebled constitutions. English teachers have not generally been able to imbue the minds of their African scholars with patriotism, and a sense of their obligations and responsibility to their country. There has been too much of being wrapt up in self. Expensiveness and the fear of their succumbing to the effects of a foreign and trying climate have often necessitated a short stay, and placed them at a disadvantage. Colleges such as I have spoken of will be a boon to the whole Coast, and be hailed with gladness; and if, after successful residence in them, visits are made to England for a finishing, much good will, I think, be done thereby.

In this matter, as in that of elementary schools for the Gold Coast, the Government will find it most helpful to ask the aid and co-operation of the Church Missionary Society, that has already a very good foundation to work upon. I would not ask that any burden be laid upon British taxpayers; local funds should be economized for this work, and a combination of local Government efforts would remove much of the pecuniary difficulty that may be raised in the matter of superior colleges.—I am, dear Sir, yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1875-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.71, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bishop of Sierra Leone on the Education of the West African', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In his book, "Sierra Leone after a Hundred Years" (Seeley & Co.), Bishop Ingham, in reviewing the work which has been accomplished in and around Sierra Leone, observes:—

"It is impossible not to regret that the Church Missionary Society were unable to develop in the schools of the Colony some accurate knowledge of manual trades. The results in aptitude for interior missionary work, in energy, perseverance, and common sense, would have been enormous. ... The other plan (abstract teaching, divorced from material business) has been abundantly tried, and what is the result? Not only does the constant hammering at the brain, of which this raw (negro) youth must now become a victim, produce an unbalanced development, but the precocious memory that will characterise him is a deceptive gauge of progress made, and, like much precociousness elsewhere, the results are disappointing in after life. For this reason, a successfully-passed examination on paper is not the test in Africa that it is in England. ... Can we be surprised that the very last thing he (the negro young man) thinks of is the development of his country or making his father's village better than he found it—and thus his want of accuracy, want of perseverance and skill, and all that goes to make a man master of any situation, remain uncorrected, and put him altogether out of the running. We are convinced that there is a more excellent way, and we regret it has not more generally approved itself to those who have done such good work in other respects in this part of Africa. Other bodies, and notably the Roman Catholics, seem to be far ahead of us in this respect. How far they fail in developing the minds and consciences of the Africans we will not here discuss; but their systems of technical training are thoroughly worthy of imitation."

The Bishop goes on to explain that the work that has been accomplished is by no means to be deprecated—indeed, it is

difficult to imagine how low Sierra Leone must have fallen, mentally and morally, were it not for the mission work carried on in face of such grave difficulties, and upon a soil necessarily so unpromising, since the first occupation of the Colony 107 years ago. But he goes on to illustrate from the physical condition of Sierra Leone; from the manners, customs, and ideas of the Negroes, both lay and clerical; from the suspicion with which the independent States surrounding the Colony regard the morals of its population, the difficulties which face one with such heavy responsibilities as are his.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1894#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRIBES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At a meeting of the Royal Colonial Institute, held lately in the Grosvenor Gallery Library, New Bond-street, a paper was read by Mr. William Greswell, M.A., on "The Education of the South African Tribes." The lecturer said: The future of South Africa was much bound up with this question of administration, and especially the educational part of it. A proper education meant an assimilation of the coloured man to the ideal of the white man, with regard to habits of mind and of thought. The question of education was visibly affected by political disturbances. With regard to the general question, which was viewed in many different ways by white people both in the colony and at home, he said the great desideratum of the hour in South Africa was to raise the discussion of important matters beyond the atmosphere of party. Nothing had so much injured the native as the custom of using him for the purpose of a party cry. Premising that he should confine himself principally to the state of affairs in the Cape Colony, the Lecturer said he should show that there had existed and did still exist in that colony a State scheme for the instruction of the natives in nearly everything they might require to know, whether it was to shoe a horse, make a wheel, or learn Greek. As he had himself endeavoured to instruct the Caffre in the Greek declensions, in his capacity as Government Lecturer in the colony, he might say that the loftiness and catholicity of the scheme had come home to him. Remarking upon the difficulties in the way of applying such a scheme in a sparsely-peopled savage country like South Africa, he said the number of white colonists at the Cape was about equal to the population of Leeds, and these had to legislate for the reclamation of more than a million blacks, who were scattered over an immense tract. Other difficulties lay in the unequal social developments among the black people, in the bi-lingual character of the white population, and in the want of unanimity on the part of the white colonists as to the proper lines upon which native education ought to go. To bring under one system of State education men of different religious views, hard though it might be, was an easy task for the political legislator compared with that encountered in an attempt to group under one plan men so intellectually and, if he might use the term, spiritually distinct as the European and the African aboriginal races. The difference between the races was, practically speaking, one absolutely of kind, not of degree. Undeterred by difficulties, legislators at the Cape had boldly grappled with the question, and they had established a complete educational ladder, with the kraal schools at the bottom and the university at the top. After going with some detail into the working of the scheme in that colony, and suggesting some possible improvements in the system, he remarked that though philanthropy in theory, in practice it was unphilosophic. A cardinal fact was ignored—the generic difference between the European and the Caffre. The principle of heredity was ignored. He was inclined to believe that the Caffre would be influenced by a simple and rather an autocratic system. Advocating a certain measure of compulsion in order to make the Caffre industrious, and to compel him to be taught, he said the educationist should walk hand in hand with the white magistrate and the missionary; these three classes of men really replace the autocracy of the chiefs. He thought that if the philanthropist could be persuaded to believe that all men were not equal, and if the Boer could be persuaded to believe that they might be equal in course of time—in fact, that there was a germ which might be worked upon in the native, there would be some chance of an agreement. If both philanthropist and Boer should take the scientific view that the Caffre was really nothing more than he was by descent, a savage pure and simple, but that he had in him the makings of a good citizen, there would be considerably less friction in South Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1884#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.712, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "MRS. MOSELEY'S CAPE COAST FEMALE SCHOOL", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On the subject of education in Africa, Major J. T. Brownall, late of the Gold Coast Artillery, writes as follows:—

"I have been a resident on the West Coast of Africa for ten years and upwards, and in my public military capacity have travelled over the whole of the Protectorate; hence I am enabled to speak from observation and experience of the character, manners, and customs of the inhabitants of that benighted and neglected country.

"It is lamentable to find that the efforts that have been made during the last thirty or forty years to civilise and bring to the knowledge of Christ these much-neglected people have not produced equal results with those made among other nations in a similar position.

"To me the cause is obvious. It is not, as some have stated (unjustly and unkindly), the want of intellect or the repugnance evinced by the natives to receive assistance and information from those who have so long laboured amongst them, but from the deep-rooted superstition which prevails, inherited from their forefathers, which cannot be at once eradicated from their minds.

"The natives generally are particularly intelligent, very grateful, and anxious to gain information, not addicted to the violent passions and cruelties practised by other unchristian nations. Why, then, should not the great cause of Christian civilization progress in West Africa as in other settlements?

"It is, in my opinion, because the female part of the community are kept in such a degraded state. They are uneducated, and looked upon by the other sex as mere slaves, and treated as such. Their lives are devoted to manual labour, and their persons frequently sold or pawned to supply the pecuniary wants of their owners, instead of being respected and looked up to as equals, and helpmates in Christian and domestic happiness. Until the female population is raised to its proper position, Christian civilization can never arrive at that standard which we are all anxious to witness, and which it is our duty, as followers of Christ, to endeavour to reach.

"Mrs. Moseley, the widow of the much-beloved and respected judge who was stationed at Cape Coast, and greatly esteemed and regretted by all, and especially by the native population, has, I am happy to find, come forward and offered her services in establishing an infant female school at Cape Coast.

"With God's assistance, and a person so well qualified as Mrs. Moseley, we may look forward to great results. hh: The integration of Africans into British military structures, as seen in the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles and other local contingents, reflects both the influence of colonial powers on local military practices and the agency of African leaders in participating in and shaping colonial military affairs.
result: The integration of Africans into British military structures, as exemplified by the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles and other local contingents, reflects a complex interplay between colonial influence and African agency. The General History of Africa textbook highlights the utilization of indigenous populations by colonial powers, such as the British and French, primarily for police functions and maintaining control, underscoring the influence of colonial powers on local military practices. However, it also points out the alienation of African soldiers from their societies and their exclusion from command positions, suggesting limited agency in shaping military affairs. This contrasts with the claim's suggestion of African leaders' active participation. The textbook also discusses conscription and forced recruitment, which may not align with the voluntary nature of the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles. In contrast, The African Times articles provide details supporting the claim, highlighting the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles as a unit composed of educated Africans with officers from principal merchants and residents, reflecting both colonial influence and African agency. The articles emphasize the involvement of local chiefs and educated Africans in military and ceremonial events, and the recruitment of African troops for British-led expeditions, such as the Bonny men in the Ashanti War. They also highlight the blending of local customs with colonial practices and the agency of African leaders, like King George Pepple, in negotiating and contributing to military efforts, indicating a degree of autonomy and influence. Together, these sources illustrate both the colonial impact on local military practices and the active role of African leaders, albeit with differing emphases on the extent of African agency.

[{'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': 'Means of control and administration', 'content': 'Whatever the variety of theories and methods of colonial domination suggested and implemented in the period between the two world wars, an emergent pattern of bureaucratic rule is evident. This shift, however, in no way denied the fact that the ultima ratio of colonial authority was displayed by European arms.
As its most ardent advocates were willing to remark, colonial rule was won by the sword and so maintained. Yet because they were frequently made to serve in geographical regions culturally and ethnically unfamiliar to them, African soldiers were thus alienated from their own society and were often received with hostility by the local populations they forcefully encountered. After the overthrow of the colonial rulers, these armies were not disbanded but were taken over by the new independent African rulers and they have turned out to be the most problematic of the products of colonialism since, as W. '$^{6}$ Indeed, as will be seen in the next volume, as a result of their repeated and often unnecessary and unjustifiable interventions in the politics of independent African states, those armies have become the heaviest of the millstones round the necks of African governments and peoples.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.724, 'probability_score': 0.053, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': 'Means of control and administration', 'content': "However, even in the inter-war period, labelled by contemporaries as one of 'colonial peace', military activities still punctuated African affairs in a severe manner. Moreover, in the essential search for allies, Europeans had to use the supply of quality guns to bargain for treaties, concessions, neutrality or active participation in wars against rival African states. It therefore became essential to regulate their Scramble on the basis of international agreements and, in particular, to limit the supply of arms and ammunition. The most intense rivalry was between the British and the French. The British tried to secure their interests by also playing the role of protectors of Portuguese interests. Only the commandant du cercle commands; only he is responsible. When the Spanish governor proclaimed Catholicism as the official religion of Fernando Po in 1858, the position of the Baptists became untenable at Clarence. Accordingly, Alfred Saker built a new settlement at Ambas Bay which he named Victoria, in June 1858. But local opposition to the Baptists continued to be high, especially as many of the Anglo-West Indian settlers at Victoria also traded in competition with the Bimbia population.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Politics and nationalism in West Africa, 1919-35', 'section_title': 'Politics and nationalism in British West Africa > Rural politics or rural mass nationalism in the inter-war period', 'content': 'In the youth movements, NCBWA and trade unions, we have been dealing with nationalism and politics as seen in the urban centres in former British West Africa and led by the educated and professional elite. But as recent research has been revealing - and future research in other countries in West Africa will confirm or reject or modify these conclusions - African nationalist activities were not confined to the urban centres only but were evident in the rural areas; in the various paramountcies, states and com› munities, and here the principal actors were the commoners and farmers, both literate and illiterate on the one hand, and the traditional rulers on the other. The latter were seen at times acting in co-operation with their subjects against the colonial system and at times being attacked by their subjects as agents of the same system. Another aspect of this theme which is still very much in the dark is the linkage there was, if any, between rural and urban politics and how or whether one influenced the other.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'The growth of European interest', 'content': "Because the lands and peoples were so interwoven, developments in one part always had effects and implications in other parts. European abolitionists found, for example, that to stop the slave trade and the wars in the interior, they had to reckon not just with the coastal rulers but also with the different power bases in the interior. Both British and French abolitionist missions from different parts of the Lower Guinea coast commonly had to visit Dahomey kings at Agbome in the first half of the century. To mediate in the Dahomey-Yoruba wars, visits had to be arranged to both Abeokuta and Agbome. Similarly, British peace› makers involved in resolving aspects of nineteenth-century Yoruba warfare had to travel virtually throughout the length and breadth of the culture area.
Unfortunately, the European approach was divisive, tending towards politically structured differentiation. This was already noticeable in the late 1840s and early 1850s. The appointment in 1849 of John Beecroft as British Consul for the Bights of Benin and Bonny (formerly Biafra) signalled the dawn of a new era. British interests came to be specifically protected visà-vis the interest of other European nationals; British interests were also advanced against those of Africans. We have already drawn attention to the penetration of the Benin kingdom from the Niger delta and the resultant whittling down of Benin's trading hinterland to the extent of the eventual abandonment of Ughoton, Benin's traditional port. Further west, suspicion of British political intentions grew in 1851 when Lagos was bombarded by the anti-slave trade squadron.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the political field', 'content': 'The second positive political impact is the very geo-political appearance of the modern independent states of Africa. The colonial partition and conquest definitely resulted, as A. E. Afigbo has pointed out above (Chapter 19), in a revolutionary reshaping of the political face of Africa. In place of the hundreds of independent clan and lineage groups, city-states, king› doms and empires, without any clearly marked boundaries, were now established fifty new states with, in most cases, fixed boundaries, and it is rather significant that the boundaries of the states as laid down during the colonial era have not undergone any changes since independence.
Thirdly, the colonial system also introduced into most parts of Africa two new institutions which again rather significantly have been maintained since independence, namely, a new judicial system and a new bureaucracy or civil service. There is no doubt that in practically all the independent states except the Muslim ones, the higher courts of judicature introduced by the colonial rulers have been retained; in the former British colonies not only in form (including, despite the climate, even the wigs and gowns), but also in content and ethos.
The machineries introduced for the administration of the colonies also steadily led, though in many areas rather belatedly, to the emergence of a civil service whose membership and influence increased with the years. The importance of this particular legacy varied from one colonial system to the other. There is no doubt that the British bequeathed a better trained, numerically larger and more experienced bureaucracy to her colonies than the French, while the record of the Belgians and the Portuguese is the worst in this respect.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.685, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the New World', 'section_title': 'Conclusions', 'content': "What were the effects of colonial African and American black interaction? Only African populations of certain regions were initially involved in inter› action with American and Caribbean blacks. Those regions involved early in our period were the ones which became the focus of American black emigration or evangelism, particularly West Africa, South Africa, and the Horn. Peoples of other regions became involved because of the penetration of their region by pan-Africanist projects, American black writings, folk› lore, and the like, or more importantly, because of the initiatives of school leavers who went, in growing numbers from all over the African continent, to America for higher education.
Perspectives were undoubtedly affected by direct and substantial inter› action of Africans within a particular black environment or set of influences. Exactly how much is anybody's guess. The effect of colonial African experience with American blacks appears, nevertheless, unique and vital in terms of subsequent social and political activities. For some, the American black component within African nationalist ideology and strategies emerging during the colonial period was striking and unequivocal. In the view of others, for example some African students, interactions within American black arenas were disappointing and unrewarding. The caustic assessment of one such visitor illustrates the latter point: 'One of the things I had decided to find out during my stay in America was the condition of the descendants of former slaves brought here from Africa ... I feel safe in saying that, so far as economic and material progress are concerned the Negro in America is on the average ahead of the West African, but when it comes to integrity and genuine manhood, the American Negro is far below him.' 75 Another view was that many Afro-American missionaries who viewed Africans as 'poor heathen savages' must bear some of the responsibility for perpetuating a distorted and pernicious picture of Africa and Africans in the minds of their fellow American blacks. [{'id': 135, 'article_title': 'Anamaboe: Reception of Governor Pine', 'full_section_title': 'Anamaboe: Reception of Governor Pine', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1863#article-14', 'issue_date': '23_03_1863', 'content': 'After the interview was over, the whole of the assembled force again fired a general salute, and then the King and chiefs retired, their men firing as they withdrew. It was altogether a splendid sight, and very interesting, even to those who were not entire strangers to such scenes. The immense crowd of spectators, all of whom were dressed in their holiday attire, added greatly to the effect. The number of young men and women dressed in European style astonished even the old residents. There was a very large sprinkling of young females expensively got up in native attire. Although there were three or four professors of the art of photography on the spot, yet it is a pity that not one of them availed himself of such a favourable occasion to take a group of African fair ones, so that their likenesses might have been enclosed herewith, in order that you kind people in England might see how shamefully some of your would-be artists misrepresent African females in features, dress, and everything else. After the termination of this African review, which passed off without the slightest accident, and at which the Governor expressed himself highly pleased, his Excellency and suite returned to the fort. In the evening a sumptuous banquet was given to his Excellency in the grand hall of the fort, by the Commandant and the principal residents of Anamaboe. Covers were laid for fifty guests. The King and three of his principal chiefs were invited, as also several gentlemen from Cape Coast and Anamaboe. The officers of the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles were also present in full uniform. The viands and wines were of the most _recherché_ description. After the usual loyal toasts, the health of his Excellency was proposed and responded to with that hearty goodwill which testifies to the respect that the Africans of the Gold Coast still entertain towards the representative of Her Majesty the Queen of England, in spite of the severe shocks which they have experienced on perceiving that their confidence in, and respect for, some of their late rulers were so woefully misplaced. A native band enlivened the festivity by performing some popular native airs on native instruments, late in the evening—the first time, I believe, that the services of a _bona fide_ native band had ever been called into requisition on such an occasion. On the 4th, at noon, his Excellency proceeded in an open carriage to the Fort-gate, whence a procession set out for the site appointed for the erection of the new market, in the following order: A carriage containing his Excellency and suite; a detachment of the Gold Coast Artillery; a detachment of the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles; merchants and other residents of Anamaboe; the members of the Anamaboe Temperance Society, under their president and founder, R. J. Ghartey; the boys and girls of the Wesleyan Mission School, preceded by the Rev. Timothy Laing, native minister. On arriving at the site, his Excellency was met by the King and chiefs with their staff, who had formed a most brilliant procession from another quarter of the town. A silver trowel was presented to his Excellency by Commandant Thomson, and after the usual observances, not forgetting the new coins, his Excellency proceeded to lay the foundation-stone; which done, he delivered a brief but most appropriate speech. The school-children then sang "God save the Queen," and their performance so delighted the Governor, that he caused them to repeat the anthem, at the conclusion of which three cheers were given, and the procession returned in the same order that it had arrived. The weather was most propitious during the whole of the time. During the day many chiefs from different parts of the country in the commandantship of Anamaboe came into town with their retainers and fired salutes and reviewed their men, in honour of the Governor. The proceedings of this day were brought to a fitting conclusion by a _grand 'relish,'_ or, as you would term it, a _déjeuner à la fourchette,_ in the fort, and the performance of the numerous guests on the occasion bore ample testimony to the fact that they did not come there for mere pastime. His Excellency and suite returned to Cape Coast Castle early on the ensuing morning. With the exception of the Governor, Major Cochrane, Lieutenant Thomson, and Mr. Brown, of Cape Coast, all those who assisted in the ceremonies of these two days were natives of Africa, including some hundreds of educated men. His Excellency expressed himself highly gratified with the brilliant reception given him by the loyal people of Anamaboe, and was particularly struck with the appearance of the Anamaboe Volunteer Rifles. This corps is composed entirely of educated Africans, the officers being selected from the principal merchants and residents of Anamaboe, having for their colonel S. C. Brew, Esq., J.P.'}, {'id': 2633, 'article_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'full_section_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/31_12_1873#article-8', 'issue_date': '31_12_1873', 'content': 'King George Pepple a large share of support, in his endeavours to introduce into his country a civilized form of government, and a civilized order of things in general—by studying to acquire such intimate knowledge of the customs, tastes, and modes of thought of the native chiefs, as will peculiarly qualify him to settle their mutual palavers in the interest of commerce, with facility and success, by equitably and yet firmly composing all commercial or other differences that may arise between these chiefs and British traders and residents; in fine, by making it his aim to promote alike British as well as native interests, he may justly deserve, and speedily win, the confidence, esteem, affection, and gratitude of all classes of the population, European and African, within the countries placed under his jurisdiction. We cordially welcome him among us, and pray that his Consulship may be characterized by tangible results of a beneficial nature to this portion of our Coast. It will, I doubt not, also interest you to learn that Captain Nicol, one of the official members of the Coomassie Expedition, also arrived here from Cape Coast, in quest of men to join the native troops proposed to be organized for that expedition. He has obtained from Jaja, of Opobo, about fifty-three men, whom he has taken to the seat of war per steamship Biafra. He has also entered into some negotiations with the King and chiefs of Bonny; and Prince Charles, Mr. John Jumbo (son of Oko Jumbo), and Mr. John Martin have been ordered by King George Pepple to go to Cape Coast or Accra with one hundred picked men, who have been drilled morning and evening gratuitously by Captain Hopkins (ex-Vice-Consul). It is understood that it is open to the Prince and Mr. Jumbo to remain at the Gold Coast at their discretion, or be recalled by the King, as circumstances may require. They will leave per steamship Liberia, by which also you will receive this letter. We hope this will lead to good in many ways.—Yours sincerely, A Votary of Civilization.'}, {'id': 2871, 'article_title': "Commodore Hewitt's Letter to King George Peppel on Arriving in the Bonny River with the Testimonial", 'full_section_title': "Commodore Hewitt's Letter to King George Peppel on Arriving in the Bonny River with the Testimonial", 'last_edit_date': '03-08-1875', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1875#article-4', 'issue_date': '01_06_1875', 'content': "H.M.S. Encounter, Bonny River, March 8, 1875. King Peppel,—The object I have in visiting this river is to convey to you, on behalf of the Governor of the Gold Coast, the expression of Her Majesty Queen Victoria's high appreciation of your services during the late Ashanti War in sending to the British Expedition the contingent of 100 Bonny men under Prince Charlie, whose steady behaviour in the field was remarked both by the General and myself on more than one occasion. The reputation they thus gained for themselves, you will be pleased to hear, is not surpassed by any of our native allies.

I regret to find that King Jaja is unable to be here to-day, as I have a similar expression of Her Majesty's esteem to convey to him for the manner in which he also aided the expedition. I shall, however, write to him on the subject and inform him of the satisfactory conduct of his contingent of 50 Opobos, who, in proportion to their numbers, rendered equally good service with the Bonny men. To you, King Peppel, Her Majesty has, through her Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies, sent this silver tankard in token of her regard and friendship, and I am also the bearer of a letter from Governor Strahan to you in reference to the gift.

To King Jaja Her Majesty has presented this sword, but as he is not here to receive it from me, the delivery of it will be entrusted to Mr. Consul Hartley.

I have also a sword, presented by the Earl of Carnarvon to Prince Charlie in recognition of his gallant and faithful conduct during the campaign; and Mr. John Jumbo has been similarly rewarded for his services while acting as Prince Charlie's Lieutenant.

Prince Charlie's sword will be given to him on my arrival at Fernando Po, where I learn he now is.

(Signed) JON. W. HEWITT.

Letter above referred to.

Government House, Cape Coast, Feb. 22, 1875. King,—I am desired by Her Majesty's Secretary of State for the Colonies to convey to you, on behalf of the Queen and Her Majesty's Government, a high appreciation of your services during the recent Ashanti War.

The gift intended to accompany this letter and to serve as a memorial and reward of the above did not reach Liverpool in time to catch the last mail steamer. It will be forwarded by first opportunity.—I am, King, yours truly,

(Signed) GEO. C. STRAHAN, Governor.

King George Peppel, Bonny.

Reply of King George.

Grand Bonny, March 18, 1875.

Governor,—Your letter under date of the 22nd of February, conveying, on behalf of Her Majesty the Queen and Her Government, their high appreciation of my services during the recent Ashanti War, with the accompanying gift, was delivered to me on the 8th instant by Commodore Sir W. Hewitt."}, {'id': 5269, 'article_title': 'The Germans in Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The Germans in Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_12_1885', 'content': "The plans for the Government Buildings for the Cameroons are now ready, and they will as soon as possible be put into execution, since the houses in which the officials at the Cameroons are at present residing are unhealthy and not befitting the position of their occupants. The site of the buildings is known as Joss Flat, on the left bank of the Cameroons river, and gives a comprehensive view of the Cameroons mountains, the sea, and the heights of the interior. The principal building contains a dwelling and a reception-room, a dining-room, the office, and five other rooms suitable for dwelling or bedrooms, with a room beneath for guests, a bathroom, and three servants' rooms. As with all buildings for Europeans there, the ground floor comprises an open hall. The house is only two-storied in the middle part, the rest being one story. The foundations will be made of a volcanic quarried stone to be found hard by, but bricks will be used for the structure, and these, together with the wood for the roof, doors, and windows, &c., will be taken from Germany. Native workmen from Accra will be employed. The total costs are placed at 66,000 marks (£3,300).

A letter has lately been received from Sergeant Biehlecke, of the Kaiser Franz Regiment, who was sent out to the Cameroons a few months ago to organize a police force, and who is at present at Bageida, in Toga-land. With Biehlecke are two other under-officers, who proceeded to West Africa for the same purpose. The little expedition was well equipped with various side-arms, carbines, and 20,000 cartridges. With these weapons a number of blacks are being exercised as a protective force. Biehlecke has, as at home, to make daily reports on all accidents, arrests, crimes, offences, &c., which are handed in to Consul Schmidt, his next superior. The merchants of the Cameroon Colony are said by the letter to be very friendly disposed, placing their kitchens at the sergeant's disposal in the absence of the familiar restaurants."}, {'id': 5566, 'article_title': 'The Colonial Conference', 'full_section_title': 'The Colonial Conference', 'last_edit_date': '08-01-1887', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1887#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_08_1887', 'content': 'This School offers special advantages to young African ladies desiring to pursue their studies in England.
