[{'document_title': 'Great Demonstration in Honour of Mr. Chamerovzow, the Secretary of the Anti-Slavery Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Rev. J. Johnson, in seconding the resolution, said: When we remember that on the very spot we stand was a slave mart, whilst now free institutions have sprung up instead, through the exertions of our friends in England, we cannot but be thankful for what has taken place, and do all in our power to show a sense of gratitude to our benefactors. Philanthropists have done much and very much for us, and it is as little as we can do for ourselves to show that we are not ignorant of or ungrateful for their priceless service. When I contrast the present state of the colony with what it was in days gone by I am lost in astonishment at the changes that have been wrought. I remember being on one occasion at the Bananas where I was called upon to preach, and during my discourse I observed an old man who wept bitter tears. After the service was concluded, I asked him what in the discourse so sensibly affected him, when he replied, "My son, I cannot refrain from weeping when I see our own children preaching to us the Gospel of peace. We had not that privilege, and had any one told me that I should be permitted to see our own children put in such a position I should not have believed it—I should have considered such a thing impossible." Now I ask you, Gentlemen, by whose influence has this change, with others equally great and beneficial to our race, been brought about? Why, by the efforts of the good people in England. But the time has come when we should not look to them to do all for us; we are now capable to help ourselves, and to benefit by the example which they have set us. Through the kindness of some kind-hearted friends in that land who paid for my education, I owe my present standing. I am grateful for what has been done for my country and myself, and shall always endeavor to prove myself so. But I must say that our native merchants in good and prosperous circumstances do not do their duty to the country as they should. How many of the sons of the soil have been educated by any of them and at their expense? I know not of a single instance. Foreigners have come here and supported at our Grammar-school youths who have turned out a blessing to the country, whilst our own wealthy countrymen have shown themselves destitute of any feeling of their duty in this respect. Are we to leave everything to strangers to do for us? Are we never to put forth an effort to help ourselves? Is the whole burden to be thrown on our Anti-Slavery friends? I say no; we must be aroused to our duty. There is a great work before us, we have been made free, and in our turn we must free others. Slavery, as we all know, exists among the surrounding tribes; we must discourage it by pointing out its evil, and by sending the Gospel to enlighten and subdue them. We must do more than we have all along been doing; we must show our friends in England that their labor has not been spent in vain; we must prove our gratitude by copying their bright example. It is time that we form an Anti-Slavery Society among ourselves, to put down the hateful system wherever it is found in Africa. Those of us who have felt the bitterness know how it brutalizes man, the noblest of God's creatures, and how it destroys all his powers, both of body and mind. Now we are here called upon to recognize the claims which Mr. Chamerovzow, the noble Secretary of the Anti-Slavery Society, has on us. It is well known that this gentleman for eighteen years has been spending his time in advocating our cause, and opposing slavery wherever it existed. We have been told by another speaker that his services were so sparingly rewarded, owing to the very limited means of the society, that now that society is virtually extinct, we find Mr. Chamerovzow with a family unprovided for. We are called upon now to show our gratitude by raising a substantial testimonial to the Secretary, and we are to do this liberally in proportion to our means. This is a matter which concerns every son of Africa, for all have been benefited by the exertions of the noble Secretary and the society of which, I may say, he was the life. There must be, I say, no niggardly giving in this matter; we must give freely, liberally, and with all our heart. I have gone to a greater length than I intended when I first got up, but the importance of the cause justifies the intrusion I have made on the meeting; and being fully persuaded that your contributions will come up to the confidence reposed in you, I shall take up no more of your time.', 'last_edit_date': '1870-03-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1870#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.64, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Too much praise cannot be given you for your unwearied and long-continued efforts on behalf of poor Africa and her unfortunate sons. The lively interest and heartfelt sympathy you have always manifested in the work of Africa's regeneration and advancement seems ever to be increasing with the onward march of time, and it is to be hoped that such zealous and benevolent efforts will be crowned with abundant success.

Your remarks on the subject of Education in your last two issues, and the convincing arguments you advanced to recommend the subject to the notice of the "higher powers," have been read by not a few here with feelings of deep gratitude and satisfaction. It is greatly to be hoped that such an earnest appeal will not be suffered to pass by unheard. It is gratifying to state that the Accra Church of England High-class School has been fairly established and set in proper working order, and since its establishment the number of its pupils has been steadily on the increase. If, as stated in my previous correspondence, such a school as the High-class School be amply and efficiently supported, it will prove a great boon to the place. That the educational work that is thus being inaugurated here needs such support as you have pleaded for will be evident from the fact that it has not been undertaken by the Church Missionary Society, as your remarks would seem to indicate, but by the sole efforts of some of the native residents of this place, who, sensible of the great educational wants of the community, have requested the Bishop of Sierra Leone to aid them in the establishment here of the Church of England with a properly-organized school; and the kind-hearted prelate, ever ready to lend a helping hand to every very good work, promised to aid their efforts in the undertaking. From this it will be seen that such needful help as you have advocated is a *sine qua non* in the proper development of education in this place; and should it be afforded, an efficient staff of competent teachers will be secured, and high-class schools, grammar schools, collegiate schools, and other seminaries of learning will be established along this Coast, which will undoubtedly be productive of unspeakable benefit to the country at large. This, Mr. Editor, in my humble opinion, will be the only panacea for the effectual eradication of the moral, social, and intellectual evil under which "the land is groaning."

The hope of this country's elevation seems to me to be in the rising and future generations, in the proper development of their intellectual faculties, and the instilment into their minds of the "sweets" of education. Without this, there will be but small encouragement to hope for the fulfilment of the oft-repeated prophecy of "Africa shall rise."', 'last_edit_date': '1880-11-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Roll of African Worthies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our heart swells with exultation whenever we are able to point to a name to be inscribed on the historical roll of African worthies. We have still among us in Great Britain not a few who contemptuously deny the common brotherhood of the African and the European; who determinedly ignore the effects of degrading influences through a long succession of generations on the one, and the effects of ennobling influences throughout a similar period on the other; and, comparing the actual condition of the two, bidding us "look on this picture and on this," maintain that they are not the "counterfeit presentment of two brothers," of two divisions of the great human family derived originally from one common stock, but of two races essentially different, the one inherently and ineradicably lower than the other in the scale of intellectual being. It is therefore not surprising that we, who contend for the Scriptural truth of the common humanity of all men and peoples on the face of this earth, should feel our heart bound with joy when one of those whom our spoiled children of science, and the inheritors of slave-trade prejudices, would relegate to the lower place, vindicates by deeds which, in European estimation, are regarded as ennobling to humanity the claim of his race to an equality with the proud "Caucasian." Such a man was Doctor Davis, of whose lamented death while engaged in a voluntary, self-imposed, gratuitous, and most self-denying work among the wretched victims of a cruel war, a notice will this month be found in our columns. When we reflect that it is only five-and-thirty years since the debasing chain of slavery was removed from those of the African race in Barbadoes, and that this man, born within ten years after, should have thus wrung from French, Germans, and Englishmen such high and well-deserved tributes of loving gratitude, admiration, and praise, we experience a fresh stimulus to exertion for Africans in Africa to effect, as soon as possible, that every impediment to their progress in Christian civilisation may be removed, that every badge of their supposed inferiority shall be obliterated, and that institutions shall be planted among them calculated to foster and develop that worthy spirit of emulation to rival their European brethren which we regard as a powerful spring of action in the coming regeneration of Africa; and it does seem to us that both Sierra Leone and Lagos, which are the, at present, chief points of civilised commercial development on the West Coast, ought to lose no time in erecting in Sierra Leone and in Lagos a column on which shall be from time to time inscribed the names of those of the African race in whose favour the world may pronounce, as in the case of the late lamented Dr. Davis; and of others whose future services to Africa, in Africa and elsewhere, may, by universal acclaim among them, be deemed worthy to be had in undying remembrance, as worthy of honour and imitation by their brother Africans.', 'last_edit_date': '1870-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1870#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'OUR THIRD VOLUME.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Non ego, sed gratia Dei."*

In commencing our Third Volume, we hope we shall be considered justified in saying that our promises have been fulfilled. It is on this ground that we call for continued and increased support. We have let in more light upon African affairs than was ever before thrown on them. But our allotted task is only begun. If we have checked some evils, prepared the way for the removal of others, and effected some real good, we regard these results as merely the first stones in our structure of African improvement. We receive from so many quarters in Africa the gratifying assurances that this journal is exercising great power for good, that we now claim from the friends of Africa, as a right, that support which we first solicited, in hope that we might possibly advance by our labours the great cause of the industrial regeneration of Africa. It is not too much to say that we have prepared the way for those commercial companies which are now coming full of promise into the great field of undeveloped African commerce. We have given Africa a voice among influential people in Great Britain. We have made her cries for help, that she can and will so richly repay, heard by those who have the power and the knowledge that are needed for successful efforts in her great fields of produce. But when we compare her gigantic evils with the elements of good directed against them, we feel that the work of her regeneration is one that demands the devotion of our life, and in which that life, by God's blessing, shall be spent. We can do nothing, however, without proper support. It is only by its being subscribed for, and read, that this journal can prove effective. And even so the African Times must necessarily have comparatively but little weight and influence without the effective organization of the African-Aid Society at its back; constantly available for action with Government and individuals for removing obstacles from the path of African progress; for denouncing with a voice of authority abuses which have but too long prevailed; apathy and inertia that reflect disgrace upon Great Britain as a civilized Christian power in presence of African barbarism and destructive superstition; and for pointing out the way to a better future.

out measures that must be adopted, if Africa is to be raised from her degradation, and the slave-trade and slavery destroyed upon her coasts and within her borders.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Tribute to the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE have been often rather tauntingly asked what the African-Aid Society is really effecting. Because querists could not see in our columns that the Society had sent "—emigrants to Africa on board the ship —," &c., they refused to comprehend that a great work was advancing under our hands. They forgot that one of our great objects is to prepare Africa for that influx of colonial civilization which will one day come in to accelerate her progress, as well as to help to bring in that coloured civilization to a home and a mission in Africa.

Under these circumstances, the letter from Anamaboe, which we now publish, is doubly gratifying to us. We offer our grateful thanks to our Gold Coast and other African friends for that and other evidences which we are now receiving of their appreciation of the benefits we are conferring upon Africa. We know that, if only adequately supported, we shall, within the next few years, be able, by God's help and blessing, to produce results in

**NOVEMBER 23, 1863.**

Africa that half a century, without the African-Aid Society or a similar organization, would not have witnessed.

The following is the letter above referred to:—

**TO THE PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY,  
8, ADELPHI-TERRACE, LONDON.**

Anamaboe, Gold Coast.

Gentlemen,—The immense good which the African-Aid Society has done for the Coast of Africa since their formation is a thing that is universally acknowledged by every African on the Coast. Through it the poorest man here has a means by which his grievances can be made known, and the want of the whole country properly represented in influential quarters; and I am sure that by the effectual organization of the African-Aid Society many valuable measures which have been proposed to the Government, having for object the raising of Africa from its degradation, but which have been squashed by Europeans on the Coast, who are dead against every measure having such tendency, will soon be so represented, that the Government will not hesitate to carry them into effect.

I am unable to express to you how grateful we are for what you have hitherto done; your Society is a necessity to Africa—a vital and indispensable one—and your existence will always ensure real, deep, and important improvements in Africa.

Truly satisfied of the inestimable benefit we have derived from the African-Aid Society and its valuable paper, I have endeavoured to urge their support not only amongst my countrymen, but also amongst Europeans, and request them to subscribe liberally to both; and I have improved the opportunity I lately had of visiting Cape Coast by calling upon each gentleman and asking his support. I am happy to state that they gave liberally towards my appeal. The only unfortunate circumstance is that the war has destroyed the country, and there is no trade whatever, or I might have been able to forward you more. I hope you will acknowledge the subscriptions in the African Times.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Industrial Education in Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '*at foot,* from the missionary paper of Abeokuta, is a tardy, but a powerful justification of the views of the African-Aid Society. Written apropos of frequent fires in Abeokuta, and of the want of some non-inflammable material for the roofs of the air and light-excluding native hut, the writer shows how slowly the system hitherto pursued works for material improvement, and the need of efforts in an industrial direction: "It is quite a question whether skilled labour should not in good policy take the lead, and reading and writing follow after, if not in point of time, yet in point of importance." And again: "Religion would be best promoted in the end by making industrial pursuits the first aim (not before religion, but before head knowledge) in point of importance. It is difficult, as experience proves in the few efforts already made, to communicate hand knowledge, but where the welfare of a country is considered, difficulties should be less thought of." The African-Aid Society and the African Times have never spoken out more strongly than this. Truth will make its way, in spite of prejudice and jealousy. The "native who returned from the Brazils," and who was sent out to Abeokuta under the auspices of the African-Aid Society, gives a faint foreshadowing of the material advancement in Africa that will some day result from the return of the African race in America to the lands of their forefathers. Had not some of the missionary body in Abeokuta opposed the sending of such people from America by the African-Aid Society, many brick and tile makers, and other valuable artisans, might now have been established there. We are glad to see that a change is coming over the spirit of our friends in that place. America will soon have many choice workmen and agriculturists from among its emancipated slaves, ready to bring their industrial knowledge to the assistance of the land of their forefathers. There are representatives there of every African race on the West, and of many races on the East Coast. Meanwhile we must all, Government and people, do the best we can, wherever British authority is in any way acknowledged, to introduce into the country those improvements in means of intercommunication, in dwellings, in tillage, and in mechanical arts, that civilization in Europe and America has acquired, and by which alone civilization can progress. We repeat our belief that coloured artisans from America are valuable, if not indispensable, for this work.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'OUR THIRD VOLUME.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have therefore no hesitation in calling upon our friends and subscribers not only to continue to us their individual support, but also to use their efforts for obtaining _new subscribers to this journal_, and _new subscribers to the African-Aid Society_, upon whose prosperity so much of the future usefulness of this journal depends. We desire that there be no mistake in this important matter. The _African Times_ and the _African-Aid Society_ are necessary to each other—and both are necessary—indispensable—of real, deep, vital importance to Africa. Let all, therefore, who are, and who profess themselves to be, the friends of Africa give both to the one and to the other that degree of support which other claims upon them will allow of their giving. It is not by wishes, but by work, that the great African industrial regeneration, so important to Great Britain as well as for Africa, is to be achieved. This special service, it is evident, can only be efficiently rendered by ourselves; but we must have the help of our European friends, as well as of those Governments to whom we owe allegiance, and whom hitherto we have so faithfully served; for they are our guardians: we are their protégés. We have already given full proof of our capabilities as a race; we have also shown ourselves peaceable, thoroughly amenable to good government, and ready to participate in all movements tending to promote the common weal.

Moreover, it is only reasonable that Africa, the land of our forefathers, and our legitimate inheritance, should be the proper sphere of our labours. There, from racial prejudices emancipated, with due diligence and perseverance, and the Divine blessing upon all, not only would we be able to find ample scope for our powers, but, as already pointed out, we could give to the Natives the benefits of the civilisation we have received, which they greatly need, and which, connected as we are with them by so many natural ties, they would accept much better from us than from others who do not know them, and whom they do not understand.

73 George Street, Edinburgh, Sept. 10, 1896.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In that letter Mr. Rosenbush, who has been eighteen years resident at Sierra Leone, states, as an incontrovertible fact, that missionary efforts have produced very beneficial results—that the most cursory comparison of the people of Sierra Leone, composed in a great measure of Africans liberated from the holds of slave-ships, with the natives of places where the influence of missionaries is not known, will establish this without dispute. Mr. Rosenbush's views so intimately coincide with our own as to the means by which "improvement and civilization" may be best advanced in the colony of Sierra Leone, that we may be excused again entering largely upon them at this time. The agricultural improvement of the colony demands the special attention of Government authorities; and when, as in this case, a means is pointed out which only requires a better disposal of the revenues raised in the colony itself, by making them instrumental in obtaining reproductive results from the enforced labour of the criminal portion of the population, instead of that labour being wasted, as at present, no trivial objections or inapplicable theories ought to be allowed to stand in the way of its adoption. There is no wealthy landed proprietary in the colony, themselves acquainted practically with agricultural industry, who might, and would, if they existed, initiate efforts and experiments for developing the resources of the soil. The "germ of improvement and civilization" now "lies," as Mr. Rosenbush most truly says, "in Africa, and Africans themselves, aided by European direction, could be the constructors of their own social improvement." hh: European expeditions in Africa heavily relied on the crucial cooperation, knowledge, and labor of local African communities and leaders, whose contributions were often essential yet frequently overlooked in the success of these missions.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that European expeditions in Africa heavily relied on the crucial cooperation, knowledge, and labor of local African communities and leaders, whose contributions were often essential yet frequently overlooked. The textbook highlights the role of local chiefs as integral to the colonial administrative structure, serving as links between colonial authorities and the population, and emphasizes the necessity for Europeans to operate within pre-existing African transportation and communication systems. It also notes African rulers' regulation of trade and engagement with missionaries for education and technology, underscoring the cooperation between Europeans and Africans. However, it points out that these contributions were often overshadowed by European military and logistical superiority, with European narratives downplaying African roles. Similarly, The African Times articles provide specific examples, such as the Mocklolo community supplying resources for Mr. Young's steamer and carriers transporting goods across challenging terrains. Local leaders like King Lepopo and Chief M'Punda are noted for their assistance to explorers, further illustrating the indispensable support from African communities. Yet, the articles also reflect a tendency to focus on European achievements, with limited acknowledgment of African contributions. Together, these sources illustrate the essential yet underappreciated role of Africans in the success of European expeditions and colonial endeavors.

The mention of African rulers regulating trade and engaging with missionaries for education and technology further supports the idea of cooperation. However, the text also emphasizes the overwhelming military and logistical superiority of Europeans, which suggests that while African contributions were significant, they were often overshadowed by European dominance. The text does not explicitly state that these contributions were frequently overlooked, but it does imply that European narratives often downplayed African roles, as seen in the discussion of the dichotomy between so-called collaborators and resisters. Overall, the textbook supports the claim by illustrating the essential yet often underappreciated role of Africans in European expeditions and colonial endeavors.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that European expeditions in Africa heavily relied on the cooperation, knowledge, and labor of local African communities and leaders. For instance, the articles mention the assistance provided by local chiefs and communities, such as the Mocklolo, who supplied meat, grain, and wood for Mr. Young's steamer, and the carriers who helped transport goods across difficult terrains. Additionally, the articles highlight the role of local leaders like King Lepopo, who aided explorers in the Merutse kingdom, and Chief M'Punda, who offered land for settlement. These examples illustrate the essential contributions of African communities to the success of European missions. However, the articles also reflect a tendency to overlook these contributions, as the focus often remains on the achievements of the European explorers themselves, with limited acknowledgment of the indispensable support from local populations. This aligns with the claim that while African contributions were crucial, they were frequently underappreciated in historical narratives.

The political and economic reconstruction that followed the Civil War in the USA accompanied a movement of legal discrimination and social and economic exclusion of the non-white sector, characterized by segregated institutions, lynchings, and overtly racist societies and organ› izations, which combined until the middle of the twentieth century.$^{54}$ The general conditions experienced by black Americans then compared with those prevailing today in a more extreme way in South Africa.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African diaspora', 'section_title': 'The diaspora in Europe', 'content': 'This community of Africans in Europe was also concentrated in certain occupations, especially domestic service, this being partly a carry-over from the occupational status of Africans who came by way of West Indian slavery, partly a reflection of the European fad for exotic servants. [{'id': 163, 'article_title': 'Speke and Grant joined by Petherick on the White Nile', 'full_section_title': 'Speke and Grant joined by Petherick on the White Nile', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_05_1863', 'content': 'Sir,—It will be a relief to the public anxiety respecting the fate of Mr. Petherick, whose death had been announced some time ago in a telegram from Alexandria, to hear the good news that he is alive and well, having effected a junction with Captains Speke and Grant at Gondokoro, on the White Nile, on the 23rd of February.

In reference to the great question of the sources of the Nile, Captain Speke thus writes to me:—

"I said I would do it, and I have done it. The Victoria Nyanza is the great reservoir of the sacred Bahr el Abiad (White Nile). ... I think I may safely say (he adds) that I never felt so rejoiced as I did when Petherick delivered to me your letter, notifying that the Royal Geographical Society had adjudicated to me their Founder's Medal (for the discovery of the Lake Victoria Nyanza), the more so as the kind expressions in your letter reached me just as my trials were over."

By the intelligence communicated to the Foreign-office by Mr. Colquhoun, Her Britannic Majesty's Consul at Alexandria, and for which I am indebted to Mr. Hammond, it appears that the Viceroy of Egypt was about to send a steamer to Assouan, to bring Speke and party down to Cairo, so that we may soon welcome them at home.

It further appears that Baker, the adventurous author of the "Rifle and Hound," had gone to the south-west in search of another great internal lake, or branch of the White Nile, and will return in one year.

Captain Speke, writing on the 30th of March, from Khartum to Mr. Saunders at Alexandria (as I learn by a letter just received from Mr. C. L. Conyngham, of the Foreign-office), says:—

"We left Petherick, wife, and doctor all well at Gondokoro. Baker, who was the first Englishman we met with, gave us assistance in boats, stores, and money."

As Captain Speke was in anxiety as to the means of sending back the negro porters and attendants, 23 in number, to their native country, near Zanzibar, I am happy to say that this wish has been anticipated by the last mail. Believing that he would be so embarrassed, I applied to my friend, Admiral W. H. Hall, who, as one of the directors of the Peninsular and Oriental Navigation Company, has liberally arranged with his associates that these poor and faithful people shall be conveyed _gratis_ to Aden or Bombay, whence they can be shipped direct for Zanzibar.

Looking to the vigour of Consul Petherick, and his being so well inured to African climate, I ventured to say at the last meeting of the Geographical Society that I thought he would emerge from the region into which he had penetrated, notwithstanding the loss of his stores and the disasters which had befallen him.

This discovery of Speke and Grant, by which the southernmost limit of the basin of the Nile is determined to be four degrees south of the equator, is the most remarkable geographical feat of our age, and is indeed an achievement of which all our countrymen may well be proud.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

RODERICK I. MURCHISON.'}, {'id': 2198, 'article_title': 'REPORT BY BISHOP CROWTHER OF A JOURNEY OVERLAND FROM THE RIVER NIGER TO LAGOS.', 'full_section_title': 'REPORT BY BISHOP CROWTHER OF A JOURNEY OVERLAND FROM THE RIVER NIGER TO LAGOS.', 'last_edit_date': '02-20-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1872#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_04_1872', 'content': 'To the Rev. D. Olubi, Native Pastor at Ibadan, to Mr. Franklin, of the Wesleyan Mission of Abeokuta, and to Mr. and Mrs. Robbin, of Ake, many thanks are due. Not only had these gentlemen thrown their houses open for our accommodation, but for several days Mrs. Robbin undertook to superintend the cooking department, to change our diet; to which was very kindly added by Mr. J. George and Mr. Robbin, refreshing drinkables, such as beer, lemonade, soda water, tea, coffee, and chocolate, at their expense, which greatly conduced to restore the declining health of the travelling party, and strengthen them for their remaining journey.

These acts of kindness deserve to be thus noticed, as the example was set by King Masaba in gratitude to the Queen, whose subjects we are, and had nothing in hand during our journey to make adequate returns.'}, {'id': 2334, 'article_title': 'Handsome Tribute by Mr. Stanley to Former East African Explorers', 'full_section_title': 'Handsome Tribute by Mr. Stanley to Former East African Explorers', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-21', 'issue_date': '23_10_1872', 'content': 'On the 18th, at a banquet at Guildhall, London, Mr. Stanley was presented with the freedom of the City of London by the Hon. Company of Turners. In reply to an address Mr. Stanley read the following speech:—

"Gentlemen,—You congratulate me on my bravery in penetrating to the silent and fabled interior. I may not accept the compliment alone for having been the means of opening the country. A Burton and Speke had already gone in advance, and by the former's exhaustive remarks concerning the unknown regions, I was enabled to use them for my advantage and for the guidance of my steps through the jungle when the expedition in the search of Dr. Livingstone was endangered by minatory natives. Burton's experience was with me at all times, and if one road was closed, another was open to the goal of my hopes. Without travelling by the same road that my predecessors had taken, the travels of those two explorers were of value to me by enabling me to choose a shorter route to the Unyanyembe. Beyond this point, though I diverged widely from this road, I knew where Ujiji was located, and, with compass and watch in hand, I could direct the steps of the expedition thither. It took seven months to reach Ujiji, now I could take one four months. I have studied the nature of the country and its inhabitants fairly well, and I cannot see why a well-organized expedition might not start from the East African coast, and arrive within four months in view of Tanganyika-Herin. I recognise the utility of my work as well as that of Burton and Speke. It is, indeed, available to commerce and trade. It is in the hands of moneyed men to take advantages of the explorer's labours, not only to obtain pecuniary profit from trade enterprises, but to obtain the acknowledgments of civilised nations for the opening of new markets and the extension of commerce. I am proud to have been the means of opening up a new world to the enterprise of the civilised world, and I trust that the work I have done will be followed up by others, who will complete what I have begun."'}, {'id': 2647, 'article_title': 'Lamented Death of Dr. Livingstone', 'full_section_title': 'Lamented Death of Dr. Livingstone', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_01_1874#article-0', 'issue_date': '29_01_1874', 'content': 'We have received the following communication: "The Chairman of the Eastern Telegraph Company presents his compliments to the Editor of the African Times, and begs to hand him the following message received yesterday morning from the Company's agent at Aden: 'Livingstone died of dysentery while travelling from Lake Bemba to Unyanyembe. Body embalmed and preserved in salt by his Nassick boys, who are conveying it to Zanzibar en route for England.'"

**ADEN, January 26.**—Dr. Livingstone died in June of dysentery at Lake Bemba, after wading through water for four days. His body has been preserved in salt by his native servants and is proceeding to Zanzibar.

The following telegram, dated Aden, the 27th instant, has been received at the Foreign-office, from Her Majesty's Acting Consul-General at Zanzibar: "The report of Livingstone's death is confirmed by letters received from Cameron, dated Unyanyembe, October 20. He died of dysentery after a fortnight's illness; shortly after leaving Lake Bemba for eastward, he had attempted to cross the lake from the north, and, failing in this, had doubled back and rounded the lake, crossing the Chambize and the other rivers flowing from it; had then crossed the Luapula and died in Lobisa, after having crossed a marshy country with the water for three hours at a time above the waist; ten of his men had died, and the remainder, consisting of seventy-nine men, were marching to Unyanyembe; they had disembowelled the body and had filled it with salt, and had put brandy into the mouth to preserve it. His servant, Chumas, went on ahead to procure provisions, as the party was destitute, and gave intelligence to Cameron, who expected the body in a few days. Cameron and his party had suffered greatly from fever and ophthalmia, but hoped to push on to Ujiji. Livingstone's body may be expected at Zanzibar in February. Please telegraph orders as to disposal. No leaden shells procurable here."

A correspondent of the Daily News sends the following:—"ADEN, Tuesday.—Dr. Livingstone died at the end of May or the beginning of June between Lake Bemba and Lake Tanganyika, of dysentery, caused by wading through water for several days. His body has been preserved in salt by his servants. When Lieutenant Cameron wrote on the 22nd October from Unyanyembe, the body was expected to arrive in four days. Lieutenant Cameron was suffering from temporary blindness. He intended to proceed at once to Ujiji to get Dr. Livingstone's papers.

GORRA, January 27.—Herr Richard Brenner, the German African traveller, has sent a communication from Zanzibar to Dr. Petermann, announcing the death of Dr. Livingstone, and stating that it occurred on the 15th of August, in the neighbourhood of Unyanyembe.'}, {'id': 3048, 'article_title': "Mr. Young's Expedition (Livingstonia Mission) to Lake Nyassa", 'full_section_title': "Mr. Young's Expedition (Livingstonia Mission) to Lake Nyassa", 'last_edit_date': '01-24-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1876#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_02_1876', 'content': 'Sir,—Many of your readers will be delighted to learn that excellent accounts have been received by Mrs. Young and myself from Mr. Edward Young, R.N., leader of the Free Kirk Mission in course of establishment on Cape Maclear, on Lake Nyassa, East Africa. His letters are dated Sept. 22, 1875, from the Upper Shiré, where he had just arrived with his little steamer, her boilers, and stores. Great difficulties had been experienced in getting up the Zambesi and Shiré. On account of their being so low he had several times to clear out his steamer entirely and drag her through the shallows; but by the 6th of September they succeeded in reaching the foot of the Murchison Rapids, where, having built a house, they at once commenced to unscrew the Ilala.

The news of Mr. Young's arrival preceded him up the river, and our old friends the Mocklolo at once sent off supplies of meat and grain, and wood for the steamer to burn. As the boats passed up the river the natives flocked down to welcome them, shouting and singing, "Here comes the English; here comes Mr. Young." But their good-will was also shown in a more practical form, for from far and near carriers arrived, offering their services; and so Mr. Young had no difficulty in obtaining the number (800) he required, and was served with such right good-will that he tells me many of them carried unusually heavy loads for upwards of sixty miles, that others came from distances of forty miles to participate in the work, and that he only paid each man three fathoms of calico for doing the entire distance of about seventy miles, besides feeding themselves. Mr. Young expected to have his vessel all "a-tauto" again by the 6th of October, and fairly launched on the waters of the Upper Shiré, leading to that grand inland sea, Lake Nyassa, and thus, in all probability, be the first person to place a steam-vessel on one of the important African lakes. Mr. Young also found time on his way up to erect an iron cross; sent out by Miss Mackenzie, in memory of her beloved brother the Bishop, who so nobly died at his post in 1862. Lastly, I am informed that the whole mission party were in excellent health and spirits, though somewhat tired after the heavy work of carrying the steamer, stores, &c., past the Murchison Rapids.—I am, Sir, yours faithfully,'}, {'id': 3075, 'article_title': 'THE LIVINGSTONIA MISSION TO LAKE NYANZA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE LIVINGSTONIA MISSION TO LAKE NYANZA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-12', 'issue_date': '01_04_1876', 'content': 'The following interesting letter has been received by Captain J. C. Wilson, R.N.:—

"Upper Shire, Oct. 24, 1875.

"Dear Captain Wilson,—We launched the steamer successfully on the 6th, sailed on the 8th, and arrived on Lake Nyassa on the 12th inst. We employed 800 carriers to convey our goods and ship across the cataracts, and nothing was lost or injured. I have tried the steamer in a stiff breeze on the lake, and she is a good sea boat, and will steam seven knots with the one boiler. I have left the greater part of the party to build houses near Cape M'Clear, while I have come down to take up the remainder of our luggage. Thus far I think the whole affair a great success. It's true I have worn down a great deal, but have some mettle left in me yet. I start for Nyassa again to-morrow. On Nyassa I came up with one of the slave dhows, but she had no slaves on board, being bound for a cargo. Before we got near her they lowered their sail, and the master, coming from Zanzibar, at once said in broken English, "Me no got slaves in." We are a wonder and astonishment to all Arabs and natives; the former shake their heads, no doubt thinking that their game is up. There are five dhows on the lake. Before entering Nyassa, I called on the powerful chief, M'Punda, through whose dominions all the slaves for the coast pass. He was very civil, and made us presents, and gave us permission to settle on any part of his land. He owns the whole of the Cape M'Clear peninsula, and for a few pieces of calico I have reason to believe would allow slaves passing through his dominions. If you can do anything to bring it about, it would prove a great blessing to thousands of poor creatures. Please write me, and give me your advice.

"Dr. Stewart has not arrived yet, and if he does not soon I intend going round the lake.

"The whole of the party are very well indeed, and have been so; in fact, we have had no sickness, and the climate of Nyassa is delightful. We sleep with two blankets over us, and during the day we have a beautiful breeze off the lake. There is not a single native we have met with but is rejoiced to see us. "There has not been, as far as I am aware, the least hitch with any of the party, and they are all becoming daily more used to their work, especially Dr. Laws and the carpenter, who are particularly well suited to this kind of life, and have most ably assisted me. Again he resumed his practice among the diggers for diamonds, determined this time not to interrupt it again until he had accumulated the means for a much more important expedition then he had yet undertaken. Two years' labour brought him money enough for this purpose, and in March, 1875, he left Kimberley with ten oxen, intending to explore the Zambesi River from the Victoria Falls to its source, and then to push northward, and, if possible, to reach Darfur. In November, 1876, the adventurous physician returned to his old home in the diamond fields.

Now for the first time his good fortune seemed to abandon him. He could not doctor other people, for he was seriously ill himself with the fever he had brought back from the interior. For months he was confined to his tent. An exhibition of his collections in Kimberley, the chief town of the diamond fields, failed to bring him any money, the ignorant inhabitants feeling no interest in his scientific curiosities, and want stared him in the face. But reports of his explorations had reached Europe, and his distress was relieved by the receipt of small remittances of money sent by the Emperor of Austria and the Geographical Society of Vienna. **ROME, Friday, July 2.**—News has reached the Italian Geographical Society of the death, on the 5th October last, of the Engineer Chiarini, who formed part of their expedition to Central Africa. The deceased was on his way, accompanied by Captain Cecchi, to Lake Nyanza, when they were seized on as spies, and subjected to cruel treatment by the Queen of Chera, a small tributary state of the kingdom of Schoa. Captain Cecchi only succeeded in communicating the death of his friend by sending the letter in a small bag shaped like an amulet, and worn by a negro round his neck.

Our Naples Correspondent writes: "Another letter from Signor Massari, one of the members of the Italian African Expedition, has been received, containing the following particulars: At Obeid (Cordofan) the authorities, merchants, and camel-drivers, who had on other occasions reported to us the state of the country, and now heard of our intention to go to Bargù, all united in assuring us that there was no longer any road, and that the natives were of the worst description; but, on arriving there, we found many pilgrims from the confines of Bornu and distant Timbuctoo to the Tomb of the Prophet. Communication is, therefore, not impossible, and the choice lay between the route via Cobè and Cabiabia and that via Coleo and Messabite. Dr. Matteucci and Prince Borghese immediately departed for Cobè, the Governor of which place is Signor Francesco Emiliani, a native of Udine, who kindly came to meet us, and has accompanied the two travellers as far as Cabiabia, situated two days' journey from Cobè. One Nur Angara is Governor of Cabiabia, a European by sentiment though not by birth, and able, it is said, to do much for our Expedition. Mr. Thomson said in coming before this meeting he did not appear in the character of a discoverer. He had not to speak of unthought-of prospects for their trade and fresh fields for philanthropic work. He proposed to carry them into the classic lands of African exploration, redolent of memories in connexion with Park, Clapperton, Denham, Lander, Barth, and a host of others. His object was to remind them of the heritage bequeathed to the British through the enterprise of those great travellers, and won at the cost of manifold hardships. He undertook the task more readily as there seemed to be an incredible amount of ignorance with regard to the Central Soudan. Few are aware of the existence of semi-civilized negro empires in the very heart of Africa, and the names of Sokoto, Kano, Kukawa, Yakoba, Illorin, and Bida are known but to the student. The geographical knowledge of the many is restricted to a hazy idea of the existence of a town named Timbuctoo, near which the Niger flows on its way to the Atlantic. It must not, however, be imagined, though the world was thus ignorant of this important region, that it had been utterly ignored and left untouched. Far from it. For years past the National African Company has been at work establishing itself on the river. From point to point it has worked its way, till its factories extend far into the very heart of the continent. Till lately the Company had been content to feel its way, laying a solid commercial basis in each district before entering into the heart of Central Africa. With the rise of the African craze and the scramble for Africa, it became of importance that the position of the Company should be secured, lest the labours of half a century should be ruined by some startling development of foreign commercial enterprise. Communication must be opened up with the two great Sultans—viz., Maliké of Gandu and Umuru of Sokoto—into whose territories the Company had found its way. To undertake this work he had been selected, and he embraced the opportunity of seeing something of Western Africa and the Niger basin. Thus it was that he transferred himself from his field of research in Eastern Africa to the other side of the continent. Speaking of the gin trade on the coast, he said that it was a scandal and a shame. Having reached the town of Rabba, the furthest factory of the National African Company, preparations were made for the land journey. The caravan consisted of three Europeans—Mr. Thomson, Mr. Hamilton, his companion from England, and Mr. W. J. Seags, who took charge of the financial matters of the expedition. Then followed two educated Coast natives. The rest of the caravan consisted of natives—Brassmen, Kruboys, and Fantees, from Akra and Elmina. On the 9th of April the caravan set out, taking the road which leads to Koutokora, in the hope that they might proceed direct to Sokoto instead of having to take the circuitous river route. On reaching Jega, we were on the great trade route which connects Timbuctoo and the Western Soudan with Bornu, and the kingdoms of the Chad region. Hitherto we had passed through sparsely populated districts, or countries desolated by war. Now, however, we had reached a healthy densely populated part, which throbbed with commercial activity. The enormous trade carried on along this trunk line was to me a never-failing source of wonderment, so unlike was it to anything I had elsewhere seen or imagined. Thus he narrates how the Stanley, the largest of his steamers, came to grief. She "had been exploring some ragged reefs on an independent course, and had rashly attempted to plough them up." The Peace, borrowed from the English Baptist Mission at Stanley Pool, did not begin brilliantly. First she broke her rudder, and was forced to put back for repairs; then she gradually lost vital energy until she began to travel down instead of upstream. Then her engineer, "smarting under the imputation that his steamer was no better than a mud-scow, took counsel with a canny Scotch colleague," and the two hit upon the expedient of screwing the safety-valve down to retain the constantly-escaping steam. The result was that the Peace from that time was ever in the van, instead of the rear, and Mr. Stanley recommends her builder to have the invention patented at once. This cheery tone is explained by the statement that since leaving Bolobo there had been "no losses in men or goods, no famine, no inconvenience, no cause of anxiety." Mr. Stanley's next letter is that which enables us to disregard the rumours of his death. It is dated June 19, at the Yambuya Rapids, on the Aruwimi River. This was the point at which the route of the expedition leaves the Congo River, and turns inland. Mr. Stanley arrived at Yambuya on the 19th, and immediately began to form a camp as a base of operations for the march along the banks of the Aruwimi to Wadelai. The country in the neighbourhood of his camp is covered with villages. From the contemporaneous observations in Batanga (3 deg. north latitude) in the south and by Lake Elephant in the north, we may expect soon to obtain a thorough knowledge of the entire district of the Cameroons.'}, {'id': 5715, 'article_title': 'Meeting of the Royal Geographical Society', 'full_section_title': 'Meeting of the Royal Geographical Society', 'last_edit_date': '06-25-1888', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1888#article-10', 'issue_date': '02_07_1888', 'content': 'Complying, Sir Francis said the paper was entitled "A Brief Account of my Explorations in Central Africa." The author commenced by saying that he proposed to place before his audience certain facts illustrative of one of the most urgent questions of the day—namely, the influence of the Arab traders in Central Africa. He invited his hearers to accompany him into a region of Central Africa unknown to Arabs and Europeans until 1881. That region was bounded by the Sankuru and the Lomami, the former of which was first crossed by Dr. Pogge and himself, and the latter was first made known through Commander Cameron. This region was inhabited by the Bene Ki, a division of the Basonge. One day in January 1882 he and his party found themselves encamped near the western entrance of a large city, which happened to be occupied by the clan of the Bagna Pesihi. Dr. Pogge, himself, and the black interpreter mounted their oxen and started. With their followers, men and women, they marched along—a procession 200 in number. Glades on either side afforded glimpses of the homesteads of the Bagna Pesihi. There were gardens in front, where wild hemp, tobacco, tomatoes, red pepper, gourds, bananas, sugar cane, and various medicinal plants were cultivated. Pot-bellied goats, with short legs, sheep, and fowls, moved about in all directions. The day of their visit was quite an "event." To the natives they were "two white men from the unknown country where the sun does not set, riding on strange animals." Rumour said they were sons of the spirit Bena Kalunga. The people, full of expectancy, gathered about the doors, and silence reigned around. Clearly the natives were not quite free from apprehension. As the procession moved along Lieutenant Wissmann shouted, "Arms down; no war," and all distrust was soon removed. They camped at the other end of the town, and between 4,000 and 5,000 Bagna Pesihi visited them, desirous of trading. No discord occurred, and the party presently left the gentle, cheerful savages. Four years later Lieutenant Wissmann again visited the district; but what a change was there! All was silent and solitary, grass grew in the streets, and skulls and human bones lay about. The Bakalanga, with the long white garments, had been there, and they had devastated the district. Then famine and small-pox had come to complete the work. How, asked Lieutenant Wissmann, could these regions be made to participate in the blessings of civilization? The work would require large means, but it was a noble work. It must be undertaken quickly.

Subsequently the Chairman said Sir F. de Winton would make a statement about what he knew, or what he thought probable, regarding the present position of Mr. Stanley. Sir Francis was in a position to speak, perhaps, more authoritatively than any other man.'}, {'id': 6802, 'article_title': 'GERMAN EXPLORATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'GERMAN EXPLORATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1897#article-10', 'issue_date': '04_01_1897', 'content': 'Messrs. Esser and Hoesch, who left Lisbon for the Cameroons and Angola last May, returned at the end of November. Their companion, Dr. Zintgraff, remained in the Cameroons to superintend their cocoa plantations at the foot of the Cameroons Peak, near Port Victoria, having studied the cultivation of cocoa in the Island of St. Thome before going to the Cameroons. Their labourers will be supplied by the King and chieftains of the Balis.

Esser and Hoesch went *via* Loanda to Mossamedes, and then to the interior of Portuguese Angola, which is separated from German territory by the River Kunene. They had fifty armed blacks and a large number of oxen and camels. From Mossamedes they marched to Port Alexander, through the Chella Mountains, to Humbe, and then through swamps, but which were then tolerably dry, to Kitere, whence they returned down the Kunene to its mouth. They found the country literally swarming with lions, elephants, leopards, giraffes, buffalos, antelopes, gnus, hippopotami, crocodiles, pigeons, ducks, flamingoes, parrots, &c. They discovered unmistakeable traces of gold on the Olchitanda, in Cassinga, and on both sides of the Kunene, the banks of which they describe as very healthy. They infer that a very brisk weapon trade with the natives of German South-West Africa is carried on on the Kunene, from the fact that the Natives wanted to buy ammunition of them, with oxen, "for the war with the Germans"—a desire which, of course, remains ungratified. The travellers discovered a small and, hitherto, unknown bay, three kilometres broad, about thirty kilometres south of the mouth of the Kunene, and named it the Augusta Victoria Bay, after the German Empress. It seems to be well fitted for a harbour, as its southern headland is high enough to resist the current from the south-east, and ends in a chain of huge rocks visible when the tide is out, and forming a fine natural breakwater.'}]

[{'document_title': 'FRENCH AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Abbé Debaize, in charge of the French Expedition sent to Africa, has written to the Director of the Paris Observatory a most interesting letter, full of curious details, concerning the "Dark Continent," and the various expeditions which are now exploring it. The letter is dated from Kuihara, near Taboza, and was written on the 17th of October. The Abbé Debaize naturally begins with his own expedition, which had so far been successful. He says: "Yesterday the caravan of the French Expedition, with flags flying and music playing, entered Kouikouron, the capital of Unyanyembe. The most sympathetic reception was given to us by the thousands of negroes who gathered round us. The Sultan and the Governor came out to receive us at the entrance to the capital, and conducted us to a vast building, the same as was given to Cameron when he passed here. So far, my journey has been most fortunate, and I am proud to say, for the honour of the Government of the Republic, that the French Expedition promises to be a great success. Of the five hundred men forming my caravan not one has deserted, and I have not lost a single thing. From Zanzibar to the present spot I have not ceased to enjoy perfect health."

The other expeditions do not appear to be so well favoured. The Abbé Debaize alludes to two in particular—namely, the Belgian Expedition and that of the Missionary Fathers of Algeria. As regards the Belgians, he says: "They have experienced troubles of all kinds. At Meromero a revolt broke out in their camp. Two hundred and eighty of their men abandoned them, carrying off with them a quantity of valuable goods. At Mpuapona one of their Zanzibar men was wounded by a native.
[APRIL 1, 1879.]

---

To avenge him, they killed five of the inhabitants. The whole of the country rose, and war was imminent. The English were obliged to interfere to put an end to the affair. On arriving at Crumbo, the remainder of the men of the Belgian caravan deserted; fresh servants had to be found, and at length the Expedition reached Mirambo, but almost ruined. The missionaries from Algeria, who are going to establish stations on Lake Tanganyika and in the Uganda country, have not been more fortunate than the Belgians. They had to pay a ruinous sum for the right to pass through the Ugogo. They were abandoned by their native servants, and, in addition, attacked by a band of brigands, who stole several valuable chests from them.
