[{'id': 170, 'article_title': 'The Merits of the Ashantee War', 'full_section_title': 'The Merits of the Ashantee War', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1863#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_06_1863', 'content': 'Under the above title, we have received the following from a most esteemed correspondent on the West Coast. It is valuable for history of the war, because it seems to show both sides of the question with great impartiality:—

"The ostensible cause of the war is the detention by the British authorities of the runaway captain and eight men from Ashantee, who took refuge in the protected territory. The King of Ashantee was determined to have this man given up to him; but the conditions required by his Excellency Governor Pine, which were just and humane, the King of Ashantee was unable to comply with. Viewing the case impartially, one is led to conclude that both parties are justified in what they have done—the Governor for protecting the man, and the King for declaring war by crossing the Prah, the boundary of the respective territories.

"The Governor is perfectly justified, because, according to the British law, a refugee who cannot be proved to have committed any crime, and who claims protection from our Government, cannot legally be delivered up to a tyrant or a despotic Government, where will is arbitrary in actions. It is well known that the life of these men, if they had been delivered up, would have been sacrificed. No sooner would they have crossed the frontier, than their heads would have been taken off and sent to the King of Ashantee at Comassie. No mercy would be shown to them, and no promise of sparing their lives that might be made to the Governor would be worthy of the least consideration.

"The King is right in declaring war, because—

"Firstly, the very throne on which he sits is at stake. Should he not have acted promptly in this affair, his people would have branded him as a coward unworthy to occupy the stool of the long-famed and brave Kings of Ashantee.

"Secondly, should he have allowed the refugees to remain quietly with us, without making any demonstration regarding them, more important men would also have soon crossed from his territory to seek protection and security under the quiet rule of our Government. It behoved the King, therefore, to show that they could not do this with impunity.

"Thirdly, the peaceful traders of the King of Ashantee had, before there was any commencement of war by him, been molested by the Fantees, their goods seized, and the men themselves put in irons. They were only released by order of Governor Pine, and no compensation was given to them.

"Fourthly, the King of Ashantee's generals and captains will, on such an occasion, swear the great oath—viz., that the King has received an unpardonable insult, and that they are determined to avenge it. They will swear to perform certain exploits, and, on being permitted, will raise and march with a large army in an almost incredibly short time.'}, {'id': 170, 'article_title': 'The Merits of the Ashantee War', 'full_section_title': 'The Merits of the Ashantee War', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1863#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_06_1863', 'content': '"From the foregoing it seems to me that the Governor could not do otherwise than retain the men who had sought protection with him, and that the King of Ashantee could not do otherwise than follow up his demand of their restitution, by war."

* We have been informed that the King would have given ample time for negotiation, if the followers of the captain, whose lives might have been secured, had been sent back to Ashantee. But we do not know that this is correct. [Ed. A. T.]'}, {'id': 1451, 'article_title': "The King of Ashantee's Message", 'full_section_title': "The King of Ashantee's Message", 'last_edit_date': '10-06-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1868#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_11_1868', 'content': 'We are sent by the great King of Ashantee to you with a message for the Kings Quasie Fram of Denkerah, Chibboo of Assin, and Eddoo of Fantee. The King said that he had heard a few months ago that these kings had gone and invaded the town of Elmina; the King, wishing to be merciful, he has forgiven them this time. He has heard that they are preparing to make another attack upon that town again. That the moment they move against Elmina he would march down his troops, with a drawn sword in his own hands, and drive the Denkerahs and Fantees into the sea. These messengers proceeded further to state that the King upon two occasions sent his traders to Mr. Blankson, of Anamaboe, to purchase some silks and other goods. The Assins wantonly seized the whole of the gold and detained the men, and up to this day he has not seen a vestige of any of them, and was very much surprised indeed to hear that one of his court criers, amongst the lost messengers, had hung himself, and why not all the messengers hung themselves the same way?

That the kings of Denkerah in former days did receive stipends from the Dutch Government, that Quaskie Fram, the present King of Denkerah, knows very well that these kings have been beaten down and routed by him, and after they had been subdued by the great King of Ashantee and his successors, the stipends that they did receive from the Dutch Government recoiled to him. That the King of Denkerah knows that the same power which subdued and ruled his ancestors is still in existence, and how dared he to attempt to stop the path by which he sends to receive his stipend (annual), and to stop his people from trading as to preventing him from getting access to the place where he eats his salt, drinks his, &c.

2. That if the Fantees and Assins do not return to him the seizure they made of 200 ounces of gold and sixty men that they had detained and plundered within thirty days from the day they arrived here, he, the King, determined to rise from his stool and take his revenge upon them, and drive them into the sea. In conclusion, the King, to show that he was in earnest in what he has said, swore upon all that was sacred to him (then he named different oaths they have in Coomassie). The first ambassador, after delivering this message, said that "the King made me swear that I will not omit one word out of the message he gave me."'}, {'id': 1452, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST', 'last_edit_date': '10-17-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1868#article-7', 'issue_date': '23_11_1868', 'content': "Sir,—You heard hastily by last mail of the King of Ashantee's message—the demand of 200 ounces of gold, cessation of hostilities against Elmina, or the threat of war in a month. The Fantees laugh at the demand, and so I suppose we shall now really have war. The young King is compelled to distinguish himself, and therefore we shall have another Ashantee invasion. There is no one here in authority fit to meet such a crisis. Will not the Government send out a good and efficient man? Sir Arthur Kennedy is, however, I hear, expected down almost immediately, and we hope and believe that will be the commencement of a new era.

With regard to the threatened and seemingly-intended Ashantee invasion, my own belief is that the King has been encouraged in his design of distinguishing himself in this quarter (and thus giving eclat to his recently commenced reign) by the tenor of a letter said to have been written by Ussher, wherein it is stated that he gives the King to understand that he would not help the Fantees, and that he must look to them for redress for any wrongs he may have to complain of. Will order come out of this chaos?—Yours truly,"}, {'id': 2026, 'article_title': 'ASHANTI PEACE NEGOTIATIONS.', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTI PEACE NEGOTIATIONS.', 'last_edit_date': '03-14-1871', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1871#article-7', 'issue_date': '24_04_1871', 'content': 'the message that he has forwarded, and is he determined on peace? The following facts go very much against it: First, he said not a word about the European prisoners he has in Coomassie; secondly, it is said that he is forwarding reinforcements to the army of Oduborfor, or Addoo Boffoe, against the Creepees and Agotims; thirdly, rumour is current that he is about to forward a large army to assist Amekie, and place him again on the throne of Appolonia; fourthly, in the letter of the King there is nothing definite about peace negotiation. But the King of Ashanti may be determined on peace—first, because his kingdom is nearly exhausted, through the continuance of war, from the great difficulty he has of receiving supplies from the coast; secondly, because Jelly Coffee has declared against him, and has closed its port against the army of Ashanti now in Creepi and Agotim; thirdly, because he has lost a great many of the best blood of Ashanti in this continual warfare, which has greatly reduced the male population of the country; fourthly, because there is a general cry for peace among his population, which must be heard; and last, but by no means the least, because his principal chiefs are becoming very rebellious, refusing to pay the accustomed tax and to obey the orders to repair to the capital.

A CORRESPONDENT.'}, {'id': 2216, 'article_title': 'West African News', 'full_section_title': 'West African News', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1872#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1872', 'content': 'The Africa and the Volta steamers arrived at Liverpool, within a few hours of each other, on the night of the 14th and morning of the 15th inst.

**OLD CALABAR.**—It is stated there has been a serious gunpowder explosion here, but the details have not yet reached us.

**ACCRA.**—There have been several shocks of earthquake here.

**ASHANTI.**—There are rumours of a civil war having commenced at Kumasi, the capital. The withdrawal of the Dutch from the sea-coast, and the organisation of the Fanti Confederation, rendering it impossible for the Ashantis to make any more successful attacks on the Fanti countries, are very likely to set them fighting among themselves; and we look forward to such a change in Ashanti as will allow civilizing influences to obtain an entry into that valuable country.'}, {'id': 2749, 'article_title': 'Revolt in Ashanti', 'full_section_title': 'Revolt in Ashanti', 'last_edit_date': '07-19-1874', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_08_1874#article-5', 'issue_date': '29_08_1874', 'content': "On the 10th inst. a messenger arrived from the King of Ashanti to the Administrator, to inform him that the Kings of Juabin and Becqueh were in revolt, and refused to attend Calcali's summons to view his return to the capital, and, further, that they threatened to attack him if he attempted to use force. The King of Ashanti therefore sent down to the Administrator, asking for his interference, as peace was what he wanted; and this attack, if carried out, would possibly introduce a lengthy war, and effectually destroy trade. It was further rumoured, and with some truth, that the Protectorate Chiefs of Akim and Denkera had eaten fetish with the revolted kings to assist them in the struggle, thus producing a most complicated state of affairs. The Administrator questioned the ambassadors who are staying here, and, after a good deal of fencing on their part, drew from them that which led him to think the King of Ashanti had been endeavouring to put some pressure on Juabin and Becqueh, thus bringing about the present crisis. The Administrator at once sent Captain Lees to Kumasi, to act as peacemaker between the two tribes, and so prevent the threatened outbreak."}, {'id': 6643, 'article_title': 'Great Britain and Ashanti in the Past', 'full_section_title': 'Great Britain and Ashanti in the Past', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1895#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_11_1895', 'content': '

The foregoing is a brief sketch of our connexion with the Ashantees until the beginning of the complications which resulted in the despatch of the expedition under Sir Garnet Wolseley. These date actually from 1870, when negotiations were pending for the transference of the Dutch possessions on the Gold Coast to the British. The King of Ashanti, Koffe Kalkalli, wrote, objecting to the transfer of Elmina, for which, he alleged, tribute had been paid to his ancestors. The agent of the Dutch Government repudiated the claim as "entirely without foundation," but the British representatives refused to proceed further until the Dutch put their title beyond dispute. This having been done, the Treaty was concluded, and the ratifications exchanged in Feb. 1872. In April 1872 the Dutch Commodore wrote to the King, informing him of what had taken place, and requesting him to hand over to the English certain missionaries he held captive in his country. Mr. Pope Hennessy, the Governor, also communicated with the King, telling him that out of the friendship he had for him and his people he had ordered all the trading communications with Ashanti to be opened, and offered to pay double the sum received annually from the Dutch. A long correspondence ensued with regard to the missionaries, for whom a ransom was demanded. While the negotiations were progressing the King was secretly preparing for war, and, on Jan. 22, 1873, a large Ashanti army crossed the Prah and invaded the British Protectorate. The whole of the available Houssa Police were hastily mobilised, and arrangements made for the issue of arms and ammunition to the Fanti Kings. But the tribes could not be brought into line. They were most discouraging material of which to form an army. The Governor urged upon them the necessity for co-operation, as there could be no doubt that all their efforts would be required to arrest the progress of the hordes of the enemy which were at their gates. Reinforcements of troops were drawn from Sierra Leone; but their numbers were but small. Meanwhile the people were in a most distressing state of panic. At last the allied tribes, finding the Ashanti legions upon them, were induced to show fight, and eventually succeeded in holding the foe in check, but nothing could persuade them to follow up their success by an attack. Gaining courage by this the Ashantees moved forward and struck a blow at the Fanti camp. The Fantees managed to hold their own, and the Ashantees achieved no advantage. The cowardice of the allied tribes is almost incomprehensible. In two battles they had not sustained a defeat; if anything the fortunes of the day were in their favour; yet in a few days, they were in full retreat to the Coast. The break-up of the Fanti Army caused the utmost consternation at Cape Coast. The Administrator ordered that a gunboat should be sent to Elmina, as that fort was the principal settlement in the territory they were anxious to repossess, and the loss of which they had never been able to forget. The Ashantees, however, contented themselves by concentrating at a central camp at Dunquah, where they remained until the middle of May. The efforts to reorganise the Fanti tribes proved unsuccessful, and the home Government decided upon despatching such an expedition as would once and for all establish the sovereignty of the British on the Coast. Sir Garnet Wolseley was sent for, and he advised the despatch of an European force, but the Government were unwilling to launch British troops without previous inquiry into a country which was sometimes called "the white man's grave." On June 9, a body of Marines, under Colonel Festing, was landed. This officer at once assumed command of the Forces, and, collecting all the available material, he advanced upon Ashanti camp and succeeded in driving the army over the Prah, with which he contented himself pending the arrival of fresh troops. The passages of the river were held, and every move of the enemy noted. By this time Sir Garnet had been despatched from England to Cape Coast Castle, constituted Commander of the Forces and Administrator of the Gold Coast. On his arrival he was more than ever convinced that European troops would be the best with which to undertake the mission he was charged with, and the troops he had asked for were sent out. This force, which consisted of three battalions of Infantry with some Royal Engineers and Royal Artillery and Administrative Services, were landed at Cape Coast Castle on Jan. 1, 1874, and on Feb. 4 arrived at Coomassie, having fought several battles on the way, and literally cut a passage through the dense brush and jungle. In addition there were two Native regiments which did excellent service, as also the Marines, Houssas, and West Indians. The Native levies that were raised by Captain Glover, R.N., on the Eastern side of the Protectorate proved quite unreliable. The greatest difficulties of the campaign arose from the almost complete lack of information that existed of the nature or topography of the country and although twenty-one years have since elapsed, but little has been added to the knowledge gained during the progress to Coomassie and the return to the Coast.'}, {'id': 6698, 'article_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION.', 'full_section_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_02_1896#article-1', 'issue_date': '03_02_1896', 'content': "The fighting column left the encampment on the banks of the river Adra at 6 o'clock on Jan. 17, and entered the capital without opposition. Major Baden Powell's levies entered Coomassie simultaneously with the main body, while the detachment of Houssas and levies under Major Gordon, entered the town from the east. As the various contingents of the force entered Coomassie they formed up in the palaver square, and there awaited the rest of the column. Sir Francis Scott, attended by his staff, arrived at 12 o'clock. King Prempeh, surrounded by his chiefs, was seated on one side of the square and made no manifestations of any kind while the troops formed up and lined the square. The Native levies, amid cheers from the troops, marched off to their respective stations. John and Albert Ansah, the envoys who recently returned from England, carried messages backwards and forwards between the King and Sir Francis Scott. They wore European dress. Except for the constant beating of drums the populace made no demonstration.

At five o'clock a palaver was held, Sir Francis Scott and staff being seated in a semicircle. The Ashanti chiefs were paraded before the Commander-in-Chief. King Prempeh then descended from his stool and shook hands with Sir Francis Scott, who informed him that Mr. Maxwell, the Governor, would arrive to-morrow, and that it would be necessary to arrange at once for the holding of a grand palaver. Sir Francis also told the King that he must clear the streets and keep the people quiet. The meeting then dispersed. The Queen Mother shortly afterwards arrived and gave in her submission to the Commander-in-Chief.

The Governor, Mr. Maxwell, arrived in the town at midday on Jan. 18. His Excellency was met outside the town by Sir Francis Scott and staff. The British troops were formed up in square and saluted the flag, the artillery afterwards firing a Royal salute. The whole ceremony was an impressive one."}]

[{'document_title': 'GOLD COAST', 'section_title': '', 'content': "It is not unlikely that ere this time you have received information about the pending danger which threatens this coast. We have for the last three months been anticipating what, to all intents and purposes, will prove a reality—viz., a war with the King of Ashantee. In November last, one of the captains of the King being ordered up to Comasie, on a charge of robbing what is regarded as the King's quota of gold, and being apprehensive that the issue would cost his head, escaped with eighty adherents from the kingdom of Ashantee to the coast, and claimed protection from the English Government. The King immediately sent one of his principal chieftains, with a number of sword-bearers, to request that the captain and his men should be given up. On his arrival at Cape Coast Castle a grand palaver was held, in which were present the Governor and Council, the principal merchants at Cape Coast and its vicinity, the chiefs and head men of Cape Coast, the runaway chief, as well as the King's messengers. After a long palaver, the last were unable to substantiate the charges against the man, who swore that he would rather have his head cut off before the fort gate than that he should be sent up to Comasie. After long deliberation it was unanimously agreed that the captain and his followers were not to be delivered up until the King should send down witnesses to corroborate the charges alleged against him. The King demanded that the men should be delivered up unconditionally; or, if not, the Governor must stand the consequence. During this time it was noticed that Ashantees, who came down as peaceful traders, bought almost wholly guns, powder, and lead bar, articles which are decidedly munitions of war. The chiefs in the interior got alarmed at this, and seized the articles as the men passed along their territory. Intelligence of this reached Comasie, and from that time the King gave orders to his captains to make preparations for an invasion. In the meantime the King sent to inform the Governor that he had broken the treaty with his Government, and that he (the King) was going to send down one of his captains, who was then in the interior, to show the Governor the treaty. The Governor promised, whenever that should be done, to deliver the captain up, and even escort him to the frontiers of the King of Ashantee with British soldiers. The next information that reached the coast was that a large Ashantee army had crossed the river Prah (the boundary line between the protectorate territory and the kingdom of his Majesty King Quaku Duah) towards the eastern district, and that the King of Akim had fallen back before them to get the support of the tribes on the seashore. A few days afterwards another army crossed the Prah at Assin, in a direct road to Anamaboe and Cape Coast. Most of the men on the seacoast who are able to bear arms have left for the Fantee camp, at the neighbourhood of Assin, where at least about 14,000 men are at present, waiting the movements of the Ashantees. Scouts have been sent out, and some Ashantee heads have been sent down, to corroborate the report that the Ashantees have invaded the Fantee territory. The report is just now current that pickets of the army of Ajeman, King of Western Akim, met an Ashantee pillaging band, fired at them, and wounded their leader, who was brought before the King as a prisoner. He begged hard for his life, and promised to reveal everything about the war. He was made to swear by his King's stool that all that he was about to say were facts. The information he gave was the following: The King, on hearing that the Governor refused to deliver up the men, turned out all the available force, numbering about 60,000 men. Of these, 20,000 were to form a corps of observation on the eastern district, by descending on Akim, and thus preventing the Accras, Aquamhus, and Akims from joining the Fantees, and the remaining 40,000 were to descend upon the Fantees through Assin, sweeping everything before them, until they arrive at Cape Coast and Anamaboe, both of which places they intend to sack; the victorious were then to march against the Accras. So that, perhaps before you receive this account, we might all have been massacred by these brutal Ashantees; but we are determined to give them a most hearty reception.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MANŒUVRES OF THE ASHANTEE GOVERNMENT', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"A friend of mine knew of the warlike intentions of the Ashantees against Krepee as long ago as December, 1865. An Ashantee trader, to whom he had shown some kindness, informed him that although the new King of Ashantee had at first refused the application of the King of Aquamboe to aid him in subjugating the Krepees, he had then very recently given his consent. Upon this it was determined by the Ashantee monarch to seek some early cause of quarrel with the Krepees, by sending Ashantees thither in the guise of traders, with instructions to take umbrage at any trifling thing that could by any means be worked up into a quarrel."', 'last_edit_date': '1870-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1870#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Ashantee Peace Negotiations—Extradition of the Refugee Gaynin', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We inserted some months ago, on authority, that peace with Ashantee had been arranged and secured. It had, indeed, under the new aspect of affairs in the protected territories, consequent upon the late Ashantee war, the recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee and the resolves of the Colonial-office, become an _absolute duty_ on the part of Great Britain to arrive at such an understanding with the King of Ashantee as should serve to place the relations between Ashantee and the kingdoms and tribes in the protectorate on the same footing as they were before the war. England having determined that she would not in future take part in any campaign against the Ashantees further than by affording some advice, arms, and ammunition to the Fantees and other tribes of the protectorate who might be involved in war with that people, it became indispensable to put an end to all existing causes of quarrel, which might otherwise afford a reason or a pretext for a new invasion. During the last year of the late war, the natives in the protectorate maintained on all occasions that it was not a war between them and Ashantee, but was a white man's palaver—a dispute between the King of Ashantee and the Governor of Cape Coast, through whom they were involved in it. We presume that it is on this ground the present administration at Cape Coast, in endeavoring to bring about pacific relations with Ashantee has thought it right and proper to conduct the negotiations without making the kings and chiefs parties to them. The proceedings have, therefore, we suppose, been, as our correspondent states, "shrouded in mystery;" and it appears the peace negotiations have been more protracted than the chief authorities at Cape Coast Castle had anticipated. Since we made the publication above alluded to, accompanied with a copy of the official proclamation, messengers and messages have passed and repassed between Cape Coast and Comassie, the latest messenger who lately made his appearance on the coast having with him a retinue of 100 men. What could this mean? Colonel Conran was so secret in his words and resolves that not the smallest suspicion of the real state of affairs seems to have been entertained. Suddenly, however, one "Gaynin" was arrested and secured, and it was made known that he was to be sent off to Sierra Leone by the next mail steamer, which was subsequently effected. At Sierra Leone he was to be allowed 1s. 9d. per diem for subsistence. This "Gaynin" was the chief alleged cause of the Ashantee invasion. He was a subject of the King of Ashantee, accused of having appropriated to his own use a lump of gold, all lump gold belonging of right to the King. Summoned to Comassie to give an account of this, he believed his life to be in danger, and sought refuge at Cape Coast. The King of Ashantee demanded him; the Governor refused to give him up; other grievances raised their heads; and the war ensued so big with results for the protectorate. From what has now occurred, it appears that the King of Ashantee, with the obstinacy which characterises the sovereigns of that country, has continued to urge the surrender of "Gaynin" as the absolutely indispensable condition of peace relations. This has, no doubt, led to the proposal by the Administrator of a medium course, namely—that he should be sent away from Cape Coast, his presence there being offensive to his late sovereign. We presume, further, that this more moderate course has been acceptable to his Majesty of Ashantee, and think it extremely probable that, as our correspondents suggest, the envoy with his escort of 100 came to Cape Coast that he might assure his master of the fact of "Gaynin" having been embarked for Sierra Leone.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1866#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Pretensions and Threats of Ashantee', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—You will perhaps be surprised to hear of the most insulting message which the King of Ashantee has sent to the Fantee kings, through Mr. Simpson, the Acting Administrator. I send it you enclosed. The messengers were six in number, besides a few carriers. They arrived here on the 5th inst., and as soon as this message was delivered, Mr. Simpson promised them that he would send for the kings and chiefs or for their deputations to receive the message. The words of this message certainly had their origin at Government-house, for since my existence I never heard any such message from the kings of Ashantee. The Fantees have had several incursions against', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1868#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Common-sense View of the Ashanti War Scare', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following admirable letter appeared in the Times of the 26th February. To our own knowledge, this letter embodies the exact position of affairs. Both we and Messrs. Swanzy may be mistaken if it be true, as often asserted, that "there is nothing certain but the impossible;" but we are certainly justified in believing that the axe was an idle threat, and will not have been followed by any of the consequences that have been so readily assumed.—Ed. A. T.

To the Editor of the Times.

Sir,—We think too much importance has been attached to the message lately received by the Lieutenant-Governor of the Gold Coast from the King of Ashanti. The telegrams have led many to believe that the Ashantees were within three days' march of Cape Coast Castle, and that the colony was in imminent danger. It has also been stated that the gold mining districts were likely to be the first invaded. We have agents at all the principal places, and, as we receive the most reliable information, we think it right to assure the public through you that we consider that there is not at present any serious cause for alarm. When the Lieutenant-Governor refused to give up the fugitive, he was informed by the King's messenger that he must take the consequences. We hardly think it follows that because the gold axe was sent an invasion of the colony was intended. The Ashantees have enough to do to hold their own, and should they leave their country it would probably be overrun by other tribes. The force that can be brought into the field against us has been grossly exaggerated. It has been computed at 90,000 men, and the same informant states that the King has been recruiting on a large scale to obtain this force. All those acquainted with the Gold Coast are aware that there is no recruiting in the Ashantee kingdom. The King is a despot, and when he makes war every able-bodied man has

abandon peaceful pursuits and join the undisciplined army. We are advised that the Ashantees desire in the first instance to crush the Adansees, who occupy the country immediately beyond our frontier at Prahsue. They would then have to overpower the Assins before advancing into the colony, and if they really contemplate so foolish a step, it would take some time for them to defeat the Assins, who are supported by our outposts.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-02-26', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ASHANTEE WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I am certain—viz., that the King of Ashantee will never agree to pay the indemnification required by the Government, unless induced by his kingdom being placed in our hands after a bloody engagement. The only thing, in my opinion, he would agree to, is to deposit in the chest at Cape Coast some 5,000l. or 6,000l., as a pledge that he will not disturb the Coast for the next ten or twenty years.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1864-01-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ASHANTEE SCHEMES.—TRIBES IN DANGER.—CRUEL GOVERNMENT MISTAKES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will not, therefore, surprise you to hear of his having sent the greater part of his troops on expedition against the interior tribes, and thinking, as the general notion in Ashanti, that their treacherous policy is still unknown by other nations, especially the Europeans, see how he sends his concerted scheme. On the 30th ultimo, a messenger arrived from King Mainza, alias Ossay Bonzo, of Ashanti, to the Lieutenant-Governor; as he was absent, on the 31st the messenger went to the Acting Colonial Secretary and delivered the following message: "My King sends his compliments to Governor, his good friend; he says, one of his revolted chiefs, Essandawah, of Insutah district, wishing to return to his former allegiance, sent to ask him, King, for ammunition to chase his own sister, who is the Queen of that district, and two sons, or rather nephews, of his, who have left and gone to Kraki because they would not go to Kumasi with him. The King had refused him ammunition; but since he sent to ask him to send a captain to take him to Kumasi, he, the King, has sent one of his captains to bring him to Kumasi; and because he fears someone may come and report him as going to war, he sends me to apprise the Governor." We have, therefore, now to wait a short time to hear the result of this from the interior. Still, I venture to hint to you the secret of this sending for the Chief of Insutah, who has no enemies between him and Kumasi to have necessitated a captain being sent to bring him.

You know, Mr. Editor, that as soon as the neighbouring tribes of Ashanti who had suffered so much the prestige of that kingdom, knew of Kumasi being set on fire, and the King's running away before Sir Garnet's troops, they all exhibited their enmity, and revenged themselves by killing all Ashantees who had gone among them, and did not wish to have anything further to do with that dynasty. When they saw that the King of Juabin also had thrown off his allegiance to it, they all then directed their course to him to join him in placing themselves under the British Government. If the attack made upon Juabin had been', 'last_edit_date': '1876-08-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Renewal of the Ashantee War', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The military department of this Coast are actively preparing to take the field against the King of Ashantee, who, about a few months ago, invaded our Protectorate. An encampment will first be made at Mansu, from which place the army will proceed to the Prah and build fortifications. The colonel commanding the troops (Colonel Conran) has divided the regular army into three divisions—the first division, under the command of Captain Mackay, 4th West India Regiment, to be accompanied by Staff Assistant-Surgeon Horton; the second division, under command of Captain Gabb, 4th West India Regiment, to be accompanied by Staff Assistant-Surgeon Steward; and the third division, under the command of Captain Thorne, also of the 4th West India Regiment, to be accompanied by Staff Assistant-Surgeon Gardiner.

To these divisions will be attached hereafter the local Militia, Volunteers, and native allies, numbering in all about 20,000 men, rendering each division about 7,000 strong. The staff of the 4th West India Regiment, including non-commissioned officers and band, will be attached to the first division as a general rule. From this you will perceive that we have commenced preparations in right good earnest, and that there is a fair prospect that the war will be prosecuted with vigour. But we need more troops.

The forts will be given over to the Navy during the campaign. There will be, for a time at least, three men-of-war at Cape Coast, one at Anamaboe, and another at Accra.

The detachments are being recalled to head-quarters, except that at Din Cane, and a day or two after the departure of the mail the first division will move for the camp.

It is reported that the King of Ashantee has moved from his capital, but I cannot vouch for the truth of the statement; one thing, however, is true—viz., that, at the assembling of his princes and chiefs in the late gathering, he swore, upon the valour of his ancestors, that no foreigners shall enter the Ashantee capital except as prisoners of war.

Deputy Commissary-General Blane arrived by the last mail from the Gambia to organise a land transport corps. Certain number of men have been received from each king, enrolled, and assigned a payment of 1s. 3d. per day. The system of the land transport corps is very good, but already there are complaints that the carriers are becoming refractory.

Two of the officers have been sent up to Mansu to prepare barracks for the men; their reports are not very favourable, the people having burnt down the old barracks on learning that the troops will move to that place. In fact, so much have things changed since last year, the war at present is very unpopular, and the inhabitants will not go into it with the same viras as they did during the last ill-managed campaign. Every one wants peace, and that trade should again be established; for this war will affect the credit of the principal merchants on the Coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-14', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'circumstances, of appointing a mere military man. Sir Samuel Rowe having had experience in those countries, having been at Coomassie with Sir John Glover, and shared, no doubt, with Sir John the disgust of not being allowed to remain there awhile and place the affairs of the countries beyond the Prah on a permanent peace footing, he knows the people with whom he has to deal, and has no more fear of an Ashantee than of any other untutored savage. Such a man, we hope, will see the necessity of something more than to be content that no invasion has taken place, or that it has been repulsed. It is not compatible with the dignity of the British Government, or with the duty of the latter to the countries under its protection, that the latter should remain liable to a repetition of the “Golden Axe” insult whenever it may suit a vain and ignorant barbarian to inflict it. Sir Samuel Rowe will, we hope, recognize the necessity, and make that necessity to be fully comprehended in Downing-street, that a definite line of policy must be adopted, and certain efficient measures be taken and maintained, as regards Ashanti and the other native States beyond the River Prah such as shall put an end for ever to the possibility of the recurrence of insulting threats, with their disturbing influence on industrial pursuits in the countries of the protectorate, and needless expense both to the Imperial and Colonial Exchequer. To give security to a country as well as to preserve peace and order in it, is one of the first duties of a sovereign power. This security the British Government must now give to the Fantee countries. We have made them dependent on us for protection, and we must make that protection efficient—not spasmodic, according to the varying humour of an insolent neighbouring barbarian, but constant and assured beyond the possibility of doubt. If it be said that the British Parliament, uninstructed by the fate of Old Rome, would not consent to any charge on the British Exchequer for any requisite measurer, then we say that the revenues of the protected territories, now not less than 100,000l. a year, are adequate for securing the interest on a public loan for the small amount that would be required. We have before contended that this revenue should be made available for guaranteeing railroads, and for other works of public improvement, that may aid in the development of the natural resources, vegetable and mineral, of those territories; but though we have the construction of railways there deeply at heart, we would postpone these and all other aids to industry in favour of that one great first aid without which all others are liable to fail in their object—security, perfect security, for life and property against the threat of barbarian invasion. We venture to hope that Sir Samuel Rowe will be the instrument through whom this great aid will be obtained. For ages past Ashanti has been the curse of all neighbouring countries. It was delivered into our hands in 1873-4 for destruction, and we failed in our duty, allowed it to be revived, and again to become insolent, and are now suffering the temporary disturbance of important industries, and compelled to incur considerable expense, because of that insolence. The line must be drawn somewhere; let it be drawn at the late “Golden Axe” menace; and then, within a few years, our great expectations of national wealth to come from those territories will be realized.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ASHANTI WAR OPERATIONS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'explicit and urgent directions for the protection of health. It then explains the Ashantee tactics, and how they are to be met; the troops being assured that, with their breech-loaders, every man of them is a match for twenty Ashantees. The order speaks encouragingly of the climate of the interior, and assures the men that the operations beyond the Prah will last only a few weeks. It concludes as follows: "When once a position has been gained, it is to be held resolutely. In warfare of this nature, there must be no retreats. No village or camp is to be set on fire except by order of the major-general commanding; officers and men are reminded of the danger and delay which occur if a village is set on fire before all the ammunition and baggage have made their way through it. All plundering and unnecessary destruction of property are to be strictly repressed; officers are to be strictly responsible that, when a village or camp is occupied, their men are kept together, and prevented from dispersing to seek plunder. The importance of kindness from all ranks to the friendly natives, who are employed as carriers, is strongly urged: if the carriers are ill-treated, the troops run imminent risk of being left without food and ammunition. It must never be forgotten by the soldiers that Providence has implanted in the heart of every native of Africa a superstitious awe and dread of the white man, that prevents the negro from daring to meet him face to face in combat. A steady advance or a charge, no matter how partial, if made with determination, always means the retreat of the enemy. Although, when at a distance, and even when under a heavy fire, the Ashantees seem brave enough, from their practice of yelling and singing and beating drums in order to frighten the enemies of their own colour with whom they are accustomed to make war, they will not stand against the advance of the white man. English soldiers and sailors are accustomed to fight against immense odds in all parts of the world. It is scarcely necessary to remind them that when in our battles beyond the Prah they find themselves surrounded on all sides by hordes of howling enemies, they must rely upon their old British courage and discipline, and upon the courage of their comrades. Soldiers and sailors, remember that the black man holds you in superstitious awe. Be cool; fire low, fire slow, and charge home; and the more numerous your enemy, the greater will be the loss inflicted upon him, and the greater your honour in defeating him."', 'last_edit_date': '1874-12-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_01_1874#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Good Relations with Ashantee: How to Restore and Maintain them', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following suggestions on this important subject have been made by one long resident on the Gold Coast. Peace relations with Ashantee and a constantly open trade are of vital moment as regards revenue and the general well-being of the Protectorate, and we readily insert the following, as we should any other suggestions emanating from similar sources. We shall examine the practicability of this and other suggestions on another occasion:—

"It is only by constant and frequent communication with Ashantee and other barbarous tribes that we can hope to bring about that state of things that will redound to the honour of England, and I have often wondered why the chief of the executive here has not attempted some effective means for this end. I would suggest the following: Let a well-paid consular agent be stationed at Kumasi,* with Prince Ansah† as interpreter; let their salary be in keeping with England's dignity, and I imagine schools and other missionary work would then commence in earnest in Ashantee. But it would be necessary that the King should also be induced to send us a consul or agent, who ought to be well treated, and made acquainted with the refinements of European life. He should not be an ordinary chief or captain, but one of Ashantee's nobles, because there are many there. With this guarantee here, our Administrator could with every safety visit Ashantee, and display, in a dignified and graceful manner, the refined customs of Europe. The Africans are very imitative, and, depend upon it, good—real good—would be the result, such good as would outweigh 5,000l. per annum, if expended in the manner it ought to be. Let a trial be made for five years, and mark the result.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1867-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1867#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: The collective action and organization among diverse African communities, influenced by Western education and local leadership, played a crucial role in addressing colonial grievances and advancing regional development.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the pivotal role of collective action and organization among diverse African communities, influenced by Western education and local leadership, in addressing colonial grievances and advancing regional development. The textbook highlights the formation of clubs and associations, such as the Aborigines Rights Protection Society (ARPS) and the Young Senegalese Club, which exemplify how educated Africans leveraged Western tools like newspapers and pamphlets to protest colonial abuses. This reflects the influence of Western education and the emergence of an educated elite, largely due to missionary and colonial educational efforts, equipping Africans with the literacy and knowledge necessary to engage with colonial powers. Pan-Africanist organizations and figures like W. E. B. Du Bois and Marcus Garvey further fostered connections between African and American black communities, influencing regional development and anti-colonial movements. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight the organized collective action of native societies and clubs, such as joiners, masons, and carpenters, who petitioned British authorities to annul ordinances, and the establishment of educational institutions like the Accra Church of England High-class School by native residents. These efforts demonstrate the influence of Western education and local leadership in advocating for rights and community development. However, both sources acknowledge the limitations and uneven impact of these efforts, as colonialism remained entrenched, and external factors like limited support from colonial governments and reliance on missionary education constrained these initiatives. Overall, the combined observations illustrate the significant, albeit varied, impact of collective action and Western-influenced leadership in addressing colonial grievances and promoting development across Africa.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that align with the claim regarding the role of collective action and organization among diverse African communities in addressing colonial grievances and advancing regional development. The articles highlight the efforts of native societies and clubs, such as those of joiners, masons, carpenters, and others, who petitioned the British authorities to annul an ordinance, demonstrating organized collective action to address grievances. Additionally, the articles discuss the influence of Western education, noting the presence of educated Africans who advocate for their rights and the development of their communities. The establishment of educational institutions, such as the Accra Church of England High-class School, initiated by native residents, further supports the claim of local leadership in advancing regional development. However, the articles also emphasize the challenges faced by these communities, such as the limited support from the British government and the reliance on missionary efforts for education, which suggests that while collective action and local leadership were crucial, they were often constrained by external factors. Overall, the articles provide evidence of both the potential and limitations of African communities' efforts in addressing colonial grievances and promoting development.

[{'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': 'African Reactions and Responses in West Africa, > Elite associations', 'content': "Many clubs and associations were also formed by the educated Africans mainly in the urban centres as vehicles for protest against the abuse and iniquities of colonial systems during this period. These associations used newspapers, plays, tracts and pamphlets as their main weapons.$^{7}$ ' Examples of such bodies, which acted as watch dogs of colonial rule, were the Aborigines Rights Protection Society (ARPS) formed in the Gold Coast in 1897, the Young Senegalese Club founded in 1910, and the Peoples Union and the Anti-Slavery and Aborigines Protection Society formed in Nigeria in 1908 and 1912 respectively. The ARPS was easily the most active. It was formed to protest against the Land Bill of 1896 which was to give control of all so-called waste or unoccupied lands to the government. As a result of a delegation it dispatched to London in 1898 which met the Secretary of State for Colonies, this obnoxious Bill was withdrawn. From then on, the ARPS sent a series of petitions to the local administration as well as the Colonial Office protesting against various projected Bills. It sent two delegations to England, one in 1906 to demand the repeal of the 1894 Towns Ordinance and the second in 1911 to oppose the Forestry Bill of 1910. It was certainly the most successful of the mouthpieces of the elite and traditional rulers of West Africa and the greatest opponent of colonialism until the formation of the National Congress of British West Africa after the First World War. In French West Africa, the Young Senegalese Club formed in 1910 also actively campaigned for equal rights.

(This Memorial bears the signatures of 270 persons, native merchants, traders, and others.)"}, {'id': 4765, 'article_title': 'Old Calabar', 'full_section_title': 'Old Calabar', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1884#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_01_1884', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—It may be questioned whether we, in this remote part of Africa, are not excluded altogether from enjoying any European influence calculated to better our condition. To distant people, we form one of the most intelligent and civilized portions of Africa, who, although not under a European Government, are enjoying as much of their influence as if we were born civilized. But to have a proper knowledge of the cotton tree, it is necessary to approach it more closely, when it will be discovered that it is full of thorns. This is the only way I can contrast what our country is with what it is considered to be. Our country is, undoubtedly, a great port for the palm-oil trade; and it appears to me that the only influence existing is that of raking and draining it of every speck of oil that could be got—and nothing more. Sordid avarice and insatiable gain is their only and chief aim. We own that we are poor, ignorant, heathen people, and, perhaps, vile savages too, as we are often styled; but we cannot feel more happy than when we have Europeans among us, whose goodness we feel proud to copy and imitate. I do not think that the days of contraband, when man formed the chief article of trade among us, were worse than ours—the period when lawful commerce takes the lead, and the Christian religion regulates its progress. Trade, from the way it is carried on, has a rather debasing effect on us; religion, from the stingy manner it is introduced and its principles engrafted, tends to steep us in a twofold ignorance, almost as dark as that in which it found us; so that the only improvement resulting from the advantage both of commerce and religion among us, at present, is a low cunning and a doggish reverence. People whose ears are accustomed to hear the fair carol of the wonderful improvement that has taken place in our country through European influence and missionary efforts, might be constrained to denounce my observations as a slander: but if they know the truly meaning of multum in parvo, and how it is unscrupulously practised by their agents abroad, I need not labour to convince them. I do not ignore the fact that faithful workers have from time to time been sent to our country, and that, through them, we should have been better; but the thing is this, those already in the field informed them, "When you go to Rome, do what Rome does." The merchant, whose only ambition is to hoard up all he could rake from the negro's hide, grins with pleasure and satisfaction at his wretchedness, contrives new methods of aggravating humanity, and uses all his subtle skill in advocating, if possible, the total extinction of the vague, glimmering twilight that shines around us; and the missionary, as a rule, teaches the black man hardly anything beyond the Bible, transcribed in his own tongue. In one of their conferences, held at Gaboon, the missionaries have decided not to give us and our children any intellectual training. We keenly feel the result of such selfishness, not only for ourselves, but for our children and children's children. How painful it is to think that there is not a single youth in our country who is capable of being more than a menial servant in any of the European establishments here! Why is it so different at Bonny, at New Calabar, at Brass, and throughout the Niger territory? It is thirty-six years ago now since a mission was planted in our midst; yet we do not present a brighter aspect than that of a dilapidated and neglected plantation. There is nothing of civilizing industry introduced into the country whereby to profit our youths; whereas in the Niger Mission—which is working exclusively by native agency, headed by its Bishop, and a grand train of clerical and lay assistants—industrial training is incorporated with the work. To every mission-station in the Niger is appended a first-class boarding-school, the pupils of which are fit to teach the teachers whom the Mission here laboured so arduously to produce. The Niger is able to furnish herself with a good staff of able and competent artisans, interpreters, clerks, and teachers; and is getting up a theological institution to train their own men. But here no such things are studied, although I am sure of their meeting the ready approval of our benefactors in Britain.'}]
