[{'id': 333, 'article_title': 'Wars among the Natives of the River Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'Wars among the Natives of the River Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-21', 'issue_date': '23_02_1864', 'content': 'Our informant, to whom we have alluded in our notice of the River Gambia, on our second page, writes in substance as follows, relative to those wars among the natives of the Gambia Districts, to which we have more than once alluded, and which have been generally represented as resulting from a Mohammedan propaganda by fire and sword:—

According to his version, the origin of this disturbance is to be found in the mismanagement of the late British war against the kingdom of Badiboo; and, therefore, that what seems now to occupy almost exclusively the heads, hearts, and hands of the Government, is traceable distinctly to their own acts. He seems to consider that the chief Mahabah is performing a duty which the Government neglected to do, and for doing which it envies the man who is really performing very important public services, and preparing the way for the progressive civilization of the country. That man, Mahabah, he says, is not seeking his own interests only, but that of all British subjects. British merchants have been without any real, efficient protection in the river of late years, and Mahabah has made a vast improvement in this respect during the last 24 months. It is true, he proceeds, that, partly owing to the war, and partly to the famine that prevailed during the rainy season, there has been a great deficiency of produce, "but it is far better to prepare the ground before sowing seed, than to sow it in unprepared soil." The Pagsoos, in this river, are a people that do not work, but who go about plundering those who do work; pillaging the merchants and traders, and committing many other and great enormities. They are, in fact, a lazy, predatory, and degraded people. The late war between the British and Badiboo was caused by such deeds as are above alluded to. The British effected really nothing, but Mahabah has made an entire change. These people, before so troublesome, having been brought by him under subjection, are now learning to depend on their own labour for the means of support; so that British merchants, who previously scarcely dared to commission any traders in that part, have now been able to find employment as traders there for those who have been (so arbitrarily, as he contends) dismissed from the Government service.'}, {'id': 1119, 'article_title': 'Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': '05-07-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_06_1867#article-4', 'issue_date': '22_06_1867', 'content': 'Governor Blackall has "settled" the Awoonlah palaver, and "made peace" with the Awoonlahs, without paying the slightest regard to any of the suggestions offered to him here; a peace made with our enemies without our concurrence or knowledge, or one farthing of indemnification, after the great losses by our traders in Krepee, and the almost ruinous expenses incurred by us during the war. The result is that we are all more and more convinced that the system which renders a reference to the Governor-in-chief at Sierra Leone requisite in all cases before any measure can be carried into effect, is one that tends very materially to retard the progress and injure the real interests of the settlements. It makes the Administrator simply an expensive shadow; and though I am perfectly aware that nothing that may be thought here on this subject will have the least weight with those at home who have the management of such matters, I see no harm in giving you the general opinion of the best informed and far-seeing portion of the community, European and native, on the Gold Coast. But as I wrote to you before, news having come—even while the Governor-General was yet here—that his peace was a sham, the Administrator has come down to Accra again to endeavour to carry out the views of the Governor-in-chief in regard to the settlement of the Awoonlah question. The course proposed now is that Mr. Ussher himself should proceed to Kpong or Assocharry on the Volta, with two or three of the merchants from Accra, and convene a meeting of the chiefs of the different tribes on both sides, with a view to an understanding that may put an end to the hostilities still being carried on in those parts.

I am a man of peace myself. My bread depends on peace being maintained, and if it could be obtained without further bloodshed no one would rejoice more than myself. But I have no faith in a peace thus concluded. A good sound thrashing by means of an expedition undertaken by the Government, at an expense of at the very utmost four or five hundred pounds, is the only way of bringing the hostile tribes of Aquamboe and Awoonlah to their senses, restoring permanent peace to the protectorate, and affording future governors leisure and opportunity to develop the resources of the country and effect improvements with the _twenty thousand a-year_ revenue, which they will derive as soon as the Dutch forts are handed over to the English.'}, {'id': 1168, 'article_title': 'Destructive Policy as regards the Eastern Districts', 'full_section_title': 'Destructive Policy as regards the Eastern Districts', 'last_edit_date': '06-06-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1867#article-7', 'issue_date': '23_08_1867', 'content': 'Sir,—The young man who has been placed at the head of affairs pro tem. by one of those extraordinary flukes which fall to the lot of only one or two very lucky men in a million, is bent on completing the ruin of the country, although there were most favourable opportunities of effecting good for it, and its hundreds of thousands of inhabitants. As your correspondents keep you pretty well informed of facts, I shall only give you the opinion entertained by all honest and independent men here, that not for a very long period has the political atmosphere had such a lowering aspect as at present. The tornado seems ready to burst over us, and should it do so, none can foretell the havoc it may make. The old trite adage comes into one's mind, "Quam cuit perdere Deus prius dementat," when reflecting on the thoughtless, headstrong, insane, suicidal policy now being pursued by the present Acting Administrator of these wretched settlements. His first acts after his accession to office led ordinary minds to indulge in hopes favourable for the country; but this was only a ruse, which deceived many others as well as myself. But some wary old birds shook their heads. "This," said they, "is only the old dodge; wait till he thinks he is seated firmly on his throne of office, and then see! And we do see! Mr. Usher seems to have desired, by a show of frankness, and wishing good for the country, to conciliate the goodwill of the natives and those Europeans who had been many years in the country, and who, having gained the respect and confidence of the natives, could by persuasion induce them to do much more than any Administrator could succeed in effecting by force.

He flattered himself that he could thus succeed in inducing the native chiefs and people of the Eastern districts of the Gold Coast to consent to a kind of patched-up peace with the Awoonlahs; for a real peace is quite out of the question until one side or the other is thoroughly defeated and exhausted. However, any kind of peace would have served his purpose; any chance that would afford an opportunity and furnish material for a grandiloquent despatch to the Duke of Buckingham, announcing the final adjustment of the vexed Awoonlah question, restoration of peace, opening of the Volta, renewal of trade, &c., &c., &c.; accompanied possibly by an "address" got up in the usual Gold Coast fashion (of which more next month).

All this you see, Sir, would have resulted most probably in the Secretary of State sending him by return mail his commission as full administrator by way of reward for his eminent services.*

But this has not succeeded; for the entire community, European and native (with the exception of two or three parasitical and uninfluential Europeans), having the interests of the country at heart, was opposed to the line of policy which the Acting Administrator had drawn up for them to follow in his lead.'}, {'id': 1274, 'article_title': 'THE AWOONLAH WARS', 'full_section_title': 'THE AWOONLAH WARS', 'last_edit_date': '02-06-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1868#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_03_1868', 'content': 'Sir,—As I am well aware that news might reach you from Accra from some of your correspondents, about a new fight on the Volta on the 1st and 6th of January between the Doffoes, Volloes, and Akwamus on one hand, and the Assucharye, and as I am sure that things might be represented to you in a different light than they ought to be, I beg you, Mr. Editor, to insert this in your next number.

I beg to inform you that I am a native of the interior, and in consequence know more about Akuapim, Akim, Kroboe, and Akwamu than many of your other correspondents, and what I now say is the truth.

The Government has done what it could in restoring peace and order amongst the natives. There are many persons who are of opinion that the Government ought to help the Adahs and Accras to fight the Anwoonahs to finish the war; but there are others who know the state of the country who think differently, and that the first who brought on the war were Adahs, and not the Anwoonahs. You will perhaps have heard that the
**[MARCH 23, 1868.]**

messengers whom the Government sent to Akwamu were killed; but I am glad to inform you that the report is not true; they came back safe and sound to Accra last Saturday, the 1st instant. Their report shows that the Akwamus would have kept the treaty if this last outrage between the Dofoes, &c., had not taken place, and also that the King and many peacefully-disposed chiefs and head men under him are greatly sorry at what has happened.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

AFRICANUS.

*Note.—It seems to us that this "true statement of facts" affords strong corroborative evidence of the absolute necessity of a supreme power insisting upon, and, if requisite, enforcing peace in the Eastern Districts.—Ed. A. T.*

---'}, {'id': 1348, 'article_title': 'Awoolah Outrages—Ashantees at Jellee Coffee—A Man Flayed Alive', 'full_section_title': 'Awoolah Outrages—Ashantees at Jellee Coffee—A Man Flayed Alive', 'last_edit_date': '04-09-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1868#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_05_1868', 'content': 'Sir,—So much for the celebrated Awoonlah peace. Providence has in its own time and way proved to the German missionaries that the Awoonlahs never did make peace.

This mail brings the following from Jellee Coffee: The place (Jellee Coffee) is full of Ashantees. The Awoonlahs have given themselves up to the Ashantees. One of the missionaries from Christainsborg, who went to Quittah intending to go by that route to Crepee, was caught by the Awoonlahs and nearly beaten to death; they knocked out half his teeth. Mr. Nicol Irvine, of this place, a native of Scotland, and one of our most esteemed merchants, who was there trading, was going to be killed, but purchased his life with two puncheons of rum If it had not been for the personal interference of John Tay, of Jellee Coffee, Irvine would have been killed. *They flayed an Accra canoeman alive!*

There were several English naval officers at Jellee Coffee at the time; the naval men assisted several of the Accras to escape on board the shipping in the roads. The Awoonlahs declare that if the Accra tribes do not attack them, they will attack the Accras. This is authentic, and you have my authority to publish it. More next mail.—Yours truly,

Accra.

P.S.—The Dart has been sent down expressly from Cape Coast by Mr. Usher to fetch Mr. Freeman, who is to be dispatched to the Fantee camp (Commendah affair) to endeavour to appease the chiefs. Mr. Usher has been arresting some of the chiefs. There is no doubt the Fantees would rather be slaves of the English than allies of the Dutch, but if this arresting of their chiefs, &c., is proceeded with there will be mischief. A.

---

*TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.*

Christiansborg, Accra, March 22, 1868:

Sir,—There is now an outcry from the Coast and the missionaries that the educated merchants and traders are a great hindrance to peace. I would like to ask, who have been the sufferers in this Awoonlah affair? What have we gained by keeping up, as they choose to say so falsely, a war excitement? Have not more than three-fourths of us been ruined by this war. Facts are now speaking for themselves. I am sorry to say that most of the European houses here are feeling the dire effects of it. You have had "Ad Valorem's" account and mine, and you have the accumulating *facts—facts* before you. The Rev. Mr. Schrenk writes against us in the *Anti-slavery Reporter*, and now you see him signing with us the memorial to the Governor-in-Chief! You must always bear in mind, as I know you do, that none of these people, the German missionaries and their commercial managers, have any *permanent interest* in these countries. They have the interest of the people at heart, no doubt, in a religious point of view; but beyond that they would sell or dispose of the country in any way that seems best to suit their present interest. The case is different with us. We have been waiting for the last two years for the restoration of peace, and have been bitterly disappointed.—Yours truly,'}, {'id': 5223, 'article_title': 'Alleged Great Mahometan Rising', 'full_section_title': 'Alleged Great Mahometan Rising', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-12', 'issue_date': '01_10_1885', 'content': "to have recently driven the French troops from the region of Boure. They were at latest accounts proceeding to Bamnak, a large town on the Niger occupied by the French about three years ago, and fortified by them. No particulars seem to have been received of the progress of the corps inland of Liberia; but as regards the Sherbro army, it was said this was but a few miles to the north-west of Sierra Leone. This army had secured, either by conquest or voluntary act, the submission of all the tribes and countries in its march of about 500 miles. For the last sixty years the Fulah Mahometans had been trying by diplomacy to subdue the place, but without effect. Last year Samuda's army in overwhelming numbers surrounded the place, and called upon the inhabitants to surrender to Islam. This the King and people refused to do. The King collected his family together, and held a consultation with his great chiefs. He said he would die rather than embrace Mahometanism, but left it to the option of his chiefs to take any course they liked. They, however, all preferred to share the fate of the Monarch. After a terrible siege of five months' duration, the King, all the Royal Family, and the chiefs entered the powder store, which they blew up, all inside being killed. The city then was reduced by flames. The Hooboo country, which had been a source of much terror to all peaceful travellers for the last thirty years, was also conquered by Samuda's army. The predatory King of Hooboo, Abal, was taken prisoner. His arms, legs, and head were severed from his body, and sent to the various countries which had suffered from the murderous and predatory acts of Abal's followers. [{'document_title': 'Wars among the Natives of the River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In justification of the statement that the late disturbances had their origin in British mismanagement during the late expedition against Badiboo, he states that when peace was signed, the King of Badiboo was not present—the King afterward declared that he never sued for peace—Mahabah was the messenger who concluded that peace in the King's name. When the King denied having been a party to this, Mahabah's life was in danger, the King declaring that since Mahabah was a friend of the British, and they had been satisfied with his statement relative to peace, it must have been he who encouraged the British to make war. Mahabah's town was then blockaded, and three of his relatives were slain. Every one attempting to leave the town was murdered. In this strait, Mahabah sallied from the town with his followers, gave battle to the Badiboos, defeated them, took their King prisoner, beheaded him, pursued the fugitives through the kingdoms of Barra and Salem, and even called upon the King of Keyang, on the other side of the river, to destroy those who had fled thither for protection.

This is at least a clear and intelligible statement, such as we were quite unable to extract from preceding accounts. And this praise must be considered as impartial on our side, since we have fallen under our friends' condemnation for having inserted in our journal certain accounts in which British official efforts were commended. As the African Times is intended to become an historical record of principal events on the West Coast of Africa, we insert whatever comes to us well authenticated touching such events, so that the truth may be arrived at. Our present informant states that, so far from deserving eulogy, the conduct of the late British war against Badiboo was disgraceful to all concerned. "It was wretchedly conducted—it was not war, but playing at war."

We are unfortunately compelled, by want of space, to break this article which will be continued in our next.—Ed.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Mahaba has made a vast improvement of late, and caused the  
once savage kingdom of Badiboo to become somewhat civil and  
tamed. From what I have experienced at Badiboo, I do protest  
against any force being sent to put him down, because he is not  
doing harm, but good, and is preparing the way for rich cul-  
tivation, large trading, and future welfare of this portion of the  
the river. But there are some fellows above: Badiboo, both  
Mohammedans and pagans, that are very troublesome, and ought  
to have a severe blowing up, &c., but not Mahaba."

**Extract from No. —**

"I am against every one, whether Mahaba, Laku, or whoever  
he may be, that makes disturbance. I do think it necessary for  
the Government to use force to put a final stop to these trouble-  
some wars. I lost forty-six cattle seized by the warriors at  
Dumansesang, and I have had no redress from the local Govern-  
ment; although I wrote to the Acting Governor about it in Novem-  
ber last, not a word on the subject have I ever heard. A small  
gunboat would do in two months all that is wanted, blowing up  
all the towns that made disturbance; then they will soon respect  
the British. A small gunboat to be sent out for a short time, is  
the only means required to promote the welfare of the rivers," &c.

**Extract from No. —**

"I see no necessity for any force being sent against Mahaba.  
He ought rather to be acknowledged and crowned as king by the  
British Government, and a responsibility be imposed on him re-  
garding the affairs of the river, owing to the great work he has  
already performed for the safety of our goods, principally at Badi-  
boo. Government protection in the river is wanted, *but no expe-  
dition.* War with the natives will never bring things to rights.  
The late Badiboo expedition did nothing. There was no change  
till Mahaba arose. That line of demarcation you called for in  
your journal of May last has never been drawn, although the  
case is urgent. There is very little to be complained of as re-  
gards Mahaba; but there are many disturbances in the river  
caused by others. The pagans are still very savage. Three  
traders have of late received a severe beating; one at Tenderbah,  
and two in the upper river above McCarthy's Island. The latter  
were Europeans."

**Extract from No. —**

"I do believe that Mahaba has done a great work, which  
ought to obtain for him the highest praise. Some years back  
there was scarcely a trader to be found at Badiboo, although it  
is one of the richest trading parts of the river. The people were  
so cruel and so naturally wicked, that only those who would risk  
their lives would trade amongst them; but since these two years  
back all the landing ports on that territory are full of traders."', 'last_edit_date': '1864-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.604, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'doing business without the least disturbance, instead of as in former days, when a trader was forced by compulsion to give presents every day to twenty, thirty, or forty men of the King's ambassadors; and custom duties to be taken by them at their own valuation. Mahaba is doing nothing but good in the river."

*Extract from No. —*

"I do not believe Mahaba ever troubled a trader. I can see no reason for warring against him. But there is one Laku that disturbs this river, and ought to be checked. So late as Tuesday, the 2nd August, I witnessed some cruel acts committed by his men at Tambakotto. Except that man is put down, the river, as regards trade, &c., will never prosper. Mahaba, too, it must be remembered, is a foreigner; he has no proper settlement of his own since his wars began. He is often 100 miles in the interior, say from Swana Conda to Macca. How long will it take the Governor to make even a common road to get at him, through 100 miles of bush? and what amount of money would it cost; and then, all for nothing," &c., &c.

*Extract from No. 19.*

"To move an expedition against Mahaba will only be injuring a man who is really on our side, and helping to promote the welfare of this river, and preparing the way for civilization," &c.

*Extract from No. 20.*

"I, being one of the traders at Badiboo, say that Mahaba has performed a very important public service, that ought to have been done by a superior to him. He is really doing good. During the last eight months, when he retired from the river, he has ordered the whole of his subjects to cultivate the ground, which they have done to a large extent. Nor has he himself been idle; and as regards cultivation, the whole territory wears an aspect of promise. These territories are now so settled and quiet, that even female traders can trade. There are three female traders, British subjects, at Njiane, one at Njorwarra, one at Kenty Coonder, one at Swarra Coonder, and two at Carrawan. What, then, can be said of Mahaba but that he is doing good, seeking the interest of traders, increasing agriculture, recommending cultivation, which leads to civilization. Cultivation and trade will not be safe or increase should Mahaba be put down.

"Instead of putting down Mahaba, why does not the local Government do its duty, in obtaining that the traders should be allowed to reside out of the towns, and in marking the line of demarcation which you pointed out as so urgent, but which is still neglected?

"But there is one Laku at Nyanne, the only fellow that troubles this river. His influence requires to be checked."

*Copy of a letter written by Mahaba to the French Commandant at the Fort Cowlack, in Salem.*

"Macca, Salem, June 1, 1864.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.619, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Policy of Non-Intervention in Western Africa: Its Mischievous Tendency on the Good Government of the Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The political horizon of British Gambia is by no means in a satisfactory state; clouds are gathering from a quarter which ordinary men regard as a menace to the peace of the river. A glance at the past will show us what we may expect in the future, and also how to deal with it.

Mahba, King of Badiboo, formidable alike to all the native kings and to the French and to the English Government, sent last September a menacing despatch (in Arabic) to Colonel D'Arcy, the officer administering the Government of the Gambia, very warlike in its tone, and by subsequent actions violated all existing treaties. He detained all the British traders within the kingdom of Badiboo, with their goods and chattels, not allowing one man to leave the place, and also prevented all ingress into Badiboo, thus putting a stop to the trade of an extensive country, whose yearly quota of ground-nuts and hides adds greatly to the revenue of the colony. What was the *casus belli*?

The ostensible cause of this warlike and menacing attitude was, that a woman with a few children* availed themselves of Mahba's temporary absence from his capital, and made their escape to the British town of Bathurst. He at once sent to Colonel D'Arcy that, unless the woman and children were delivered up, all friendly diplomatic relation must stop, and trade cease, and the ports of Badiboo must, consequently, be considered closed to English merchants.

But the real cause, to all those who have studied the character of these Marabouts, inhabitants of the River Gambia, is to be found in that ambitious, overbearing, and covetous disposition of the Mussulmans, who view with discontent the rich prize they would obtain, could they have an opportunity of making one midnight raid on the rich Babboo Christian merchants at Bathurst. The toleration of this overbearing disposition of the Marabout chieftains in the River Gambia will always lead to serious complications; they must be made to understand that the British Government, although desirous of peace, yet still will never tolerate any nonsense from them.

We have not as yet forgotten the outrageous attack of Mahfal, the Commander-in-Chief of south-eastern Badiboo, on towns in British grounds, which led to the battle of Zoobabocolong; and at present, if reports from traders are correct, the greater part of Mahba's force is threatening Albreda. But the unhappy manner in which that most justifiable war was received by the home authorities, must for ever fetter the hands of all subsequent administrators of the Government of British Gambia.", 'last_edit_date': '1867-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "DEFEAT AND DEATH OF THE MAHOMETAN CHIEF AND WARRIOR MABA, OR MAHABA.**

We have often had to report in the African Times the successes and excesses of Maba, who has been the scourge of the countries between the Senegal and the Gambia, and thus brought himself occasionally into collision with both the French and the English. In 1861 he was an unimportant chief in the kingdom of Baddiboo, against which the last great war expedition of the British authorities in the Gambia was directed. Maba was a bigoted Mahometan, and watching his opportunity, he in 1861 rebelled against the King of Baddiboo, whom he put to death, raising himself to be supreme ruler of Baddiboo. He then declared a propaganda of Mahometanism, which he endeavoured to force by fire and sword in all the adjacent countries. His last recorded exploit was a successful attack upon some 300 French troops (Europeans), who were all slain except nine, the officer in command putting an end to his own existence.

The last French mail from Senegal brought to Europe the intelligence that this restless and cruel fanatic chief has at last met with the fate he has constantly provoked. He was therein stated to have been taken prisoner in battle by the Joloffe King of Sein, and by him put to death, his head and hands being sent by the Joloffe King to the French Governor of Senegal.

By the mail of the 2nd inst. from Bathurst we have a confirmation of this important news. As we are not of those who believe that the forcible spread of Mahometanism in Africa (and it never spreads in any other way) is desirable, we unfeignedly rejoice that this great warrior-chief, for such he undoubtedly was, exists no more to trouble the Gambia countries. He has interfered very much with the development of the ground-nut cultivation, on which the trade in the Gambia chiefly depends, and many British traders up the river have suffered severely in the troubles he was constantly exciting, and the wars he was as constantly waging; and we hope now to hear of a new era of trading prosperity there which may compensate them for their losses, and promote the spread of civilisation in those important countries. In this case we feel certain the British authorities will again find it necessary to place a small force at M'Carthy's Island, the former British outpost in the interior.", 'last_edit_date': '1867-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1867#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.631, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Policy of Non-Intervention in Western Africa: Its Mischievous Tendency on the Good Government of the Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the first case this would have delayed the expedition for two or three weeks; the Marabouts would have had everything their own way; they would have become masters of the stockaded towns in British Neomy, or Barra, from whence they might have marched on to Albreda, burnt it down, and pillaged the property of British and French merchants. Mahba, finding his captain-general so successful, might have sent down a large army, and swept away the whole of the Jollof population before we could even make an armed protest against them. The Marabouts at Goonjour, who were watching what turn events would take, would have pounced on the British towns of Newcastle, Jassewrang, Hamilton Town, and the towns in their "father's ground" at Sabajee; and destruction, confusion and perplexity would have been the result.

Had the Marabouts been allowed to glory in their victory, and all expeditionary movement been disapproved of, the British Government would have lost all prestige in the river; the Governor of the Gambia would have been a nonentity, except in the town of Bathurst, and the Marabouts would have attempted to dictate terms to him in British grounds. As it was, they told Masamba Kokie before the war that the Governor of the Gambia speaks only soft words to them; "he will never defend you against us;" and Mahfal studiously made it to be believed amongst the whole of his people that there was an agreement between Mahba and the British Governor that they should fight against the Jollof Soninkees, and that nothing would be done to them; and had not the expedition taken place, it would have been impossible to persuade them to believe otherwise, and Masamba Kokie, the British chief, and all his people, would have been destroyed or driven from British ground by these foreign Marabouts.

The war had a most beneficial effect in the whole river. Mahba, on hearing of the success of the British arms at Zoobabocolong, sent immediately to the Governor disowning all connexion with Mahfal; all the British traders were looked upon with respect and fear; the Marabouts in native Neomy were ready at that moment to ask pardon for what they have done, and begged to be received again in British territory; the Goonjour people laid down their arms, and nothing more was heard of their intended marauding expedition, and British prestige was held up and respected in the rivers.

We have always freely complained of the many grievous errors in Colonel D'Arcy's administration—but in that expedition Colonel D'Arcy staked everything. He was determined to uphold the prestige of the British Government in the river, to moderate the Marabout influence, and to save British subjects from their murderous attacks. He staked his life and government in the undertaking. A short, inexpensive, decisive, and successful expedition would have been the only means to save the influence of the Gambia Government, and how far this was realized in the Zoobabocolong war former reports have told.

---', 'last_edit_date': '1867-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'all went well; "peace, quietness, and justice began to reign in the land," we are told; but soon discussions arose, the Arab traders saw that the growth of Christian influence was fatal to the slave trade, and they began to intrigue against the Christian ministers of the new King Kiwewa, who, they got him to believe, were plotting against him—the idea being that the Christians wished to be governed by a woman, as in England. The chief of the Christian party managed also to offend the King, and this became the signal for the outbreak of a fresh revolution. The Mohammedans attacked the Christians—who were obliged to flee for their lives, two of the chief among the latter being killed. The Mohammedans, supported by the Arabs, were now in the ascendant, new officers of state were appointed, and the missionaries—both French and English—were cast into prison, being after a few days released, and told to leave the country, with the injunction: "Let no white man come to Buganda for two years. We do not want to see a white teacher back in Buganda till we have converted the whole people to the Mohammedan faith."

There is a lesson to be learnt from this case, and what has lately happened to the German East African Company in Zanzibar. In both cases the Arab traders were the instigators, though in the latter case they seem to have had matters simplified for them by the action of the German East African and Imperial authorities. If it be true that the German ships have occasionally been guilty of promiscuously shelling the coast, "simply to overawe the natives," we can hardly wonder at the influence obtained by these Arab traders. In the ordinary way there is not much reason for this alliance between the natives and the Arabs—as the intercourse of the latter is generally confined to kidnapping and enslaving the former. But the presence of a common enemy is sure to drive them into alliance together. And let us remember the native mind does not grasp the difference between one European power and another. It is not in the interests of the Arab to enlighten them—on the contrary, it is clearly to his advantage to persuade them that all Europeans are bent upon their destruction. The Arab influence in East Africa is already immense. The chief obstacle to its further development lies in the hostility of the native tribes, who have trusted Europeans in preference, because they found that these have been just and considerate; but according to latest accounts, the Germans seem bent upon changing all this, and forcing the natives to make common cause with the Arabs. Their efforts at peaceful colonisation will surely fail in exact proportion to their success in this enterprise.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.605, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GAMBIA—ITS ADMINISTRATION AND THREATENED CESSION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—That the settlements in the River Gambia are suffering from being under the management of the Governor of Sierra Leone, or, as he is, in the technical language of Bumbledom, called "Governor of the West African Settlements," is a fact patent to every practical man on the West Coast. That the other West African Colonies, such as Lagos and the Gold Coast, are also suffering from the same cause is equally clear, and that the great and important colony of Sierra Leone feels her interests to be sadly compromised by the so-called consolidation of all the settlements into a general government, with local administrators at the Gambia, Cape Coast, and Lagos, is clearly shown by the able Editor of the West African Liberator (published at Sierra Leone) in several of his leaders, but more especially in one dated 5th September of last year, from which I extract the following paragraph. Speaking of the consolidation he says: "But this having been put into practice has turned out a complete and disastrous failure, and, instead of proving a benefit to, has only brought suffering on them all (i.e., in all the settlements on the West Coast), in consequence of the evils which spring from having two masters to rule in each, minus Sierra Leone, and she, sad to say, has turned out, as usual, to be the greatest of the sufferers." After illustrating in his usual clear and forcibly style the manner in which Sierra Leone suffers from this great official mistake, he goes on to say: "This interference with the other settlements is the cause of much mischief. By it the various administrators have lost their patronage, and with it their influence. It is out of their power to reward men of merit in their own governments, but they must submit to any appointments made by Sierra Leone, which has aroused great dissatisfaction, as complaints from the Gambia show. The governor-in-chief has as much as he can attend to at his own station if he were ever so industrious, and to divide his time is to make him perform his work imperfectly and unsatisfactorily. The evil can only be got rid of by placing the settlements as they were before, by confining each governor to his immediate governments, thereby preventing the one from meddling with the business of the other. Under such an arrangement individual responsibility would be felt, but under the present system no one holds himself responsible, so that should any difficulty arise we may rest assured that each will try to throw the burden on the shoulders of the others. Then, again, a fearful expense is entailed, for, among other things, a steamer must be supported to keep up a ruinous system. So much for having two rulers. It is true there are governors-in-chiefs in the West Indies as well as in the West Coast, but it must be borne in mind that these West India Islands have their own representative institutions to protect their internal affairs. They have self-government, and all the governor-in-chief has to do is to supervise. But on the West Coast he is the legislature itself, the constructor and supervisor of all measures; in a word, he is absolute and rules over the people, who are powerless, just as he pleases, and disposes of their interests as he sees proper."', 'last_edit_date': '1870-12-12', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1871#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.604, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "RIVER GAMBIA: MAHABA'S AFFAIRS", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—I have read the document published in your paper about Mahaba. His worshippers seem to have forgotten what atrocities he had committed. The reason why they are opposed to the Soninkee Government was, that at certain times the people generally came to the factors and begged or demanded certain articles from them, and if refused in an obstinate manner, they considered it an insult to them, as the factors were occupying the ground of their fathers. The affray then generally terminated by the traders receiving a good flogging, and being made to pay a larger demand. I do not wonder at this being complained of; but if the traders were polite and obliging to them, and showed them that the goods did not really belong to the traders, at the same time making them small presents, they generally returned double the amount in a few days in cattle.

When Badiboo was under the Soninkee Government, traders from every part of the country came down to trade in it, as it is situated near the large and populous kingdom of Salom. At Badiboo are the best cotton and phangs, numerous bandy cloth, and an immense quantity of ground-nuts; so much so, that Badiboo, under the government of the Soninkees, produced more nuts than any other kingdom on the River Gambia. The principal ground-nut marts were Swarak, Cindah, Bany, Kintak Cundah, and Sabaj. In these towns kola are sold in great abundance for phangs, and afterwards exchanged for ground-nuts, from which the petty traders derive great benefit.

The people at Badiboo are an intermixture of Jollof, Mandigo, and Foolahs, and from them the people at Bathurst receive yearly several head of cattle, with some fresh butter, corn, and rice. Although the Soninkees are universally considered to be lazy, yet still the lower class are hard-working, and when a Soninkee chief has rule over Marabouts, it is his general practice to compel them to work, so as to pay him a portion of their earnings. But when Mahaba became chief, trade almost ceased, the people in the interior being afraid to come down, as their property would not be secured from the ravages of Mahaba's people. The Cabuncas, who occupy an extensive region in the interior of Badiboo, reaching to Rio Nunez, on the other hand, were in the habit of coming down by land to Tenderbar, and from there cross over to Badiboo for the express purpose of purchasing horses and phangs, but they have since been afraid to do so.", 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BASUTOLAND.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We learn by telegram from Durban (Dec. 5) that all the Basuto chiefs, except Masupha, Joel, and Ramanella, having accepted the proposals of the Imperial Government, the issue practically rests with these malcontents. Any settlement which would exclude Masupha would obviously be incomplete.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1884#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.622, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GAMBIA AND ITS NEIGHBOURS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In the report on the Gambia which has just been issued the Administrator speaks of the year under review as an important one for the settlement. In 1885 differences existed in the kingdom of Baddiboo, a country which, under favourable circumstances, contributes greatly to the prosperity of Gambia, because it grows the staple product of the settlement—ground nuts. The Baddiboo war, in conjunction with the simultaneous depression in the value of this staple, produced a disastrous decline in the revenue of Gambia, and therefore special efforts were made to bring about a settlement of the difficulty. After prolonged negotiations the Acting Administrator arranged a basis of peace, and the two rival chiefs, Beram Ceasey and Saide Mattie, signed treaties with the Government of Gambia in 1887, guaranteeing to stop the war, and to engage in no further hostilities without reference to the Governor at Bathurst.

For a short time matters went on satisfactorily, and preparations to cultivate Baddiboo were being renewed, when, unhappily, Saide Mattie, in opposition to the emphatic advice of the Administrator, persisted in going to the adjoining kingdom of Saloum to obtain redress for some wrong, imaginary or real, committed by the King of that country against him. Soon after the treaty was signed he proceeded with a strong contingent of his army to Saloum. The latter chief sought assistance from the French, who espoused his cause and warned Saide Mattie to return to Baddiboo. He was, however, defiant, and a fight ensued in which he and his army were utterly routed and driven back. They were pursued and dispersed, and Saide Mattie, seeing that all was over, took refuge in Albareda, and laid down his arms at the English Governor's request. He consented to go to the English settlement at Bathurst, and there he has remained ever since.

The difference made by a tribal war of this kind in the trade of the settlements on the adjacent coasts is shown by the circumstance that the trade of Gambia in ground nuts, which, in 1883, prior to the Baddiboo war, amounted to over 23,000 tons, had fallen in 1887 to less than 3,000. Ground nut oil is used as a substitute for olive oil and in the manufacture of butterine.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.605, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Party Criticisms on Ashanti War Operations', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have been greatly tempted to reply to some leading articles in the Daily Press on the subject of the successfully terminated Ashanti War, the destruction of Kumasi, the peace with Koffee Kalkalli, and the disintegration of the Ashanti kingdom. When we find the latter bewailed as though a star had been rent from the firmament, we could almost wish that the writer could at least have been "in log" for a short time with the barbarian, and have witnessed those scenes which gave so detestable an odour—that faint, sickening smell of human blood—to the whole town in which he dwelt, and which has now been so righteously destroyed. It is indeed lamentable to behold the lengths to which political party feeling will impel public writers, even in matters of national import. We are sorry to be compelled to say that, if we may judge by the tone of their public organs, the now dominant political party find the Ashanti success of Sir Garnet Wolseley, almost as palatable as gall and wormwood. So much pains had been taken by members of the Conservative Opposition to prepare the Ashanti War stone, to be slung, on the re-assembling of Parliament, at the now defunct Administration, that although it is not now necessary for hurling them from power, it is not unnaturally a source of irritation that Sir Garnet Wolseley’s successes, obtained at so small a cost, should have robbed them of the still anticipated pleasure of propelling it against them in their retreat. Had but those successes been delayed, had it but been indispensable to send out reinforcements, so that the ultimate success might have been claimed by the new Administration! But, alas! Sir Garnet effected what he had been sent to effect, with the forces that had been placed at his disposal for that purpose; and keen and bitter seems to be the disappointment. The virulent nonsense that has been written may pass current with ignorant partizans who know nothing of the merits or demerits of the late little war,

hh: Despite the colonial agenda to assimilate African tribes through education, some African intellectuals leveraged European education to advocate for independence and reform, highlighting education's transformative potential when it respects and builds upon existing cultural traits.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that African intellectuals leveraged European education to advocate for independence and reform, while highlighting education's transformative potential when it respects and builds upon existing cultural traits. The textbook details the emergence of an educated African elite, fostered by missionary and colonial educational efforts, who became significant agents of change. Intellectuals like J. E. Casely Hayford and J. E. K. Aggrey used their education to critique colonial policies and advocate for reforms aligned with African cultural values. Cultural movements such as pan-Africanism and négritude, rooted in cultural identity, further exemplify this advocacy. Local initiatives, like the Gikuyu cultural nationalists establishing their own schools, demonstrate how education was adapted to support cultural preservation and self-reliance. However, the textbook also acknowledges the challenges faced by African intellectuals, such as the internal conflict between embracing European culture and maintaining African identity, as seen in the example of Jean-Joseph Rabearivelo. Similarly, The African Times articles emphasize the importance of education in uplifting African societies, advocating for schools that cater to the specific needs of African children, with a preference for African teachers who understand local customs and languages. This reflects a desire to integrate education with cultural understanding, rather than mere assimilation. The articles also discuss the role of education in empowering Africans to participate in governance and societal development, suggesting a push for independence and self-governance. Despite the challenges posed by colonial policies that often inadequately supported educational initiatives, both sources illustrate how education was viewed as a means of transformation and empowerment, provided it was adapted to respect and enhance African cultural traits.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that align with the claim that African intellectuals leveraged European education to advocate for independence and reform, while also highlighting the transformative potential of education when it respects and builds upon existing cultural traits. It is correct to say that the educational revolution in Africa was the work of three interest groups Christian missions, colonial governments and local African initiative, in that order of importance. For the Christian missions the school was a key institution, being the most reliable means for membership recruitment, and for creating self-perpetuating congregations whose members would ensure the survival of Christianity in the event of withdrawal by the white missionaries. Education and evangelization were so closely linked that for many parts of Africa the pitching of the missionary tent was synonymous with the establishment of a school. Among the Nguni the opening of a school is said to have preceded the opening of a church in all cases. 4
The colonial administrations, on their part, hoped through the school to raise the low-grade personnel they needed for staffing the bottom echelons of the colonial bureaucracy, to create such conditions - political, economic, social and moral - as would enable Europe to exploit as fully as possible what were regarded as the hitherto insufficiently tapped resources of Africa. In these places, too, some of the new elite established and ran schools, especially at the secondary level where the felt need for self-reliance at times led to the building of technical rather than grammar schools, independent of the colonial administration and the missions.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.053, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'Change and continuity', 'content': 'Nor is the 'traditional-modern' polar model, with all its attendant implications of conflict and incompatibility, applicable to the entire spectrum of African experience of change under colonialism. Not only were certain customs and beliefs discarded or modified, but some were retained at one level of society at the same time as new alternatives were being accepted at another level. Thus while human sacrifice, the slave trade and the killing of twins were discarded in societies where such practices had existed, and old and new ideas were amalgamated in the sphere of religion, the European ideal of monogamous marriage, accepted as part of an expected public image by sections of the westernized elite, exists side by side under the law with the institution of polygamy among the urban and rural masses. Today we have existing side by side in Africa indigenous and European architectural traditions; local ethnicity and nationalism; local and regional-locked economies and a notional money economy; rural and urban life; western bureaucratic institutions and traditional local authorities; Ku'ranic and Western schools.
Thus with ease many indigenous African institutions and ideas survived the impact of, or even blended with, alien European values. They see no contradiction, and have no difficulty, in combining Christian and traditional Nguni rites in marriage and funeral ceremonies.$^{2}$ Professor Fallers has also described some Ugandan groups as 'enthusiastically and successfully' accepting many elements of modernization - confining their influence, and adapting them to traditional culture and social structure. Brew and John Mensah Sarbah.31', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'Change and continuity', 'content': "Any easy generalization on the response of African societies to the European impact is thus bound to be misleading. One must always bear in mind the territorial vastness of the continent, the rich diversity and variegation of African cultures, differences in individual and group temperaments and psychologies - and thus the fact that response to even similar stimuli was likely to vary not only from individual to individual or from society to society, but also from time to time within the same society and by the same individual. One can, therefore, subscribe to the view that change as such was not new to colonial Africa and that there is no African society which was not affected to an appreciable extent by European contact or which simply withered before it. One must also concede that with colonial rule the ideology of change came to be consciously embraced by the rulers of Africa and their would-be friends. Even those colonial officials who were strongly committed to the policy and practice of indirect rule, with its emphasis on the preservation of traditional institutions and values, still recognized the need for change. Indeed under indirect rule indigenous institutions and rulers were expected to serve as media for introducing reform in measured doses and in ways acceptable to the colonial authority. Every colonial administration saw change as the only way of modernizing Africa and fitting her into the orbit of the West to the latter's advantage. The indigenous elites have patronized change as a way of getting Africa on to her feet and making her states equal members of the community of nations.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the New World', 'section_title': 'The educational impact of the Americas', 'content': "While travelling in West and Southern Africa with the Phelps-Stokes Commission and while lecturing in the Gold Coast as part of his Achimota appointment, Aggrey and several others in similar ways reached across many African communities and prompted dozens of African youth to seek an American rather than a British education. Azikiwe, Banda and Nkrumah became the three most well-known of those touched by Aggrey. The ex› periences of these men also illustrate the pan-African or pan-black aspects of their American days. Yet these aspects of African interaction with blacks of the diaspora do not wholly explain the activities of the Americaneducated Africans on their return home. Nor are they adequately explained in currently available scholarship. [{'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': '### BY AFRICANUS HORTON, M.D., S.A.S.'}, {'id': 956, 'article_title': "Speech of Colonel D'Arcy", 'full_section_title': "Speech of Colonel D'Arcy", 'last_edit_date': '10-24-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1866#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_11_1866', 'content': 'I am sure the ladies and gentlemen who have honoured you with their presence to-day feel with me great satisfaction at the progress you have made in your studies. I have so often, and for so many years, dwelt on the advantages of education, that I fear I have exhausted the subject, but I can perhaps bring them clear to your minds by giving you the opinion of one of the deepest thinkers the English nation has ever produced.

Mr. Addison, the philosopher and Secretary of State, thus describes the difference between a man of education and a man of the bush: "I consider the human soul without education like marble in the quarry, which shows none of its inherent beauties, till the skill of the polisher fetches out the colour, makes the surface shine, and discovers every ornament that runs through the body of it." This comparison is clear, and can be easily grasped by the simplest minds.

Now, before I conclude, let me give honour to your schoolmaster. It is but tiresome for him year after year to plod on the same course, to go over the old ground of instruction day after day. The small salary is not a sufficient reward for this labour; but with a well-regulated mind this labour becomes one of love, and his conscience tells him that his vocation is peculiarly honoured. Superficially, to those who do not reflect, the aged, poverty-stricken village master, teaching the mechanical art of reading or writing, is supposed only to teach that alone; while in truth he is protecting life, insuring property, fencing the altar, guarding the throne, giving peace and liberty to all the fine powers of man, and lifting him up to his own place in the order of creation. This is essentially true; for without education we should be like the wild nations around us, every man's hand against his neighbour.

You have, as I often told you, much to be thankful for—born in a Christian country, governed by a constitutional Christian Queen, to whom the words of our poet may be so truthfully applied—

> Thou art alone  
> (Of thy rare qualities, sweet gentleness,  
> Thy meekness, saint-like, wife-like government,  
> Obeying in commanding, and thy parts)  
> The Queen of earthly queens.

Your education, moreover, is superintended by ministers of the Gospel, who one after the other are compelled through sickness to leave their posts, and yet the good people of England send others to fill their places equally kind, equally zealous.

I trust you will all grow up with life-long feelings of gratitude for all the advantages you are enjoying. Now, for the last time, I am afraid, I bid you all good-bye. God bless you.'}, {'id': 2976, 'article_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': '09-01-1875', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_11_1875', 'content': 'I consider your suggestion that the Government should ask for the aid of the Wesleyan Missionary Society, a very wholesome one; not that the Society needs the prestige of the Government to insure success to its work, but the Society would be able to give to the Government the benefit of its experience and its services, and this may result in a considerable reduction of the expense that would be incurred in the outlay. But, besides, this would be for us some security against the wholesale establishment of barely secular schools. I would not compel a child to be a Christian, nor would I use any other unlawful means to win him over to Christianity, nor yet would I deny him the benefit of a liberal secular education because he or his parents refuse the religion. To do otherwise would be to punish one for his faith; but I would provide for him the means of a religious education, and leave the responsibility of refusing it to himself.

If a people are to be raised by a foreign race, it is the duty of the teaching race to study the idiosyncrasies of their scholars, follow the guidings of nature, take care to preserve all that is noble and good, and build upon it. But if they would destroy them indiscriminately, perhaps because they do not understand them, or because these do not altogether fall in with their own'}, {'id': 3431, 'article_title': 'The Abominable Fetish Customs of Accra', 'full_section_title': 'The Abominable Fetish Customs of Accra', 'last_edit_date': '09-17-1877', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1877#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_11_1877', 'content': '"There are more than twelve Fetish houses in this town. The house of this special Fetish to which this letter ascribes this barbarous custom, is in the quarter of Ussher Town called 'Churor,' named 'Oyeardoo's House.'—I have the honour to be," &c.

I had long thought of writing you this, but resolved to wait until the removal of the head-quarters here, when it would be convenient to bring everything to the notice of the Governor before reporting it to you.

Now, Mr. Editor, is this not one special proof of the want of a good school here, to bring the people under the fear of God? The want of a superior education here is greatly felt. Without it no country will civilize, and the sooner the Government introduce one here the better it will be for all parties.

I hear privately that the Government have resolved not to establish a good school here, in consequence of the conduct of the educated Sierra Leoneans being so bad as to defeat their expectation. If such is their intention—to leave us in the dark—the sooner they retire from the place the better.—I remain, yours truly,  
A.

---'}, {'id': 4793, 'article_title': 'EDUCATION OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRIBES.', 'full_section_title': 'EDUCATION OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRIBES.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1884#article-15', 'issue_date': '01_02_1884', 'content': 'At a meeting of the Royal Colonial Institute, held lately in the Grosvenor Gallery Library, New Bond-street, a paper was read by Mr. William Greswell, M.A., on "The Education of the South African Tribes." The lecturer said: The future of South Africa was much bound up with this question of administration, and especially the educational part of it. A proper education meant an assimilation of the coloured man to the ideal of the white man, with regard to habits of mind and of thought. The question of education was visibly affected by political disturbances. With regard to the general question, which was viewed in many different ways by white people both in the colony and at home, he said the great desideratum of the hour in South Africa was to raise the discussion of important matters beyond the atmosphere of party. Nothing had so much injured the native as the custom of using him for the purpose of a party cry. Premising that he should confine himself principally to the state of affairs in the Cape Colony, the Lecturer said he should show that there had existed and did still exist in that colony a State scheme for the instruction of the natives in nearly everything they might require to know, whether it was to shoe a horse, make a wheel, or learn Greek. As he had himself endeavoured to instruct the Caffre in the Greek declensions, in his capacity as Government Lecturer in the colony, he might say that the loftiness and catholicity of the scheme had come home to him. Remarking upon the difficulties in the way of applying such a scheme in a sparsely-peopled savage country like South Africa, he said the number of white colonists at the Cape was about equal to the population of Leeds, and these had to legislate for the reclamation of more than a million blacks, who were scattered over an immense tract. Other difficulties lay in the unequal social developments among the black people, in the bi-lingual character of the white population, and in the want of unanimity on the part of the white colonists as to the proper lines upon which native education ought to go. To bring under one system of State education men of different religious views, hard though it might be, was an easy task for the political legislator compared with that encountered in an attempt to group under one plan men so intellectually and, if he might use the term, spiritually distinct as the European and the African aboriginal races. The difference between the races was, practically speaking, one absolutely of kind, not of degree. Undeterred by difficulties, legislators at the Cape had boldly grappled with the question, and they had established a complete educational ladder, with the kraal schools at the bottom and the university at the top. After going with some detail into the working of the scheme in that colony, and suggesting some possible improvements in the system, he remarked that though philanthropy in theory, in practice it was unphilosophic. A cardinal fact was ignored—the generic difference between the European and the Caffre. The principle of heredity was ignored. He was inclined to believe that the Caffre would be influenced by a simple and rather an autocratic system. Advocating a certain measure of compulsion in order to make the Caffre industrious, and to compel him to be taught, he said the educationist should walk hand in hand with the white magistrate and the missionary; these three classes of men really replace the autocracy of the chiefs. He thought that if the philanthropist could be persuaded to believe that all men were not equal, and if the Boer could be persuaded to believe that they might be equal in course of time—in fact, that there was a germ which might be worked upon in the native, there would be some chance of an agreement. If both philanthropist and Boer should take the scientific view that the Caffre was really nothing more than he was by descent, a savage pure and simple, but that he had in him the makings of a good citizen, there would be considerably less friction in South Africa.'}]
