## LATEST INTELLIGENCE.—Nov. 22.

### RE-ELECTION FOR FOUR YEARS OF ABRAHAM LINCOLN AS PRESIDENT.

**New York, Nov. 9, Morning.**—Abraham Lincoln and Andrew Johnson, of Tennessee, have been elected President and Vice-President.

(Via Halifax).

**New York, Nov. 10.**—Lincoln has carried every state except Kentucky, Delaware, and New Jersey. Seymour's election as Governor of New York is doubtful. The Republicans have two-thirds of the majority in the Congress.

**New York, Nov. 10, Evening.**—The Presidential Election has passed off quietly. Lincoln's majority is 225,000 votes; M'Clellan's majority in New York city is 37,000.

**Negro Soldiers.**—The Confederates have enrolled the negroes in Mobile between the ages of fifteen and forty-five."}, {'id': 4518, 'article_title': 'THE FALSE STATEMENT OF THE DROWNING OF KROOMEN FROM THE AFRICAN S.S. BIAFRA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE FALSE STATEMENT OF THE DROWNING OF KROOMEN FROM THE AFRICAN S.S. BIAFRA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-15', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': "TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Sir,—Captain Rattray, late of the steamship Biafra, has drawn our attention to the articles appearing in your paper of the 1st September last, one of which purports to give an extract from the Monrovia Observer, practically charging our client with the death of certain Krooboys at Settra Kroo. The article attributes to our client conduct so inhuman and abominable that he is most anxious that the public should be freely informed what the facts really were. We have, therefore, to request that you will give this letter as great prominence in your paper as the editorial article in your issue to which we have referred. In the month of June last, the Biafra put into Grand Cess, to land some Kroo passengers, and, as usual, canoes came off from the shore to land the passengers and their effects. Kroo passengers learned from those coming from ashore that there was some dispute between the town from which the canoes had come and the town to which they wished to go, and where they resided. Not knowing how far this dispute had gone, or whether actual fighting had taken place, the Kroo passengers were afraid to land, and asked Captain Rattray to wait until canoes should arrive from their own town. The ship had already been delayed, waiting for canoes, and was behind time; so that it was uncertain when canoes would, if at all, come from their town. Captain Rattray informed them it was impossible for him to wait, but he offered to take them to Bassa or Monrovia.

to land them there, and give them a note to the Captain of the next returning steamer to take them back. This arrangement was entirely satisfactory to the passengers, and they were landed by the steamer's boats at Monrovia, where the Captain gave them the promised note for their passages home by the Company's next steamer, giving them, in addition, a week's rations of bread and meat. From this you will see that Captain Rattray, instead of treating the men in the cruel manner attributed to him, treated them in the best possible way, and, for their accommodation, went much farther than there was any legal call upon him. We may add, that we have in our possession a duly signed and attested certificate to the effect that there is no truth whatever in the article you have quoted. We would only add, that the Biafra never was at Settra Kroo at all on the voyage referred to.—

We are, Sir, your obedient servants,  
**Hill, Dickinson, & Co.**

In inserting the above letter of Captain Rattray, we beg to express our deep and sincere regret that we should have been misled into copying from the Monrovia Observer, and publishing in our columns, with editorial remarks on the same, the false and calumnious statement of which Captain Rattray so justly complains. We can imagine the pain it must have caused him, and tender our apologies for having been thus instrumental in inflicting it."}]

[{'document_title': 'Government Notices at Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '### TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Accra, Gold Coast, West Africa, December 10, 1865.

Sir,—Accra has hitherto been noted as one of the very few places in Western Africa where the white man and the black man pulled together better than they are generally known to do in almost all other parts. There may be many ways of accounting for this, but no doubt it must be ascribed chiefly to the fact that from time immemorial the white men who came to sojourn at Accra, whether Danes, Dutch, or English, were almost invariably of a superior class.

Times are, however, changed; the English gentleman is not now so frequently met with here as in days of yore.

In those days the white man lived in harmony with the black man. Being a gentleman, he did not consider himself degraded by associating on terms of perfect equality with the coloured man whose education, intellectual attainments, and self-respect entitled him to the respect of those whose esteem is of any value.

Having in view why exact English gentlemen deem qualifications, sufficient to entitle the Frenchman, the Turk, the American, Indian, or the Ashantee to move in their society, and having that feeling which pervades all real gentlemen, those white men, when they encountered black men possessing intellectual abilities and other qualifications not inferior to their own, were only too ready to receive them into their society, and too glad to be admitted into that of the natives. The European being a man of education and good breeding felt quite as much at ease in the society of the educated black man as in that of his brethren at home; he knew that his companion, though black, yet for all that, was a gentleman; and that was quite sufficient for him, and vice versa.

Now-a-days, things are not exactly the same. The white men of the ancient type certainly do visit this country and sojourn for a period, but they do not, as of old, make it their home. They make their money and are off again whence they came, or if they be Government officials their term of service expires and away they depart.

The English gentleman has been to a certain extent superseded by the English Gent, a distinct class too well known and too well described and caricatured by their own countrymen, to render a description necessary here.

These men, whom the rage for the rapid acquisition of wealth has induced to visit our parts, or others to send them here to acquire wealth for them, arrive imbued with ideas common to all ignorant men—that is to say, if beings whose minds have such a limited scope can be said to have any ideas of their own at all, and not picked up second-hand from others only a shade less ignorant than themselves.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1866#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AN AFRICAN TOUR IN THE CAMEROON MOUNTAIN DISTRICT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Once away in the forest, we took out some tobacco, and made ready so many leaves for each of several head-men that we should have to pass, and we determined at whose town we should sleep, and planned to walk quickly, without stopping, through each village, the interpreter and guide to shove the tobacco into the head-men's hands, and pass on, saying where we were going, and that we were in a hurry, as the day was drawing to a close. The guide and interpreter walked before, the carriers followed them, and I brought up the rear. I was compelled to do this all the way going, as otherwise the Kroo boys would have straggled behind or run away. By this arrangement we managed to pass through four villages without being stopped for a moment. After passing the largest of the four, some people came close up to me, calling the guide and interpreter to stop—that the tobacco was not enough. But they were well in advance, walking steadily on, and pretended not to hear. The people never supposed I heard, and so we escaped a palaver. About half-past four we got to Monyanga. There we were to stay the night, and the next morning, all being well, enter the country we had come to see. The head-man of Monyanga and his son were fine, friendly men; gave us two houses, took the whole care of providing and cooking food for us, and sent a man to show us the brook to wash. We were now really in the country interior to Rumby, rather more than half a day's walk from Balundu, which is the principal trading place of Yellow Duke of Calabar, and where that celebrated man was at the time. We were only two or three hours' walk from Ekumbi, the place we had been trying to reach, and on the direct road for the interior.

We were to the north of the mountain. On looking behind we saw it to the south of us. We were astonished to see that the posts of a new house that was being erected were well charred to about four inches above the ground. We asked why they did that, when they replied, "To make the posts last long; that when charred they would not cut." I had never seen this done by natives before, except in imitation of white men. Another peculiar thing we noticed was that a country rope was used to mark the line of the posts. The people said these things were their own customs, and they had not been taught by any one. My letter is too long already, so I must jump to the conclusion. At night the head-man and his son arranged that we should leave carriers and boxes with them, and, taking one box only, we should go, with a man they would give us, into Ekumbi, and as the place was large, there being three head-men, we should stay one night, and return the day after. The next morning we had to wait for breakfast, which was cooked for us by our host. When that was over, a private conference of a number of head-men from other places was held.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-10-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Reported Troubles in the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A recent telegram from Liverpool says that news received by the West African steamship Boma from the German colony of the Cameroons, which arrived in the Mersey on Nov. 11, shows that some serious disturbances have occurred there. The Boma left the Cameroons River on Oct. 11, at which date six chiefs had recently been sentenced to five years’ imprisonment, and were then awaiting transportation to the German Togo territory, which adjoins the Gold Coast. Some time ago trade in the Cameroons was so unsatisfactory that the traders, both English and German, formed a “conference,” and agreed to pay only certain prices to the Natives for produce. This agreement was maintained for some time, but appears to have been broken at last by one of the German houses. After this the Natives formed a “conference” against the traders, which one of the Natives broke in the same way by trading with an English house on the old terms. This Native and his people were seized by the other members of the “conference” and very badly treated, besides having everything in their canoes taken from them. Dr. Seitz, the Acting Governor, was administering the colony, and promptly had the offenders arrested. They included all the leading Natives of the place, and they were tried and found guilty of the offence charged against them. Three of them, including a king, were each fined a money payment, and six other chiefs were sentenced to five years’ imprisonment. The Natives of the place were in a state of great excitement. Governor Puttkamer arrived in the Cameroons just as the Boma left, and it was believed by the Natives that he would cancel the sentences on the chiefs. Although one of the reports said that the Natives would rise against the Germans and drive them out of the river, it was not believed by the English that anything of the kind would be attempted, as the Germans a few years ago gave the Natives a lesson of their strength which they are not likely to forget.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1896#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. These were strong statements, they would say, and required confirmation. If true, what could possibly have caused this frightful miscarriage of the noblest aspirations of a Christian people? The answer was simply the nature of their commerce with Africa in the past and present. To the slave and gin trades, and that in gunpowder and guns, must he ascribed the frightful evils they had brought upon the negro race, beside which the good they had tried to achieve was hardly discernible.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Recent Explorations in the Cameroons Interior', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Germans have lost no time in making themselves acquainted with the character and capacities of the territories which they have acquired in the Cameroons region and the country extending indefinitely into the interior. This is one of the few regions into which Europeans have not penetrated; the facilities which exist in other parts of Africa being almost entirely absent here. The coast population have hitherto resented all attempts of Europeans to communicate with the natives of the interior, as the latter would thus be able to dispense with their services as middlemen. Lieutenants Kund and Tappenbeck met with serious resistance, and both were wounded some time ago as they were pushing their way inland: indeed, the latter has succumbed to his sufferings. However, the German Colonial Administration determined to push on reconnoitring expeditions. With this task Dr. Zuitgraff was intrusted, and since 1886 he has made five exhibitions to the coast region, collecting information which has enabled him to organise an expedition into the far interior. He met with many difficulties from the natives, who were hostile to European intrusion, but succeeded in reaching Yola, on the Binué, and in pushing to a considerable distance to the east. Dr. Zuitgraff described the results of his expedition at a recent meeting of the Berlin Geographical Society. He started first at Christmas 1887, and founded various stations in the interior. He returned to the Cameroons early in the present year, and the information he brought back as to the character of the country is of great value geographically and commercially.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1890#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.649, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Germany and the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The text of the correspondence between the British and German Governments in regard to the respective spheres of action of the two nations on the West Coast of Africa was published on June 20 in the *Official Gazette*, almost simultaneously with the English Blue-book on the same subject. This is said to be almost the first time in which a publication of this nature has been made simultaneously by the two Governments.

A new steamer, to be placed at the service of the Governor of the Cameroons, was launched recently at Kiel, receiving the appropriate name of Nachtigal, in memory of the eminent pioneer of German colonization. She is a small yacht-like vessel, of the kind known as compass-ship. The ribs, beams, and all interior framework are of steel, the outer fencing being of teak with coppered bottom. The steamer has a compound engine of 180 indicated horse power, the estimated speed being ten and a half knots. The vessel was to be taken to the Cameroons last month.

A private letter recently received from an officer on board the Bismarck, at the Cameroons, confirms the English report that Admiral Knorr was kept prisoner for some time by the natives. The Admiral wished to make an alliance with the natives of Upper Cameroon, but was seized by the Abo negroes, and was not released till his men had recourse to severe reprisals. This happened about the middle of February. The Admiral then resolved to stop all traffic with the Abo negroes, who occupy the banks of the Yabiang, and to this end he sent a small steamer belonging to the firm of Wörmann, with about twenty men, to anchor at a point where the Yabiang flows into the Cameroon. The command of this steamer was entrusted to the writer of the letter. The blockade lasted till March 21, and all but the officer himself and one sailor were seized with fever, and had to be replaced. A small boat expedition was made up the Yabiang, and some canoes laden with oil were captured and sunk, and a few negroes were killed.

The reports brought by the corvette Olga from the West Coast of Africa contain gloomy accounts of the climate of the German settlements, and the health of Dr. Büchner, the German representative in the Cameroons, is reported to be severely tried.

The *Norddeutsche* recently published an official report of the situation of the German territory in the Cameroons, up to April 1. Peace has been restored there, and the German Captain Bendemann and the English Captain Young have fixed the frontier.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The National African Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The fifth ordinary general meeting of this company was held on June 30. Lord Aberdare presided, and in moving the adoption of the report, observed that the circumstances in which they held that meeting were somewhat exceptional, though not in any discouraging sense. During the past year many of their managers had been engaged in works of diplomacy and exploration, almost to the exclusion of commercial work. One reason would, doubtless, suffice to explain this state of things. They would remember that the eminent traveller, the late Dr. Nachtigal, was chosen by the German Government to take measures to satisfy the desire of the German people to found a colonial empire, and they might remember with what secrecy and expedition the measures of the German Government were taken, and how they contrived to anticipate the action of the English Government, and to take possession of the Cameroons. He was sure that no one would be jealous of a country so great as Germany, having so very small an amount of colonial possessions, pursuing a policy which we had so long followed, and with such marvellous success; but the lesson was one which could not be overlooked. The directors had felt that it was necessary to strengthen the position of the company in these rivers, and to prevent the action of any other foreign State from injuring a trade which they and those amalgamated with them had been creating, with so many years of labour and at so much cost. The result of their deliberations was that it was necessary to enter into treaties with the chiefs of all those portions of the Niger and the Binué with which they were then dealing, or with which they were likely to be dealing within any reasonable time; and in doing that they had not only extended their operations up those two rivers, but also laterally into the adjoining territories. They had formed treaties with nearly 100 potentates of various descriptions—some small, others rulers of kingdom, not inferior either in size or in population to second-rate European Powers. In the Binué especially they had travelled along the line of the principal stream, and had also discovered and navigated tributaries of very considerable extent, which had brought them into communication with regions previously unknown, and with people who, they had every reason to believe, would desire to trade with them. In these efforts, which they had been so suddenly called upon to make—instead of making them gradually, as would have been done in ordinary circumstances—very great demands had been made on their managers. Mr. David M'Intosh, their general agent in Africa, was selected by Her Majesty's Government to represent this country as Vice-Consul in those regions—a position which had added very much to his weight in dealing with the local chiefs. Lord Aberdare then referred to measures which had been taken, resulting in their having made arrangements with three other companies which had been in existence in the Binué in the last three years.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-06-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1885#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Climate of the West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'But, as a rule, the most healthy, because the most industrious, of white residents in Western Africa, including the Gold Coast, are Englishmen, Americans, Germans, and Dutchmen. Commander V. L. Cameron, who is at this present moment on the Gold Coast, in company with Captain R. F. Burton, has told us that last year, when surveying the Akankoo concession, he worked for days together up to his middle in water, and lived! Captain Burton himself, in a letter written in February last to the directors of the Guinea Coast Gold Mining Company, speaking of Apollonia, says "During the hot hours the doctor—that is, the sea breeze—blows freshly; the evening temperature is delicious, and during the cool dewy nights we found blankets necessary."

I visited all the mines then being worked, and saw upwards of thirty Europeans, of various nationalities, who both worked and lived. I also saw very large numbers of natives, as well as several hundreds of Kroomen, who worked regularly, both day and night, at the mines, and in transporting heavy machinery and other goods from Axim to the different mines at and near Takwah. I travelled partly by hammock, partly by boat and canoe, as well as on foot, over Wassaw, Egwira, Apollonia, Axim, and Apatim, meeting hundreds of native carriers transporting provisions, pieces of heavy machinery, and other articles, by road and river, without overseers, and by whose means, aided by Kroomen, everything now at the mines had been carried there, with little loss by accident or theft. I slept in native huts without doors or fastenings; and at Axim, my bedroom door and windows remained open day and night; yet the whole extent of my loss by theft, during six months, was one plated table-fork stolen on board a steam launch! Surely this does not look as though the "natives cannot be induced to work," or that "the people are debased beyond conception." On the contrary, having visited most places between Gorée and the Congo, I am happy to state that I found the natives of the Western Province of the Gold Coast Colony exceptionally honest for negroes. As to work, we all know that the negro has no abstract love of labour, but he can and will work for gain—and work well. Moreover whenever it may become necessary, Coolies in any number can be imported from China and India, and this is already under consideration.

Roads can be made, and kept in order, where the traffic is sufficiently great to counteract the rapidity of vegetable growth incidental to a tropical climate; and here again I may quote Captain Burton's letter, in which he says: "A good line was cut from the village to the concession. A 'sulky' could easily have been driven along it."', 'last_edit_date': '1882-04-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1882#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GERMANS IN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The development of the German colony in the Cameroons has arrived at a turning-point. Either the entire administration and commerce of the Colony must be placed on a broader basis, and then a prosperous development of the Colony in every direction is expected with certainty; or the old course is kept up, and then the Colony will meet with unavoidable ruin. According to the present system the Colony must cover all its administrative expenses from the current receipts. These receipts consist, almost exclusively, in the duties levied at the coast. The income of the duty increases and decreases with the commerce in the Colony. German trade in Cameroons, however, is going backward, in consequence of the falling of prices for African products and of the trading monopoly of the tribes on the coast, which more than doubles, often quintuples, the price of the goods from the interior, thereby limiting the intercourse of the coast with the interior. If this continues, the end can easily be foreseen. The Colony will be less capable to recoup its costs of administration—it will require more and more support from the Empire and yet it will not improve. hh: The people of the Gold Coast sought to integrate traditional governance structures into the colonial system by advocating for participatory governance and involving local leaders in decision-making.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a comprehensive view of the efforts by the people of the Gold Coast to integrate traditional governance structures into the colonial system by advocating for participatory governance and involving local leaders in decision-making. The General History of Africa highlights initiatives such as the transformation of the Okwahuman Council into a representative body of chiefs and commoners, and the actions of the Kwahu asafo company, which compelled the Omanhene of Kwahu to sign a document regulating political and economic affairs, later ratified as the Magna Carta. These efforts illustrate a push for participatory governance and the involvement of local leaders. The establishment of the United Gold Coast Convention, representing a rapprochement between new and traditional elites, further supports this claim. However, challenges such as the colonial administration's tendency to cultivate conflict between traditional and new elites, and the imposition of indirect rule, which often subordinated local leaders to colonial authorities, are also noted. Similarly, The African Times articles document petitions from local kings, chiefs, and headmen to colonial authorities, expressing dissatisfaction with the lack of representation in decision-making processes and the imposition of taxes and ordinances without their input. These petitions requested the appointment of representatives and the formation of municipal councils, indicating a desire for participatory governance. References to the Fanti Confederation as a potential organization for native governance suggest an interest in integrating traditional structures into the colonial framework. Nonetheless, the articles also highlight challenges such as the imposition of colonial authority over traditional practices and the lack of acknowledgment of local leaders' authority. Together, these sources provide evidence of the efforts by the people of the Gold Coast to involve local leaders in governance, while also illustrating the significant obstacles they faced within the colonial system.

Kwahu assembled at Abetifi, summoned the Omanhene of Kwahu to the meeting and forced him to sign a document which they had already prepared consisting of rules 'regulating political and economic affairs in the state'. In 1917, this document was formally ratified by the Kwahu State Council and became known later as the Magna Carta.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Politics and nationalism in West Africa, 1919-35', 'section_title': 'Politics and nationalism in British West Africa > Rural politics or rural mass nationalism in the inter-war period', 'content': "Let me illustrate this theme from the results of the limited research that has been conducted so far in Ghana.$^{17}$ The inter-war period was characterized in the Gold Coast, as in the other British colonies in West Africa, by the establishment and consolidation of the system of indirect rule in the rural areas through the introduction of a number of ordinances and acts - the Native Jurisdiction Amendment Ordinance of 1910, the Guggisberg Constitution of 1925, the Native Administration Ordinance of 1927 and the Native Administration Revenue Bill of 1931. Economically, the era saw the alternation of periods of boom with those of recession and inflation - the latter in 1915-17, 1929-30 and the second half of the 1930s. It also saw the spread of the cocoa industry into the rural areas especially of Akuapem and Akyem Abuakwa which led to the emergence of an increasing number of rich young farmers and long-distance traders. Socially, the period also saw the spread of elementary education into the rural areas and while some of the products of these schools drifted into the urban centres, others stayed behind and took to either farming or petty trading. With all these changes in their socio› economic status, these rural people began to demand a corresponding change in their political status and especially representation on the state and provincial councils, a demand which the ordinances mentioned above made steadily impossible. The principal objectives of the rural folk, then, were to acquire representation on these councils and, above all, to curb the increasing powers of their traditional rulers and the district commis› sioners and abolition or reduction of some of the fines and taxes being imposed by them.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': "'Native policy'", 'content': "Although there was initially no universally accepted approach to colonial administration in Africa, most lines of thought converged on what might be called conjunctive administration (usually termed indirect rule); that which joined African authorities, in traditionally-held or European-imposed political roles, to the colonial government, but in an obviously subordinate capacity. The reasons for general concurrence on this broad principle of rule are varied. First, the historical pattern of late nineteenth-century colonial acquisition was a formative factor, as size alone added a new dimension to the problem of colonial rule. Secondly the internal penetration of Africa rapidly outpaced the numbers of European personnel available to administer the newly possessed lands. Furthermore, since such penetration extended into many regions yet untouched by European cultural contact, direct rule of any kind would have been an entirely new experience and therefore immediately unworkable. Primarily as a result of these conditions, previously noted by several critics,$^{4}$ the direct rule characteristic of the smaller possessions on the coast gave way to the indirect rule of the larger possessions in the interior. Furthermore, at the turn of the century, the collapse of rule by chartered companies necessitated the establishment of national control over weakly held extensive territories. Indeed, every colonial power in Black Africa depended on the chief, whether traditional or warrant in authority, as the basic element of the administrative structure. The French colonial administrator, Robert Delavignette, explained the nature of the system succinctly, and in a way applicable to more than the French West African situation, when he wrote: 'There is no colonization without native policy; no native policy without a territorial command; and no territorial command without native chiefs who serve as links between the colonial authority and the population.' 8 Although no observer or critic has doubted that chiefly activities were integral to the colonial system throughout the continent, there has been a considerable academic debate about the uses to which the various European powers put these chiefs.$^{9}$ The major question has centred on the difference between direct and indirect rule, between delegation of European authority to the African rulers and European mediation of traditional authority enjoyed by these rulers. While most scholarly interest has been directed to the distinction between the British and French modes of control in sub-Saharan Africa, where procedures, if not ultimate effects, were distinctive, the issue is perhaps best placed in historical perspective by a general review of continental policy, but with special attention still given to the activities of the British and French.
The most famous explanation of the importance of the 'native authority' to the colonial order was that of Lugard, who encased in theory the most discussed and imitated method of domination: indirect rule. But such a conclusion was also supported by his belief, which had already been formed during his earlier service in Uganda, that the use of existing indigenous institutions was the best method of colonial administration. [{'id': 491, 'article_title': 'ANAMABOE', 'full_section_title': 'ANAMABOE', 'last_edit_date': '11-07-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_12_1864', 'content': "To his Excellency Richard Pine, Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Her Majesty's Forts and Settlements on the Gold Coast.

The humble petition of the undersigned King, Chiefs, Headmen, and other inhabitants of Anamaboe, sheweth—

That your petitioners, not being British subjects, but considered as being merely under British protection, as it has been latterly demonstrated to the natives of the Gold Coast by the Home Government, through your Excellency, beg to be heard on the subject of the late ordinance, relating to the sale of spirits and other drinks, so suddenly imposed on the dealers of the country, without at least the necessary considerations which would otherwise make this taxation tolerable.

That your petitioners, forbearing to enter into other details that render the introduction and expediency of such an ordinance questionable, would simply for the present offer to your Excellency's consideration the following circumstances, under which any further compliance with colonial taxation seems hard and uneasy.

That this imposition seems to have for its object, not the benefit of the country at large, but the replenishing of colonial finances.

That more than one of these taxes have been heretofore imposed upon and willingly borne by your petitioners, with the direct understanding that the country was to have been benefited by them.

That, regardless of sweet and conciliatory promises of improvement held out to them by your Excellency's predecessors, as inducement to their paying these taxes, not even so much as accounts thereof have ever been published, much less any improvement made as far as it regards this place.

That many heavy fines have been in like manner imposed upon certain of the inhabitants of this place—in some instances amounting to 100 ounces and upwards—which fines were never accounted for, except that the money went into the colonial chest, and appropriated anyhow but rightly.

That when your Excellency called a general meeting at Cape Coast lately, your Excellency's petitioners understood certain suggestions to have been properly made by your Excellency, as to how they could protect their country and benefit the land; and, consequently, your Excellency's petitioners expected no additional burdens, but rather a voice which should direct them how to proceed to that end, by appointing representatives, instituting municipal councils, and forming other useful means, which might conduce to the improvement of the country, as Sir Benjamin Pine proposed, and also bringing the native kings, chiefs, and people into a union, which would make the country strong, and advance the interests and enlightenment of the people, as well as accommodate the wishes of the local Government.

That the native magistrates and the councillors here are not, and never were, your petitioners' chosen nor recognised representatives, supposing your Excellency to have consulted these personages in order to the passing of the ordinance."}, {'id': 939, 'article_title': 'Copy of Petition of the King, Chiefs, Headmen, &c., on the Gold Coast, to the Governor-General', 'full_section_title': 'Copy of Petition of the King, Chiefs, Headmen, &c., on the Gold Coast, to the Governor-General', 'last_edit_date': '09-01-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1866#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_10_1866', 'content': "Cape Coast, September, 1866.

_To his Excellency Major Blackall, Governor-General and Commander-in-Chief of Her Majesty's Colony of Sierra Leone and Forts and Settlements on the Gold Coast of Africa._

The humble Petition of the undersigned King, Chiefs, Headmen, and other Residents on the Gold Coast under the British Protection,  
Humbly sheweth,

That your petitioners, having taken into consideration the present unsatisfactory state of affairs on the Gold Coast, and of Cape Coast in particular, arising from the present mal-administration on this Coast, have unanimously resolved to address your Excellency with the view of drawing your Excellency's attention to the same.

That your petitioners sincerely deplore the undignified ill-treatment to which his Excellency Colonel Conran has at various times subjected the King of Cape Coast. On the occurrence of a vacancy, from whatever cause, in this place, a King is elected, by the suffrages of the majority of the people; and John Aggery, on the last occasion of such vacancy, was so elected, by those who had a right so to do; and this election was confirmed by the then Governor."}, {'id': 5348, 'article_title': 'Colonial and Indian Exhibition', 'full_section_title': 'Colonial and Indian Exhibition', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1886#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_04_1886', 'content': "It is now officially announced that this Exhibition will be opened on Tuesday, May 4th, when the ceremony will be performed by Her Majesty.

**Executive Commissioner.**—Sir James Marshall, Richmond House, Roehampton, S.W.

**Committee.**—The Right Hon. Lord Aberdare, G.C.B., Chairman (Royal Commissioner); A. W. L. Swanzy, Esq., Vice-President of the West African Trade Section of the London Chamber of Commerce; E. G. Banner, Esq., Member of the West African Trade Section Committee of the London Chamber of Commerce; T. Riseley Griffith, Esq., Colonial Secretary, Sierra Leone; W. H. ### XXIV.—WEST AFRICA SETTLEMENTS.

#### COMMISSION IN SIERRA LEONE.

**Sherbro District.**—The Commandant (for the time being); J. B. Wright, Esq., J.P.; W. H. Davison, Esq.; J. A. Williams, Esq.; J. T. Alldridge, Esq.

**2nd Eastern and Quiah Districts.**—W. M. Huggins, Esq., J.P.

**Western District.**—J. M. Metzger, Esq., J.P.; Secretary—Enoch Faulkner, Esq.

#### COMMISSION IN GAMBIA.

**President.**—His Excellency C. A. Moloney, C.M.G., Administrator.

**Commissioners at Bathurst.**—The Hon. James Topp; the Hon. J. D. Richards; C. Beving, Esq.; E. Allegre, Esq.; H. C. Goddard, Esq.; A. Dubois, Esq.; T. B. Evans, Esq.; G. Verdier, Esq.; S. J. Roche, Government Secretary; Dr. W. Allan, Assistant Colonial Surgeon.

### XXV.—GOLD COAST.

#### COMMISSION AT ACCRA.

**Committee.**—John Pagan, Esq., Colonial Surveyor; Dr. Easmon; P. Schindler, Esq.; Edmund Bannerman, Esq.; G. Gauger, Esq.; G. F. Cleland, Esq.

**Native Committee.**—King Tackie, Chief Ajauben Ankrah, Chief John Quartey, Chief Ackromah.

### XXVI.—LAGOS.

**Committee at Lagos.**—Mr. Justice Smalman Smith, Chairman; Mr. Consul Hood; Mr. Consul Heldbek; C. J. George, Esq.; J. D. Fairley, Esq., Secretary; A. R. Elliott, Esq.; J. J. Thomas, Esq.; J. A. Payne, Esq.; W. Shitta, Esq.; G. W. Neville, Esq."}]

A decision must be arrived at sooner or later. Let it be arrived at now, or we shall be drifting into Gold Coast complications of a serious and disgraceful kind. The present of a wide territory and its people is endangered—their future is at stake; further hesitation will be criminal.", 'last_edit_date': '1873-01-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Chiefs and Kings of the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The interest which your journal has always taken in the affairs of West Africa induces me to solicit a space for the insertion of this article, which I trust will not fail to lead to an amelioration of the state of things, by its being brought to the knowledge of those whom it concerns.

One of the results of the Ashanti Campaign was to bring the countries on the Gold Coast under the control or protection of the British Government. The countries on the sea-coast are divided into districts, to each of which a Commissioner is appointed by the Governor. The interior countries, however, are not thus provided for, but are left to be ruled by their chiefs and kings, as formerly. The authority of these kings and chiefs was not formally acknowledged, and any offence which, according to custom, is visited with severe punishment, is immediately reported to the Government authorities on the sea-coast; and the chieftain or king who ordered the punishment is brought before the Court and treated as the commonest fellow.

This action on the part of the Government terrifies and paralyzes a good many of these chiefs and kings, so that in a great many instances the wicked go unpunished. On the other hand, others use the name of the Government to acquire territories which they have not the least right to. Amongst these I may mention the name of one "Sakiaty," who is of great notoriety in Eastern Croboe, interior of Accra. This man was a chief of Odumase, a country of Eastern Croboe, before the Ashanti Campaign, but immediately after the war, he assumed the authority and title of king, which he said was vested in him by Sir John Glover for the valuable services he rendered in the war. Not contented with the throne which he has thus usurped, he is now intriguing to acquire Western Croboe also. The present king of Western Croboe, who is now being molested, forbears to say anything, lest his opposition may end in a contest, and he may be thereby brought to the sea-coast and treated with ignominy. But there is sure to come a successor who will dispute every inch of ground that "Sakiaty" has thus acquired. This will undoubtedly end in strife, when people will have the mortification again to see that their royalties are treated contemptuously by those who are their protectors. If the present system of government in the interior countries is to continue, I would, Sir, respectfully recommend that the following plans be carried out: (1) that every chieftain or king in the interior should prove his claim; (2) that the right of government by native chiefs and kings in the interior, so far as it is compatible with common sense and humanity, be proclaimed as supported by the British authorities on the sea-coast; and (3), that any unnecessary interference and aggression of one chief or king with another, be met with the highest displeasure of the Governor.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_08_1880#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CAPE COAST IMBROGLIO.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The chief Coast authority has at last appeared upon the scene. We were delighted when we heard he was to do so. Now, at least, we shall all understand what the Government really intends to do. King Aggery has been deposed, the native town courts have been abolished, there has been a real exercise of sovereignty over the town of Cape Coast, and the Governor-General will no doubt give us the key to all this; the natives will know whether they are regarded as British subjects or not; their future position and rights will be defined and explained, and the earnest solicitude of Her Majesty's Government for the welfare and progress of the people will most satisfactorily appear. The eventful day arrived. A general meeting was convened at Government-house on the 4th April. The authorities and people assembled. The Governor-General commenced by stating that "there is to be a very great change in the Government at Cape Coast Castle." We have given his Excellency's speech among our Cape Coast news; and we think our readers will agree with us that a more inconclusive and unsatisfactory address, regard being had to the peculiar state of affairs in the Protected Territories at the present time, never emanated from a superior authority. We shall not open up the whole question this month, because the Governor-General was to return to Cape Coast for a day or two, and it is possible that he may have then supplied the grave omissions in his former address. That address contains three salient points. First, the nomination of a head man by the Governor, instead of, as from time immemorial, the election of a King by the chiefs and people. Second, an assurance that they were under a mistake to think that the Government of those parts will ever be transferred to any native power. (We merely en passant beg to ask how far this agrees with the recommendation of the late Parliamentary Committee.) Third, that they should know what they were to expect in return for obedience to Her Majesty's laws. Now No. 1 was an accomplished fact; just or unjust, there it stood plainly and palpably before the assembly; for Quashie Attab, the head man so nominated, was there to be sworn in, and was sworn in to office before the assembly broke up. No. 2 was an authoritative declaration of very high importance no doubt, if the Governor-General was empowered to make it, and if it had been accompanied by those explanations which such an altered state of things absolutely required. But No. 3 was a promise which, if fulfilled, would have enabled every one to understand his true position vis-à-vis the British authorities, would have shown his duties and privileges, and cleared up all those doubts which, especially since 1865, have overshadowed the Gold Coast. But only in West African affairs could there have been so absurd a sequence as that to which Governor Blackall then treated the people. The great revelation of what they were to expect resolved itself into what was expected from them; for surely it did not need the presence of a supreme authority to tell them that they could appeal to him or Her Majesty's Government if they think fit; and yet this, and the assurance that in case of any opposition they would be prosecuted in the British courts of law, was all the revelation made to them of "what they are to expect in return for obedience to Her Majesty's laws." As we have before said, we refrain from comment until we know what supplementary revelations the Governor-in-Chief may have made during his second visit, of which we shall have news by the next mail; only remarking meanwhile that his communication to the people, so far as we yet know of it, must be considered by them about as satisfactory as was that of Rehoboam to the chiefs and people of Israel on his accession to the throne of his father Solomon. Governor Blackall will certainly never rank as the Solomon of the Coast; but he may be the Rehoboam if he proceeds in his present arbitrary and insulting policy, which seems to us to have no redeeming point as regards the people placed under his superintendence. "I did not come to have a palaver; I came to lay down my law" would be very fine, no doubt, from a great man and a conqueror, but is not what we expect from a Governor-General of the West Coast, as representing the Christian Government of Great Britain.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Popular Aspirations on the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A small Parliamentary paper recently issued contains reports from the Governor of the Gold Coast Settlements to Lord Knutsford on a tour made by the former in the eastern districts of his government. In the various places to which he went Sir B. Griffith collected around him native chiefs and merchants, in order to hear from themselves their views and wishes. At Pram Pram, the King, an old man, wanted nothing save to be allowed to revive an old custom, part of which consisted in the exhumation of the dead. At Big Awoonah the chief sent a friendly message, which the Governor acknowledged with a present of half a sovereign and two bottles of champagne. At Addah there was an important meeting; the people there wanted a road to the beach, a school, stipends to the chiefs, the reduction of the duty on rum to 1s. a gallon, wells, a public bell to mark the time, a free ferry across the Volta River, and a warehouse on the beach. hh: King Theodore's insistence on direct royal communication in diplomatic negotiations highlights his pursuit of equal recognition and respect from European powers.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles both provide insights into King Theodore's insistence on direct royal communication in diplomatic negotiations, highlighting his pursuit of equal recognition and respect from European powers. The textbook details Theodore's proactive efforts to engage directly with European leaders, such as his letters to Queen Victoria and Emperor Napoleon III, where he proposed sending embassies and sought technical assistance. His frustration with Britain's lack of response and the perceived slight to his royal dignity further underscores his desire for equal recognition. Theodore's actions, including sending gifts and attempting to negotiate directly with European representatives, reflect his pursuit of direct communication and acknowledgment. However, the textbook also notes the challenges he faced, such as Britain's reluctance to engage and the shifting diplomatic landscape, complicating his efforts. The African Times articles support this claim by highlighting an instance where King Theodore, upon receiving a letter from the British Queen delivered by Mr. Bassam, remarked that "Kings ought to write to kings, but no subordinates," emphasizing the importance of direct communication between monarchs. This statement aligns with his desire for equal recognition, though the articles lack further details on how this insistence impacted his broader diplomatic relations, a gap that historians might find significant. Together, these sources illustrate Theodore's insistence on being treated as an equal by European powers through direct diplomatic engagement.

P. Badger, of Bayswater, under date, Massowa, Nov. 4, saying that he had heard of the safe arrival of his messenger at Gondar, and was therefore quite at a loss to know why no answer had been sent to him; but that having despatched another letter, he was daily expecting permission to go up. He then adds: "A rebellion, headed by a chief named Tissoo Gabazai, had broken out in different parts of the country, and it is not improbable that this circumstance may have rendered the roads unsafe towards the coast. So great, moreover, is the dread of the King's displeasure, that Abyssinians arriving from the interior scrupulously avoid all intercourse with Europeans. Hence it is very difficult to obtain any reliable information respecting the state of things at Gondar, and every attempt to communicate privately with Captain Cameron and the other British captives has proved unsuccessful. It appears that our unfortunate countrymen are confined in a tent next to that of the King, and all intercourse with them is strictly forbidden under the severest penalties. Besides this vigilant watch, each European is chained to a trustworthy dependent of the royal household, the latter being relieved at short intervals. The chain is never more than four feet long, so that the prisoner can scarcely move without the knowledge of the guard, and vice versa." Mr. Bassam finished by expressing his determination to go up to Gondar, should there be the most distant hope of his obtaining an interview with King Theodorus.

The Bengal Hurkuru, published at Calcutta, November 12, says:—

"King Theodore, we learn, on the receipt of Her Majesty the Queen's letter, delivered to him by Mr. Bassam, relative to the release of the European gentlemen confined in Abyssinia, remarked, 'Kings ought to write to kings, but no subordinates' (governors). He, however, immediately ordered the release of the Europeans, and loaded them with presents. Her Majesty's steamer Pantaloon will perhaps bring back the Abyssinian mission to Aden."

We are sure our readers will feel, with us, that there is great difficulty in reconciling these two statements. Either there must be error as regards the date of the letter sent to Mr. Badger, or the news published by the Bengal paper is not authentic. We trust, however, that it is authentic, and that the British Consul and the missionaries have been released. "Mr. Flad and the German artisans are reported to have interceded for the release of the prisoners. Theodorus at first consented, but subsequently withdrew his promise, stating that he could not release them until he had received a reply from the Queen of England.

Your words are true, Sir, about our land being at one time covered with darkness and idolatry; but, through the help and teaching which have come from you English, and from the French also—(hear, hear)—we have struggled to leave our ignorance behind us, and have come to the foot of civilization's ladder. We are no longer lying asleep in the mire below—(hear, hear)—and I tell you most truly, gentlemen, that our ambition is to climb that ladder, and that we fail to see what right any other nation has to prevent us from climbing higher. (Cheers.) Whatever of good that is brought to us by foreigners we receive with gladness, and we desire that good should come to us in greater abundance. King Ja Ja, so far from attempting to monopolize the trade, has been fighting the battle of the native traders, his subjects. It is all a question of getting rid of the middleman. When trade is depressed the buyer wishes to deal directly with the seller, without the intervention of a broker. King Ja Ja and his merchants are the brokers between the producers of palm oil in the interior and the merchants who export the oil from the coast. The European traders wish to trade direct, just as we natives would like to trade direct with the manufacturers in this country. But we are not allowed; for we are compelled to submit to the brokerage charges of English middlemen. The European merchants on the coast consented to pay brokerage or commission to King Ja Ja for all oil which they bought from him, but they refused to pay commission to the native merchants, who were doing business side by side with the King. When King Ja Ja, relying upon the good faith of the Consul, came to the meeting, he was arrested and carried away to the Gold Coast, where he still remains, surrounded by people who cannot speak his own language, and unable to communicate his grievances to those who are sitting in judgment upon him. Consul Johnston has trampled under foot the rights of treaties, and even the ordinary usages of savage nations, in his arrest of a protected King, who accepted his apparently friendly invitation only to find himself made a prisoner and carried away from his own country. This is not honest, neither is it honest the way in which Consul Johnston goes on suppressing my trade, for instance (said one member of the deputation), and saying that he does so because of orders from home. "It is only by constant and frequent communication with Ashantee and other barbarous tribes that we can hope to bring about that state of things that will redound to the honour of England, and I have often wondered why the chief of the executive here has not attempted some effective means for this end. I would suggest the following: Let a well-paid consular agent be stationed at Kumasi,* with Prince Ansah† as interpreter; let their salary be in keeping with England's dignity, and I imagine schools and other missionary work would then commence in earnest in Ashantee. Let a trial be made for five years, and mark the result.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1867-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1867#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PRINCE BISMARCK AND PEACE DIPLOMACY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'During the visit of Prince Bismarck to Vienna, he said, in reference to the aims which should chiefly influence the policy of modern diplomacy and statesmanship—"What is a statesman's duty? He must see the danger of war approaching and get out of its way. He must know whether a ditch is too broad to be jumped. Yes; I regard it as the highest political aim, that peace should be maintained. Where shall we get to, if we wage a successful war, and then have two neighbours incessantly dreaming of revenge?"

These are remarkable words from the German ex-Chancellor, whose term of office was characterised by some of the most awful of modern wars.

For certainly they are very wise, and they will long serve as an authoritative quotation in support of the extension and expediency of international arbitration and conciliation. They furnish a decisive rejoinder to those persons who are apt to retort upon the advocates of peace that their views are not practical, or are not in accordance with the requirements of actual diplomacy. For here is a man, who for years stood at the very head of the world's statesmanship, and the result of his experience is that he now urges it as a paramount duty for every statesman to avert the dangers of war and to make peace his "highest political aim."

What society has ever spoken more emphatically than the great ex-Chancellor has thus done? These words contribute a weighty dictum for acceptation throughout the world. The Editor of the _Neue Freie Presse_, after listening to Bismarck's words, remarked that he left the Prince "with the impression of having looked history in the face." Yes, truly, and history, in the person of Bismarck, has now given this memorable verdict on the side of the peacemakers.

For the ex-Chancellor's words involve the increased direction of statesmanship to the object of preparing such embodiments of international law, and facilities for the extension of international arbitration, as may be needful for the special object of "getting out of the way of war," and obviating such conquests as compel neighbouring States to be "incessantly dreaming of revenge." Prince Bismarck would lay the world under deep obligation if he could associate with the weight and influence of his own name any feasible scheme for the solution of this continuing peril to international peace.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1892#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'European Conduct and Morality on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I trust you will allow me the indulgence of a word or two in your valuable columns; I will endeavor they shall be as short as possible. CURRIE.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.606, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EUROPEAN AFFAIRS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'JUNE 20.—The first great result of the efforts of Count Schouvaloff was that a form of invitation to a Congress, which could be accepted by both Great Britain and Russia if issued by the German Government, was agreed upon. In due time this invitation to Berlin was issued, and accepted by all the European Powers who were signatories to the Treaty of Paris. The Council was summoned to meet on the 13th June, and on that day it duly assembled at the Old Radziwill Palace, in Berlin, which has been recently restored and fitted as a residence for Prince Bismarck. To the great astonishment of the majority of the British people, it was first rumoured, and subsequently officially announced, that the British Plenipotentiaries were to be the Premier, the Earl of Beaconsfield, and the Marquis of Salisbury, Her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, to be assisted by Lord Odo Russell, the British Ambassador at the German Court. The unadvisability of the simultaneous absence from London of the Premier and the Foreign Secretary, and that during the sitting of Parliament, was justly and freely animadverted upon even by some of the deeply pledged adherents of the Ministry on the Eastern Question; while, on the other hand, it was almost asserted that so much of a mutual understanding between the divers European Courts had been arrived at, that the entire work of the Council would probably be concluded in three or four sittings, and Great Britain have back her Premier, chaplet on brow, to be displaced only by a ducal coronet that should adorn his distinguished head, and realize, we may suppose, the loftiest height of his ambitious dreams. The Plenipotentiaries meet, as proposed, on the 13th June. On the 14th, the Globe, an evening paper, came out in London with certain columns headed "Full Text of the Anglo-Russian Agreement," the details of which in English and in the original French, and signed "Schouvaloff" and "Salisbury," it prefaced with the following words: "The Berlin Congress having assembled, there is no longer any reason for our withholding the full text of the agreement between the Governments of England and Russia, signed at the Foreign Office on the 30th May," &c., &c. This publication, seemingly considered opportune by the editor of a paper which had always supported the Beaconsfield Cabinet on the Eastern Question, was regarded as the very adverse of opportune by the members of that Cabinet. Great trouble was in the camp of the Ministerial and War party; and it seemed almost as if with the latter the Earl of Beaconsfield had become "the demon" instead of "the quasi-divine." And yet although "the independence and integrity of the Ottoman Empire" was no longer to be a stumbling-block in the way of pacific arrangement, the agreement manifested a full determination on the part of the British Cabinet to uphold to the fullest extent that might be possible pacifically, a Turkish Empire in Europe.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-06-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1878#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.601, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Coronation of a Chief at Little Popoe', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In the first place I pray God that he would be pleased to give you wisdom and understanding to walk and act wisely in all things, and incline the heart of all in favour towards you and you towards them. I would advise you, my dear brother, first of all to endeavour to cultivate peace and friendship at home among yourselves and abroad.

Second.—Let honesty and fair dealings be the rule of the day, as well as truthfulness in all your sayings and actions.

Third.—Cultivation of the earth for saleable productions should be the engagement of all in the country, by which the riches of the country will be increased, and that abominable traffic, slave dealing, will be forgotten, which trade should not be countenanced, but considered dead and gone.

Fourth.—Let no European whatever suffer unjustly or be illtreated in any of our territories, but ample protection be rendered to them against any man or woman. In doing this remember and bear in mind that the English nation and their subjects should share the greatest part, and be considered the lion among you, for they are the truest and best of friends we have among European nations, from our grandfather Latty's day up to ours and our children, as it is at present.

Fifth.—Let none of our sisters cry for want.

Sixth.—Be not partial in your dealings between man and man in judgment.

Seventh.—Let schools be established for the education of the rising generation, not only for our children, as has been the policy of our late father, but for the general benefit of the whole country. In this myself and children here are quite willing and ready to assist. I need not say anything more at present till I hear how you are settled. I hope soon to hear that yourself and my relatives at Abguay are united in peace and goodwill one toward another.

I have heard with deep regret of the death of my sister Kawasoo. It grieves me to my heart, but what can I say but that God has so allotted it? I was much rejoiced to learn that our eldest sister, your mother's daughter, is still alive. I don't know whether I should be permitted by God to see you all again in the flesh, but if it is the Lord's will we shall see each other; this we must leave in the hands of the Lord. The only thing I would ask at your hand, and at the hands of our people, whether you hear that I am alive or dead, is protection for the British nation and people. Let none of them think or feel themselves strangers in any portion of Little Popoe Land. My love to you, our brothers, our sisters, and all our countrymen. You will hear from me again; farewell. Our brother Frederick, who is here with me, begs to be remembered to you all. Your affectionate eldest brother, who absent from home forty-four years this year, (Signed) THOMAS G. LAWSON.

Mr. Boivie Lawson, or now George Acquaitay Lawson, present Chief of Little Popoe, New London.", 'last_edit_date': '1870-01-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_01_1870#article-24', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.596, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sir Claude Macdonald', 'section_title': '', 'content': "(From the London Gazette.)_

People feel jealous of being advised by foreigners; they feel that there is an assumption of superiority of wisdom and virtue; and selfish motives are attributed to the advisers. Now, I venture to think that this objection does not apply in the slightest degree to the meeting to-day. Some eighteen months ago her Majesty's Government made a proposal, not that we should go and teach other countries what was to be done about the slave trade, but assuming that all European nations are now inclined to carry out principles which have been proclaimed both by treaty and international communications for some seventy-five years. As against the slave trade, the Government felt that the moment had come when other countries desired to give practical effect to that policy. Lord Salisbury selected perhaps the individual who was best qualified for the duty to preside over the Conference of European Powers. I therefore accepted the invitation to come here with very great pleasure. I received a little shock when I saw in the newspapers that objections were made to our meeting by a society for which I have the very greatest possible respect—that important historical society, the Anti-Slavery Society. It is now more than fifty years ago, very soon after the Aborigines' Protection Society was established, that I entered office under Lord Palmerston. The strongest political feeling Lord Palmerston had was his horror of the slave trade, and his determination to put it down, and no one who was not in the Foreign Office at the time with him could hardly be aware of the immense amount of energy and labour he devoted to the attainment of that object. Under these circumstances I was naturally in communication with the Anti-Slavery Society—and I have at times been in communication with it ever since. I say that any objection from the Anti-Slavery Society, or any communication from it, would come with great authority. I own that if the objection taken had been that our objects were unworthy, I should have been very much shaken. But it is not so; they agree with us entirely in thinking that this question of the supply of arms to the slave-traders and the question of the supply of alcohol to a great multitude of the African population is one of the most serious and dangerous importance. Their objection rests on a question of tactics. They think that there are two questions already brought before the Conference of vital importance, and that they might be endangered by any other question being raised there at all. But on this question I am not sure that the Anti-Slavery Society speak with greater authority than any other body of men. What is our position here? You have heard the first resolution. Other resolutions to be proposed will set out the prominent causes of the mischief, and the final resolution will be "That copies of the foregoing resolutions be forwarded to his Majesty the King of the Belgians, the president of the International Conference, her Majesty's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, and her Majesty's Minister at the Belgian Court." There is nothing compulsory in that, and if Lord Salisbury and the King of the Belgians and Lord Vivian are of opinion that no new subject should be brought before the Conference, supposing they think it better to keep these resolutions a little in the background, in what way can our recommendations of today interfere with such a decision? If, they think that these subjects are so closely interweaved that they would not interfere with the general consent of the European Powers. I venture to think that it would strengthen the hands of Lord Salisbury and Lord Vivian, that a meeting under the presidency of the Lord Mayor had passed these resolutions. I said that it was a wise step to ask the King of the Belgians to take the initiative in this matter of the Conference. I think that it is impossible not to recognise why he has the greatest claims and qualifications for the task. In recent years we have seen men of great wealth making magnificent contributions to objects of philanthropy. The King of the Belgians has this pleasant characteristic, but none of the contributions approached in wideness of scope those of the King of the Belgians. We see what he has done, for instance, by the creation of the Congo State. He has not only given time and most anxious care to the affairs of the State—his contributions in a pecuniary sense are perfectly enormous. The official returns show the cost to be about £70,000 a year, and the whole comes from the King of the Belgians, not as Sovereign, but as a private individual from his private means. I have reason to believe that hundreds of thousands beyond that have been spent by him in this great work, and I think it is satisfactory that the King of the Belgians accepted the presidency of the Conference, the object of which is to give practical effect to principles which have really been sanctioned by the whole of Europe for some seventy-five years. I think it is becoming that this meeting we should commence operations by giving a vote of thanks to the King of the Belgians for the part he has taken in this important affair. He hoped the next mail would bring good news from the seat of war in South Africa.", 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1879#article-24', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.596, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE EARL OF DERBY ON THE COLONIES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Tuesday, January 16, the Earl of Derby received a deputation from the principal British Colonies, at the Colonial Office.

In reply to the address of Sir Alexander Galt on behalf of the deputation, the Earl of Derby said: “I thank you for your address, and for the expressions of personal courtesy and goodwill which it contains. Be assured that it will always be a pleasure to me to receive you, collectively or singly, and that any statements which you may bring before me as to the Colonies which you respectfully represent will be carefully listened to and fully weighed. The growing importance of the great self-governed colonies of England is recognized by every Englishman, of whatever party or class. We rejoice in their strength and prosperity, and we have a right to expect results such as the world has not often seen, where the energies and the experience of an ancient civilization are applied to a boundless territory and an unexhausted soil. Old men are said to live again in their children, and it is the rare privilege of England to have been able to extend the freedom which she has won for herself over an empire wider than any which in former ages has acknowledged a single head. The position which our country will hold in the history of the future will, in my judgment at least, depend far more on her achievements in the way of colonization, and on the diffusion of our race over so many of the choicest regions of the earth, than on the part we have played or may still play in Europe. It is difficult to avoid the language of exaggeration in speaking of the possible future of such countries as Canada and Australasia; and if South Africa offers a less extensive field for European settlement, its progress has of late been very remarkable, and is well maintained. We fully recognize and we duly value the attachment of our colonial kinsmen to the Constitution under which we live, to the mother country from which they have sprung, and to the empire of which, though divided by distance, they continue to form an integral part. It will be my duty and my wish, and it will be equally that of any Minister who may hereafter stand in my place, to take care that the deep interest felt by the people of these islands in the welfare of the colonies shall find adequate expression in the language and in the actions of the official representative of the Crown.”', 'last_edit_date': '1883-01-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1883#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.597, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE UNITED STATES AND THE CONGO.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'NEW YORK, Jan. 10.

result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles present contrasting perspectives on the claim that women significantly influenced societal development in 19th-century Africa through philanthropic activities and by challenging traditional gender roles. The General History of Africa textbook refutes this claim, highlighting the deterioration of women's status during the colonial period. It notes that women were largely excluded from activities introduced or intensified by colonialism, such as Western education and various professions, and were not given a place in the new colonial political setup. Even in matrilineal societies, there was a shift towards patrilineal systems, emphasizing the marginalization of women rather than their active involvement in societal development. In contrast, The African Times articles support the claim by detailing the efforts of women like Mrs. Joseph Moseley, who established a female school at Cape Coast to elevate the moral and social status of African women through education. The articles also mention other women, such as Mrs. Ingham, who trained African women as nurses, and the Methodist Christian Women’s Association, which engaged in fundraising and organizing bazaars. These activities illustrate women's active roles in philanthropy and their efforts to improve social conditions, thereby challenging traditional gender roles. However, the articles do not explicitly discuss the broader societal impact of these efforts or their perception in the context of 19th-century African society, leaving an area of interest for historians studying women's influence during this period.
