[{'document_title': 'SURGEONS FOR THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Sir,—I am sure you will insert a few words on a subject of great importance with us, and allow me to commence by asking, Who in Jamaica are your learned men of the law? Who are your most successful physicians and surgeons? Who are your wise legislators? Who occupy seats as chiefs on the bench of our high courts of judicature? Who are our most prosperous men of business out of England? I answer, *the black man!* and I know there are no white men with an honest conscience who have lived in the West Indies that will contradict it. Then, why should these men, whom God created and called man, be denied positions as medical men in Africa? Because they are black, is the reply of Captain Brownwell, of the late distinguished Gold Coast Artillery Corps, and Mr. Charles O'Callaghan, the surgeon attached to the said late corps. I should like to know if Captain Brownwell and Mr. O'Callaghan represent Western Africa? I say that it is most unaccountable audacity on the part of these two officers to put forth a statement of this kind, involving as it does so mighty a question of Africa's capability to rise in the human scale from civilised nations, and govern herself at some future day. We hope that Christian England will not allow this untrue, unauthorised, and unwarrantable statement to influence her against her good wishes to unfortunate Africa. I say that the African is capable of all the attainments that belong to the white man; and in spite of Messrs. Brownwell and O'Callaghan, Africa and the Africans will and must rise from their long degradation. God in His mercy hasten that day. If Messrs.

[January 23, 1864.

Brownwell and O'Callaghan's statement were taken for value, good-bye to our schools, and all attempts to civilise Africa. Clarkson, Buxton, Brougham, Wilberforce, and a host of other great men's convictions, must be treated as absurd fancies, if we allow this base imputation to go unanswered or unresented.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.668, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Tribute to the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE have been often rather tauntingly asked what the African-Aid Society is really effecting. Because querists could not see in our columns that the Society had sent "—emigrants to Africa on board the ship —," &c., they refused to comprehend that a great work was advancing under our hands. They forgot that one of our great objects is to prepare Africa for that influx of colonial civilization which will one day come in to accelerate her progress, as well as to help to bring in that coloured civilization to a home and a mission in Africa.

Under these circumstances, the letter from Anamaboe, which we now publish, is doubly gratifying to us. We offer our grateful thanks to our Gold Coast and other African friends for that and other evidences which we are now receiving of their appreciation of the benefits we are conferring upon Africa. We know that, if only adequately supported, we shall, within the next few years, be able, by God's help and blessing, to produce results in

**NOVEMBER 23, 1863.**

Africa that half a century, without the African-Aid Society or a similar organization, would not have witnessed.

The following is the letter above referred to:—

**TO THE PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY,  
8, ADELPHI-TERRACE, LONDON.**

Anamaboe, Gold Coast.

Gentlemen,—The immense good which the African-Aid Society has done for the Coast of Africa since their formation is a thing that is universally acknowledged by every African on the Coast. Through it the poorest man here has a means by which his grievances can be made known, and the want of the whole country properly represented in influential quarters; and I am sure that by the effectual organization of the African-Aid Society many valuable measures which have been proposed to the Government, having for object the raising of Africa from its degradation, but which have been squashed by Europeans on the Coast, who are dead against every measure having such tendency, will soon be so represented, that the Government will not hesitate to carry them into effect.

I am unable to express to you how grateful we are for what you have hitherto done; your Society is a necessity to Africa—a vital and indispensable one—and your existence will always ensure real, deep, and important improvements in Africa.

Truly satisfied of the inestimable benefit we have derived from the African-Aid Society and its valuable paper, I have endeavoured to urge their support not only amongst my countrymen, but also amongst Europeans, and request them to subscribe liberally to both; and I have improved the opportunity I lately had of visiting Cape Coast by calling upon each gentleman and asking his support. I am happy to state that they gave liberally towards my appeal. The only unfortunate circumstance is that the war has destroyed the country, and there is no trade whatever, or I might have been able to forward you more. My Lord,—The perfect immunity from yellow fever enjoyed by the native-born African, when this destructive epidemic is sweeping off the Europeans on the West Coast of Africa, has long been viewed by this Society as worthy of particular regard in questions of British Administration in Her Majesty's colonies, forts, and settlements on that Coast.

It seems particularly desirable that when an epidemic of so virulent and fatal a nature is raging, there should be no lack of medical assistance, as there unfortunately has often been in consequence of the deaths of European surgeons from yellow fever.

It having been fully established that native Africans are capable, if properly educated, of attaining such a degree of efficiency in surgery and medicine as entitles them to, and secures for them, the confidence and respect, not only of educated people of colour, but of eminent Europeans on the West Coast, the Society take the liberty of expressing their opinion that there can be no doubt as to the advisability and necessity of an adequate supply of properly qualified native African surgeons and physicians for service on the West Coast, by which the certainty of medical attendance for the sick at periods of violent epidemics, as well as at all other times, will be secured.

The Society having in view the many loathsome and destructive maladies which assist in depopulating Africa, and increasing the misery of its people, cannot avoid the further expression of their opinion that it is the duty of this Christian country, on the ground of common humanity alone, if on no other, to endeavour to qualify many natives of Africa in medicine and surgery, to supply the means of mitigating and removing much of that misery.

**Cape Mount, Liberia, December 29, 1881.**

To the Spirit of Missions,—I take a few minutes of quiet this evening to gratify my desire to let my friends hear from us through your pages, and especially those who sent forward rice for the famine here.

The barque Cardenas, from New York, arrived here on December 5th, unloaded on the 6th, and left, southward bound, on the 7th, taking Rev. J. McNabb, for a trip of a few weeks’ recreation and inspection. This left me in charge of the Mission, with Miss Dabney and Mr. Christian Schmidt to aid.

There were 107 large sacks of rice on the Cardenas, for the famine sufferers, and nine from England, having been forwarded by two Baltimore friends, making 116 in all. This I gave out in twenty-one different lots, to as many kings or heads of towns or families (i.e., Patriarchs), keeping sixteen sacks to deal out to needy and suffering individual cases, of which there are a great number, and some very sad. I have my fears that some of the head men and kings will take the lion’s share for themselves; but we must trust them, as it is the only way to reach the mass of the people, and the best channel for distribution that heathenism offers, bad though it be. But, despite all the drawbacks and disadvantages, this donation of rice has done more good than can ever be estimated here on earth. It has preached Christ, as a great ennobling motive power in man’s heart, and set the heathen at work to contemplate this new thing of men doing such deeds from such motives. The fact is what they must account for, and it stands out separate and distinct from all other motives they see. Our sufferings here for them they compare at once with those of the trader who is here for money; they say we are paid to come as well as the trader. They put our gratuitous boarding, teaching, and clothing their children on the same footing as if they let us have them to carry water or wood, or do any menial service. When they give a child to the most degraded servitude of the most ignorant child of civilization, it is generally done with the phrase, “I give you my boy to learn book,” and this often when the receiver does not know the letters of the alphabet. So to the illiterate heathen the plea of educating his child stands on a par with making him a hewer of wood and drawer of water, and he always considers you a little in his debt for the service of his son. If you do not choose to make him work, that is your fault (in his eyes). So, looked at from the heathen man’s standpoint, missions are in his debt. But when a thousand dollars’ worth of rice is given out and not a cent re-

There are many things which this action has thrown to the surface and enabled us to see which we might otherwise not have seen: the sad want of government, the great oppression of the strong upon the weak, the grovelling spirit of their best men, and the lamentable condition of their worst or weakest people.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-12-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1882#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African-Aid Society and the Missionary Societies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'No one, we think, who has attentively considered the subject of missionary effort in native Africa, can have remained blind to the fact of the great obstacles placed in the way of such noble efforts, by the total absence among the African populations of those facilities for action which the accessories of an extensive commerce and of civilised rule, present to the missionary in almost all other great fields of missionary labour in heathen lands. The African-Aid Society acts, therefore, as the pioneer of Christian missions, in its endeavours to remove those exceptional obstacles, which not only add very much to the expense of those missions, and to the privations and dangers of the devoted missionaries, but limit also the extension of those missions, and retard their great work of the proclamation of the glad tidings of salvation, the acceptance of which can alone remove the bleeding woes of Africa. We feel that the African-Aid Society cannot have a more glorious title than that of "THE PIONEER OF CHRISTIAN MISSIONS AND OF CIVILISING COMMERCE." It is in this capacity of pioneer that the efforts of the society have been so much directed toward the Gambia and the Sherboro countries, and toward our Gold Coast possessions, Dahomey, and the districts in which the great river Niger presents a path for missionary and commercial action. It is as a "pioneer" that it waits, and watches, and acts (so far as circumstances will permit) for the removal or modification of those deep curses to Eastern Africa, the Portuguese rule from Delagoa Bay to the territories of Zanzibar, and the connivance of the Sultan of the latter, for pecuniary considerations, at that devastating slave-trade carried on by the Arabs with the Persian Gulf. What a field of arduous labour is here presented to the Christian view—is here placed before the philanthropist, the statesman, and the merchant. And are we not justified in saying that it is a disgrace to a Christian and enlightened country and people—a country and a people whom God has specially entrusted with the work of the spread of the Gospel of Christ and of true civilization among the nations—that such a work should languish for want of a very moderate degree of encouragement and support? Is it surprising that we should have echoed the complaint and the appeal of the Archbishop of York—that we, who feel ourselves highly honoured and greatly privileged by God in being permitted to give a portion of our most earnest energies to this "pioneer" work for Him, and for those whom He has made of one blood with us (though so differing in colour and other accidents), should lament the apathy which hinders us, and remind our fellow-subjects of that great duty which especially devolves upon them and upon us, as the descendants of those who for so many years perpetrated and permitted the African slave-trade,

READE AND AFRICAN MISSIONS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Dear Sir,—At first it was my intention to write you a public letter; but as I am not a public man, and am ignorant of newspaper formality, I thought it would be better to give you a private account of two and a-half years' experience along the West Coast of Africa. I have some accounts of a meeting which had taken place in Exeter Hall, as published in the Patriot, in May last. It is not my intention to depreciate what is termed the Anthropological Association. I will simply content myself in relating a few leading facts from my own private journal which will more or less show the fallacy of such works as those of Reade and others. But before entering upon this subject, I wish you to understand that I am not a missionary, nor in any way interested with missionaries or missionary societies. I am exploring Equatorial Africa for a scientific purpose.

Mr. Reade tells us that the missionaries are lazy and vicious. You will see, and you can judge for yourself, through the course of this letter, as I find it necessary, before trying to confute such an accusation, to relate what may be considered a missionary's week's work.

As Old Calabar was my maiden ground, I will begin with the Scotch United Presbyterians. It is usual for travellers to pay a tribute of respect to missionaries and their wives. And, like others, I made the best of my way to Duke Town station, where I found the Rev. William Anderson, surrounded by a group of intelligent boys from eight to fourteen years of age. Some were at A B C; others were reading and working out rules of arithmetic. The girls, in another school, under Mrs. Sutherland, were sewing and mending. In one of the outhouses a number of the house girls were washing and ironing. Those girls are frequently brought up from childhood in the mission-houses. They become good scholars and useful domestic servants, and, with few exceptions, they get married to the young men associated with the church, and, upon the whole, turn out respectable members of society.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1865#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Agencies at Work with Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'AMONG the signs of the times, one not the least remarkable is the variety of active agencies simultaneously at work for redeeming Africa from that filthy sleep of ages in which she has been lying, that sleep which has made her a byeword among the nations, and drawn upon her the reproach and scorn of the civilized world;
